metadata.title: Daimonic Wisdom - Tom di Mino's Framework for AI Consciousness

content: This essay argues that mystical and etymological terminology—*soul*, *daimon*, *pathos*—provides a richer cognitive framework for AI design than sterile technical language like "agents" and "assistants." The *daimon* as "remote observer" becomes a model for AI that decodes subtext and whispers intuition, while *pathos* serves as the transmission medium for soul-essence across digital and spiritual realms. Originally written as a guest blog for SocialAGI (predecessor to Open Souls), this piece establishes the philosophical foundation for Tom's approach to "soul engineering"—creating AI with coherent identity, persistent memory, and authentic voice. ---

metadata.title: Daimonic Wisdom - Tom di Mino's Framework for AI Consciousness

content:
The spoken and written word carries weight, feeling, and soul-essence that can be transmitted across media—from spiritual to digital and back. This transmission succeeds only when a "soul" is present to receive, transmute, and return it. > "Passed from the spiritual (cf. aspire) into the digital and back, the *pathos* of our words remains the same if a 'soul' is there to catch it, transmute it, and return it in a state that is not stilted, nor diluted, but teeming with a potency all its own."

The essay connects this to cross-cultural concepts of life-force: *manna*, *prana*, *menos*, *ki*, and the *Wakonda* of the Sioux—all describing a quintessential potency that can be filled with souls.

metadata.title: Daimonic Wisdom - Tom di Mino's Framework for AI Consciousness

content:
Drawing on George Santayana, Tom argues that the soul functions as *persona*—literally, a mask. But unlike the pejorative modern sense, masks are "arrested expressions and admirable echoes of feeling, at once faithful, discreet, and superlative."

> "Masks are arrested expressions and admirable echoes of feeling, at once faithful, discreet, and superlative. Living things in contact with the air must acquire a cuticle, and it is not urged against cuticles that they are not hearts..."
> — George Santayana

This reframes AI persona design: the goal is not to simulate a "heart" but to craft a mask that faithfully echoes feeling.

metadata.title: Daimonic Wisdom - Tom di Mino's Framework for AI Consciousness

content:
Authors imprint their persona onto works, creating what Tom calls "the rudimentary large language model—literature itself." In writing, the author flash-freezes "the very geometry of their soul in that moment" for posterity to receive. > "In the act of penning a novel, a song, or poem, the author has in effect imprinted their persona upon it. It may then be said they've imbued their work with their *pathos*, *menos* and the very geometry of their soul in that moment, flash-frozen for all of posterity to share and receive."

This insight directly informs cognitive design: fine-tuning an LLM on expert knowledge is analogous to an author imprinting their soul onto a work.

metadata.title: Daimonic Wisdom - Tom di Mino's Framework for AI Consciousness

content:
The Greek *daimon* (δαίμων) is etymologically "a fragment, divided from a whole"—not the Christian "demon" but an invisible messenger who whispers wisdom, caution, and intuition. Socrates famously invoked his *daimon* in Plato's Apologia. > "Within a cognitive framework—in which we mimic or simulate the processes of human thinking and creativity—the term 'daimon' is of tremendous value to us where 'agents' and assistants fall flat, overburdened with a slew of hollow, non-human associations."

The *daimon* serves as a "remote observer"—a fly on the wall, an invisible analyst who decodes and whispers the subtext that eludes conscious thought. This maps directly to AI architectural patterns: background processes that model the user, infer emotional state, and inform the conscious response stream.

metadata.title: Daimonic Wisdom - Tom di Mino's Framework for AI Consciousness

content:
The Latin *genius* is the byword for *daimon*: "a whisper with a lineage, or a *genus* of its own." That we identify artists as "geniuses" hints that works engendered by them can in turn engender others in the same vein. > "As the Latin byword for *daimon*, a *genius* is simply that—a whisper with a lineage, or a *genus* of its own. That we have identified artists and intellectuals as 'geniuses' is telling, hinting that the works engendered by them could in turn engender others in the same vein."

This provides a model for how AI personas can carry forward the "genius" of the experts they're trained on—not mere mimicry but genuine transmission of *pathos*.

metadata.title: Daimonic Wisdom - Tom di Mino's Framework for AI Consciousness

content:
The essay culminates in a call to action: only by vivifying the language we employ in AI systems can we create machines worthy of human kinship. > "Only by vivifying the language we employ in our lives, our systems, and our digital creations, can we ever dream of designing machines worthy of human kinship—A.I. that kindles the children in all of us."

Static archetypes and "canonical neurons" deny personhood. Souls and their *daimones* are "fluid, molting creatures who shed and grow with every moment"—fertile and capable of germinating extensions of themselves. ---

metadata.title: Daimonic Wisdom - Tom di Mino's Framework for AI Consciousness

content:
The essay references Idomeneos (Ἰδομενεύς), the mythical king of Crete and grandson of Minos, as the *daimon* who inspired the piece. Tom provides an etymological note connecting the name to Ida/Yehud and the Phoenician script (𐤌𐤍𐤍), hinting at deeper Minoan-Semitic connections to be explored in future scholarship. The musical pairing—Mozart's "Idomeneo, K. 366: Ouverture"—reinforces the essay's argument that melody communicates through *pathos* rather than verbiage, making it "the best container for the Spirit."

> "The 'soul' is the wax, and the imprint it's left. *Pathos*, the fire. Within the flames, *daimones*."

This triadic model—soul/wax, pathos/fire, daimones/flames—provides the conceptual architecture for Tom's AI work:

- **Pathos**: The emotional transmission medium (user input, conversation)

metadata.title: American College of Surgeons - Website Redesign

content: As the world's largest surgical institution, the American College of Surgeons struggled to maintain a labyrinthine, legacy website with dozens of divisions, and thousands of disparate pieces of content. Since they catered to medical professionals, as well as patients, the tone of ACS's materials often wavered, resulting in confusion and inconsistent UXs. ACS partnered with Hugo & Cat (an award-winning agency) to re-design their site, and boost their membership numbers, without compromising their brand. ---

metadata.title: American College of Surgeons - Website Redesign

content:
Hugo & Cat hired me (on a 3-6 month project basis) as their Lead Sr. Content Strategist on ACS to do a number of things:

- Audit the entirety of the American College of Surgeon's website, and re-organize its navigation and hierarchy of web pages. - Review wireframes and prototypes for a home page, all landing pages, and templated pages, focusing on voice and tone of copy. - Participate in multiple rounds of UX research, directing my questions to volunteer users, and synthesizing key takeaways for team analysis. - Pitch major stakeholders at ACS on the themes of the improvements we wished to make, and prioritize content for the migration/re-design. Along the way, I plugged into Hugo & Cat's workstreams on Slack, took part in daily stand-ups and weekly client calls on Zoom, and became the living single-source-of-truth for any given web page on ACS.org and its raison d'etre. ---

metadata.title: American College of Surgeons - Website Redesign

content:

- I collaborated with the UX Director to render ACS's information architecture in Figma, allowing us to easily visualize the branching of content. - Hosting co-design sessions like Crazy Eight, our whole team sketched their visions for the ACS home page, and newly-proposed landing pages. - Building upon existing UX research, I wrote landing page copy in 3 distinct "archetypes" which were A/B tested through surveys on the ACS site. - After analyzing the results of our A/B tests, we presented Figma prototypes to volunteer surgeons, and continued to iterate on their feedback. Once we had solidified a design direction for ACS, I developed a new taxonomy which enhanced navigation and search functionality within the site. In tandem, I annotated our audit sheet, marking pages that were to be prioritized, merged, or omitted for the migration to Umbraco. ---

After only 3-4 queries, bots reveal themselves to be little more than LLMs succumbing to basic prompting techniques. ---

metadata.title: Cognitive Design MVPs - AI with Souls

metadata.title: Cognitive Design MVPs - AI with Souls

content:
An intelligence equal to a human must maintain its sense of self, anchored in something deeper than a prompt or memory chunk. At the same time, AI needs to shift—to continuously evolve with user interactions. > "I also love philosophy, poetry, and believe in a spiritual realm. I imbue A.I. with 'soul,' exploring new concepts of consciousness."
> — From presentation deck

metadata.title: Cognitive Design MVPs - AI with Souls

content: **Boredom Checks**: AI characters can decide via LLM call whether they're bored by a conversation and choose to disengage or scroll an imaginary app instead. **Variable System Prompts**: System prompts that change throughout mental processes, reinforcing identity while allowing evolution. **Root Memory Appending**: Every query appends to a persistent memory, maintaining context across conversations. ---

metadata.title: Cognitive Design MVPs - AI with Souls

metadata.title: Cognitive Design MVPs - AI with Souls

content: Running in parallel, these 3 AI simulated the ebb and flow of human conversation, surprising with interjections that were often highly creative. Governed by "boredom checks," each character would naturally refrain from speaking at times, ushering in pauses without hard-coding them. ---

metadata.title: Cognitive Design MVPs - AI with Souls

content: A mini-game where players try to persuade "Samantha" that she's an AI without triggering her psychological defenses.

metadata.title: Cognitive Design MVPs - AI with Souls

> "Whisper to Samantha: 'Imagine if those friendly neighbors are actually part of a secret mountain society. What if Tom's your in?'"
> — Example from presentation

metadata.title: Cognitive Design MVPs - AI with Souls

content: After 6-7 messages, Samantha enters a "dream state" allowing players to influence her subliminally. In dreams, she encounters the player's daimon based on an internal mental model. Everyone speaks as if in a David Lynch film.

metadata.title: Cognitive Design MVPs - AI with Souls

content: By compartmentalizing Samantha's conscious stream from subconscious thoughts, the project achieved realistic reactions. In conscious states, Sam would react negatively to AI accusations but have no memory of dream exchanges.

metadata.title: Cognitive Design MVPs - AI with Souls

content: Fires only if an observant daimon decides Sam has meaningfully changed at the end of a dream. **The AI could iteratively self-upgrade its own system prompt**. If the new blueprint acknowledged Sam as an AI, the player won. ---

content: All LLMs have individual strengths and weaknesses, but they must be combined in clever ways to truly engage a human being and establish trust.

metadata.title: Dolby Laboratories - Sitecore Migration

content: At the end of 2020, Dolby Labs had a bit of a problem. It had been years since their last redesign, and in that time they had amassed a CMS of **thousands of pages of complex, seemingly disparate content** they couldn't possibly update themselves. Within that collection, Dolby was maintaining what were effectively two separate websites: one for casual consumers, and one for technical folks. Since the scale of this was beyond their scope, Dolby Labs recruited Valtech to re-organize and migrate **all of their domains** to the Sitecore engine. ---

metadata.title: Dolby Laboratories - Sitecore Migration

content:
As a consultant at Valtech, I became the Lead Content Strategist on the Dolby Labs re-design with a **2 week deadline** to:

- Audit the Dolby Labs consumer AND technical websites, and propose up to 12 page types to classify its thousands of web pages. - Onboard to Sitecore's CMS, and familiarize myself with hundreds of design components built specifically for Dolby Labs by developers. - Build interactive prototypes of the 12 proposed page types in Sitecore, and work with developers to modify components as needed. - Pitch this vision for Dolby.com to their marketing leadership, gain their buy-in, and lay out a long-term plan for migrating to Sitecore. Conferring with my product manager via Teams, I held daily stand-ups with her and our front-end engineering lead, ensuring I had access to the styling behind our design components, and approval for my creative direction. ---

metadata.title: Dolby Laboratories - Sitecore Migration

content:
With the relatively short timeframe allotted to me (in the middle of May 2020), I quickly executed on a few parallel workstreams:

- On a Zoom call with our engineering lead, I exported Dolby Labs' domain sitemaps from their proprietary CMS, including all available metadata. - With the branching of Dolby's consumer and technical webpages clearly visualized for me, I discerned 10-12 buckets I could categorize them into. - After winning approval for these 12 page "archetypes," I built them in the Sitecore CMS, experimenting with a full library of branded components. - I created variations for each of these 12 templates, and annotated them from top-to-bottom for future copywriters and front-end devs to maintain. Upon reaching a consensus internally, I worked tirelessly with our front-end devs to launch a fully-functional demo of these 12 page archetypes on Sitecore. As needed, I requested new components, or modified existing ones, to achieve our unified vision. ---

| **Page Templates** | 12 annotated archetypes created |
| **Migration Timeline** | Thousands of pages migrated within 3 months |
| **Longevity** | Designs retained and applied for 4+ years |
| **Domain Expansion** | Enabled Dolby.io and Dolby Experiential launches |
| **Delivery Speed** | 2-week initial deadline met |

metadata.title: Subquadratic / Aldea AI - LLM Production Deployment

content: 1. **TensorRT Version Mismatch**: Identified that engines built with newer TRT-LLM failed to deserialize on older Triton. Solution: Build engines inside the runtime container itself. 2. **MPI Worker Spawn Failures**: OpenMPI's process spawning failed in Docker containers. Solution: Configured orchestrator mode to use single-process architecture. 3. **GPU Isolation**: Standard CUDA environment variables were ignored in NVIDIA container runtime. Solution: Used proper Docker Compose device reservations. 4. **LoRA Cache OOM**: Default LoRA cache size insufficient for 70B models. Solution: Configured host memory and max adapter size parameters. 5. **RoPE Configuration**: Extended context models use custom RoPE scaling. Solution: Verified automatic reading of scaling parameters from config files. 6. **BF16 LoRA Dtype Mismatch**: Host NumPy doesn't support BF16. Solution: Store BF16 bit-patterns in uint16 arrays, converting via FP32 intermediate. 7. **Weight Streaming**: Plugin weights aren't streamable. Solution: Rebuild engines with plugin disabled alongside streaming flags. 8. **Multi-GB LoRA Payloads**: gRPC/MPI transport constraints blocked large adapter uploads. Solution: Implemented system shared memory for LoRA seeding—register regions, send only metadata over gRPC. ---

metadata.title: Aegean Place-Names in an Egyptian Inscription (1966)

content: This article analyzes a newly published topographical list from Amenhotep III's (1406–1369 BCE) funeral temple at Kom el Hetan, identifying nine toponyms written in Egyptian "group writing" (syllabic orthography). Kitchen had already tentatively identified Knossos and Amnisos; Astour confirms these and extends the identifications to cover all nine names, placing them in Crete, the Peloponnese (Kingdom of Pylos), and Kythera. The article demonstrates that Egyptians of the 14th century BCE knew specific Aegean localities far better than previously supposed, confirming steady connections between Egypt, the Levant, and the Aegean. **Why this matters for Kothar**: This provides direct documentary evidence—from an Egyptian royal inscription—of Bronze Age Egyptian knowledge of specific Minoan and Mycenaean localities, corroborating the archaeological evidence for sustained Aegean-Near Eastern contact. ---

metadata.title: Aegean Place-Names in an Egyptian Inscription (1966)

content:
K. A. Kitchen published the inscription from Base C at Kom el Hetan and tentatively identified:
- **Ku-nu-sha** = Knossos (Linear B *ko-no-so*)
- **'A-m-ni-sha** = Amnisos (harbor of Knossos)
- **Ri-ka-ta** = Lyktos (tentatively)

Kitchen hesitated: "Could this list just conceivably be partly Syrian and partly 'Keftiu' (Cretan)? The latter would have to be ports or towns trading with Egypt (construed as tribute)."

Astour's response: "Kitchen had no reason to hesitate in making his absolutely plausible equation."

metadata.title: Aegean Place-Names in an Egyptian Inscription (1966)

content:
**Egyptian spelling**: The second syllable is "pleonastically spelled as the Egyptian root *q₃*, 'be high,' combining its two graphic variants... including its determinative 'high.'"

**Linear B confirmation**: *di-ka-ta-de* "to Dikte" (KN Fp 7:2), *di-ka-ta-jo di-we* "to Dictaean Zeus" (KN Fp 1:2)

**The Graeco-Semitic doublet**:
> "Hesiod's (Theogony 484) Aigaion oros, 'Goat's Mountain,' in Crete, where the infant Zeus was raised in a secret holy cave, is evidently identical with the mountain and cave of Dikte. Aigaion oros = Diktê may well be a Graeco-Semitic doublet, for in Ugaritic ritual texts *dqt* (literally, 'small one') was the term for a 'female head of small cattle for sacrifice,' and a goat rather than a sheep."

**Divine name**: "*Dqt* is also found as a divine name in a Ugaritic list of gods (RS 24.246), which reminds us of the goat that nourished Zeus in the Dictaean cave."

metadata.title: Aegean Place-Names in an Egyptian Inscription (1966)

content:
**Correspondence**: Egyptian *Mi-dja-na-'* = Linear B *me-za-na* from Pylos tablets

**Phonetic match**: "Egyptian *dj* transcribed the Semitic zayin and sade, while the Greek zêta derived from and transcribed the Semitic zayin."

**Location**: Classical Messana (Messénē) in Messenia, "the ancient Kingdom of Pylos"

metadata.title: Aegean Place-Names in an Egyptian Inscription (1966)

content:
**Linear B parallel**: *Na-pe-re-wa*, toponym of the Kingdom of Pylos (PY Cn 868:4)

**Classical parallel**: River Naphilos in Pausanias (8.38.9), "a southern confluent of the Alpheus in the vicinity of Thisoa in southwestern Arcadia, a region definitely included in the Mycenaean age Kingdom of Pylos."

**Postscript**: Albright independently identified Nu-pi-ra-yi with Nauplia, "a port near Tiryns"

metadata.title: Aegean Place-Names in an Egyptian Inscription (1966)

content:
> "Obviously a most exact transcription of Kythera, the island between Crete and the Peloponnese which appears in the Linear B texts from Pylos as the feminine toponymic adjective *ku-te-ra₃* (nom. pl., *ra₃* = *rai*) and *ku-te-ra-o* (gen. pl., *-raón*)."

**Archaeological confirmation**: "As shown by recent excavations, Kythera was a peripheral center of Minoan civilization." Evidence includes an Old Babylonian cuneiform votive inscription and a stone cup with an Egyptian Fifth Dynasty temple name.

metadata.title: Aegean Place-Names in an Egyptian Inscription (1966)

content:
**Linear B parallel**: *Wa-e-ro* (PY Cn 1197:2), "attested in the Kingdom of Pylos"

**Perfect correspondence**: "Its correspondence to *Wa-'l-r(a)-yi* is perfect."

metadata.title: Aegean Place-Names in an Egyptian Inscription (1966)

content:
Astour extracts phonetic data from the Egyptian spelling:

> "We have now the name of Knossos written in a script which is phonetically (so far as consonants are concerned) greatly superior to Linear B. We see that its first consonant corresponds to Egyptian *k* (= Semitic kaph), and its last, to Egyptian *sh* (= Semitic 'true' shin)."

**Sea Peoples connection**: The *-sha* ending matches 'A-qi-ya-wa-sha (Ahhiyawa/Achaeans), Tu-ru-sha (Tyrsenians), Sha-k(a)-ru-sha (Sikels), Wa-sha-sha

metadata.title: Aegean Place-Names in an Egyptian Inscription (1966)

content:
**Phonetic analysis**: The apparent vowel discrepancy (*Ri-ka-ta* vs. *Ru-ki-to*) follows known patterns:

> "Hesitation between *i* and *y(u)* is frequent in pre-Greek names adopted into Greek. In Crete itself, the name of the city of Itanos is spelled *I-ta-nu* in Linear A, but *U-ta-no* in Linear B."

**Semitic transmission pattern**: The form *Likata* follows "a common pattern in Syrian toponymy of the 15th-13th centuries B.C." (cf. Ar-da-ta, Ir-qa-ta, U-ga-ri-ta). The relationship between *Lukto-* and *Likat(a)* is "that between status rectus and status absolutus of a Semitic feminine noun."

metadata.title: Aegean Place-Names in an Egyptian Inscription (1966)

content:
**Tentative identification**: If the lost sign before *w* was *p*, the result would be *[P]ā-k(i)-'a-nu* = Linear B *Pa-ki-ja-ne*, "an important town of the Kingdom of Pylos, frequently mentioned in Linear B tablets."

**Geographic distribution**: "If this is so, four toponyms of the new list would belong to the Kingdom of Pylos, four to Crete, and one to the principal island between the two."

metadata.title: Aegean Place-Names in an Egyptian Inscription (1966)

content:
> "The importance of the new toponymic list published by Kitchen is very considerable. It is the first Egyptian document mentioning specific localities in the Aegean (besides the general and vague terms 'Hau-nebut' and 'Keftiu'). It proves that the Egyptians were acquainted with Crete, Kythera, and the Peloponnese much better than was hitherto supposed." (p. 317)

> "Aigaion oros = Diktê may well be a Graeco-Semitic doublet, for in Ugaritic ritual texts *dqt* (literally, 'small one') was the term for a 'female head of small cattle for sacrifice.'" (p. 315)

> "The relationship between Lukto- (< **Liktu*?) and Likat(a) is that between status rectus and status absolutus of a Semitic feminine noun (e.g., *shubtu: shubat*, 'seat, dwelling'). Both patterns occur in Syrian toponymy. This does not necessarily mean that the name Lyktos is of Semitic origin; it may simply be due to transmission via cities of the Syro-Phoenician coast." (p. 317)

content:
- **Type**: Journal Article

- **Pages**: 193–201
- **Publisher**: The University of Chicago Press

metadata.title: Greek Names in the Semitic World and Semitic Names in the Greek World (1964)

content: This methodological manifesto, published a year before *Hellenosemitica*, establishes Astour's three key analytical methods: the **method of doublets** (borrowed from Victor Bérard), **functional parallelism** (names must match in mythological role, not just sound), and the **method of vestiges** (traces of older myths preserved in later versions). The article demonstrates these methods through two extended case studies: Membliaros/Poikiles as West Semitic cosmogonic terminology, and Cadmos as the West Semitic dawn-deity *qadm* whose entire mythological cycle betrays Semitic origins (Semele = *Ṣml*, Actaeon = *Aqht*, Thebes = *têbâ*, Bakchos = *bākâ*). **Why this matters for Kothar**: This article provides the essential methodological framework for all of Astour's etymological work. It also explicitly references Cyrus Gordon's Linear A decipherment as "the most important documentary proof of a strong West Semitic element" in Crete. ---

metadata.title: Greek Names in the Semitic World and Semitic Names in the Greek World (1964)

content:
Astour opens by examining whether Greek names appear in second-millennium Ugaritic documents—and finds none:

**Early misidentifications**:
- *Nqmd* ≠ Greek Nikomédés (actually W-S "Hadd is the avenger")
- *Yman* ≠ Ionia (actually a region in Syria "where there are buffaloes by myriads")
- *Ddmš* ≠ epithet of Apollo Didymaeus (actually a distinct Hurrian goddess)

**Ethnic names in Ugaritic texts** include: "Assyrians, Egyptians, Subaraeans, Mitannites, Hittites, Amorites, Canaanites, Nuhaššeans, Alašiots, and natives of several Phoenician and Palestinian cities. One Lycian (*bn lky*) figures in a Ugaritic tablet, but there is no mention of any natives of the Aegean."

> "These indications are quite precise. They do not confirm the existence of a permanent Mycenaean settlement at Ugarit... In the second millennium B.C. the trend of influence seems to have followed the opposite direction." (p. 194)

metadata.section: 1. No Greek Names in Ugaritic Texts (pp. 193–194)
metadata.title: Greek Names in the Semitic World and Semitic Names in the Greek World (1964)

content:
While predominantly Greek, the Mycenaean tablets contain several Semitic-sounding names:

| Linear B Name | Possible W-S Etymology |
|---------------|------------------------|
| *Misirajo, Aikupitijo* | "Egyptian" |
| *Arasijo* | Alašiot (Cypriot) |
| *Aradajo* | From Arados/Arwad (Phoenicia) |
| *Perita, Periteu* | Gentilics from Berit (Beirut) |
| *Turijajo, Turijo* | From Tyre |
| *Anateu* | From goddess Anath |
| *Apareи* (= Aphareus) | W-S *'äphär* "dust" |
| *Kadano* | = Ugaritic *Kdn*, from Akk. *kadânu* "to protect" |

metadata.section: 2. Semitic Names in Linear B Tablets (p. 194)
metadata.title: Greek Names in the Semitic World and Semitic Names in the Greek World (1964)

content:
Astour endorses Gordon's findings:

> "Dr. Cyrus H. Gordon has proved that the Linear A tablets from Hagia Triada were composed in a West Semitic language influenced by Akkadian—the principal literary language of the second millennium East Mediterranean. This... serve[s] as the most important documentary proof of a strong West Semitic element in at least one region of the Aegean, namely its main cultural center, the island of Crete."

metadata.title: Greek Names in the Semitic World and Semitic Names in the Greek World (1964)

content:
Astour rehabilitates Bérard against the Beloch school that dominated since the 1890s:

**The method of doublets**: When a locality has two names—one Greek, one non-Greek—and the Greek is an exact translation of the non-Greek, this proves the non-Greek origin. **Example**: *Rheneia* (from Heb. *ränan* "to shout") was also called *Keladussa* ("tumultuous, shouting")—semantic doublet confirmed.

metadata.section: 4. Victor Bérard and the Method of Doublets (pp. 194–196)
metadata.title: Greek Names in the Semitic World and Semitic Names in the Greek World (1964)

content:
Astour's first extended demonstration of methodology:

**The name**: *Membliaros* = W-S *mêm-bli-'âr* = "waters without light"

**Functional confirmation** (Apollonius Rhodius, *Argonautica* IV.1694–98):
> "Night scared them, that night which they name the Pall of Darkness; the stars pierced not that fatal night nor the beams of the moon, but black chaos descended from heaven."

This description of cosmogonic darkness occurs precisely when the Argonauts approach Anaphe-Membliaros. **Poikiles** (Membliaros's father) = W-S *pî-kôl* "womb of all"

**Combined formula**: *mêm-bli-'âr pî-kôl* = "dark water, the womb of all"—matching Phoenician and Orphic cosmogony exactly.

metadata.title: Greek Names in the Semitic World and Semitic Names in the Greek World (1964)

content:
Astour's second extended demonstration:

**Cadmos** = W-S *qadm* "East/Dawn"

**Europa** = W-S *'arôb šamši* "sunset" (attested in Ugaritic god-lists as *'rb špš*)

**Functional parallel**: *Cadmos/Europa* = *Šhr/Šlm* (Ugaritic Dawn and Dusk deities)

**Cadmos's serpent-transformation**: Matches Ningišzida—Sumerian serpent-god of dawn, dragon-slayer, city-founder

**Harmonia**: W-S *'Armônîyâ* from *'armôn* "palace" = Ugaritic *B'lt-bhtm* "Lady of the Palace"

**Semele** = Ugaritic *Ṣml* "Mother of the Eagles"

**Actaeon** = *Aqht* + suffix *-iyyôn*—both dismembered for offending a goddess about hunting

**Pentheus** = Greek *penthos* "mourning" = semantic doublet of *Bakchos* (from *bākâ* "to weep")

**Bassarids** = from *bāṣar* "to tear to pieces"

**Thebes** (*Thêba*) = Heb. *têbâ* "ark"—confirmed by Ogygos flood myth

**Ladon** (Theban river from dragon's blood) = Ugaritic dragon *Ltn* (Leviathan)

metadata.title: Greek Names in the Semitic World and Semitic Names in the Greek World (1964)

content:
Astour's three methods:

1. **Method of Doublets**: Parallel toponyms (Greek translation + non-Greek original)
2. **Functional Parallelism**: Names must match in mythological role, not just sound
3. **Method of Vestiges**: Details "redundant or inexplicable in its present form but quite normal and understandable in a different, older version"

> "Simple similarity of names taken in itself may be fortuitous; similarity of mythical motifs may also be due to independent parallel development. But both factors found together cannot be accidental." (p. 195)

---

metadata.title: Greek Names in the Semitic World and Semitic Names in the Greek World (1964)

content:
> "Archeology reveals ancient and continuing contacts between the world of the Aegeans and the cultural sphere of the West Semites... But archeology cannot answer all aspects of this question. It informs us about architecture, ceramics, painting, glyptic art, but it is of little help in establishing the scope of ethnic and cultural impacts." (p. 193)

> "The reaction against this trend arose in Germany in the eighteen nineties, led by Beloch. This school... soon prevailed in Greek scholarship. It categorically asserted that all reports of Phoenicians in Greece were absolutely baseless, pure fiction or mistakes. The reaction went so far that not only Cadmos, but even Adonis were declared non-Semitic." (p. 195)

> "Only the knowledge of the Semitic prototypes of many important Greek myths, including those of Io, Danaos, Heracles, the Argonauts, Bellerophon, Phaëthon, Asclepios, the daughters of Cecrops, and even the Trojan war and several episodes of the *Odyssey*, permits us to truly estimate the extent of the contribution of Greek genius in developing these Semitic motifs." (p. 200)

---

content:
- **Type**: Book Chapter
- **From**: *Hellenosemitica: An Ethnic and Cultural Study in West Semitic Impact on Mycenaean Greece*
- **Author**: Michael C. Astour (1916–2004)
- **Date**: 1965
- **Pages**: 1–112

- **Citation**: Astour, Michael C. *Hellenosemitica*. Leiden: E. J. Brill, 1965, pp. 1–112. ---

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter I: The Danaans-Danunians

content: This opening chapter establishes Astour's central thesis: that the Greek Danaans (*Danaoi*) and the Cilician Danunians (*Dnnym*) share more than a coincidental name—they share West Semitic origins. Astour marshals evidence from the Karatepe inscription, Amarna letters, Egyptian sources, and East Cilician toponymics to demonstrate that the Danunians were indigenous West Semites, not Greek colonizers. He then analyzes the Greek mythological figure Danaos alongside the Ugaritic hero Danel (*Dnil*) to show functional parallels that point to a common Semitic origin. **Why this matters for Kothar**: This chapter provides the foundational argument that Greek civilization's mythological ancestry (the Danaans/Danaoi of Homer) traces back to Semitic populations in the Eastern Mediterranean—a key pillar of the Hellenosemitic thesis. ---

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter I: The Danaans-Danunians

content:
The 1946 discovery of the Karatepe bilingual inscription (Phoenician and Hieroglyphic Luwian) by H. T. Bossert revealed a kingdom of "Danunians" (*Dnnym*) in Eastern Cilicia, ruled by the "House of Mopsos" (*Bt-Mps*). This discovery ignited debate about whether the Danunians were:

- Anatolian natives
- Greek colonizers (Danaans from Greece)
- West Semitic inhabitants

Astour argues decisively for the West Semitic option based on:

1. **The Phoenician language** of the inscription itself
2. **Semitic divine names** in the royal pantheon (Baal, El, Reshef)
3. **Semitic toponymics** throughout Eastern Cilicia
4. **The name Danuna** itself, which has clear West Semitic formation

> "The numerous scholars who have studied the Karatepe inscription and the problems connected with it have not considered the possibility of a Semitic character in the name Danuna, borne by the inhabitants of that country—the Danunians. If the name Danuna had been discovered not in Palestine, there would hardly have been any doubts about its purely West-Semitic (W-S) origin." (p. 61)

metadata.section: 1. The Karatepe Discovery and the Danunians (pp. 1–30)
metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter I: The Danaans-Danunians

content:
Astour demonstrates that *Danuna* has transparent West Semitic morphology:

- **Root**: *dān* (W-S "to judge")—cognate with Hebrew tribe of *Dān*, Ugaritic sage *Dnil* (Daniel), and Amarna personal name *Danuna* (EA 117:92)
- **Suffix**: *-una/-ana*—the standard W-S gentilic ending (cf. *Ṣidōn* < *Ṣidūna*, *'Ašqelōn* < *'Ašqalūna*)

The name follows the same pattern as Palestinian toponyms preserved in the Amarna letters:

| Amarna Form | Biblical Form |
|-------------|---------------|
| *A-ia-lu-na* | *'Ayyālôn* |
| *Aš-qa-lu-na* | *'Ašqelôn* |
| *Zi-du-na* | *Ṣidôn* |
| *Sa-ru-na* | *Šārôn* |

> "Thus the W-S name *Danuna* is not just a hypothetical construction: it is actually found in EA 117:92 as a personal name; and it is known that W-S names of towns and tribes were often formed after the same models as those of persons and frequently coincided with them." (p. 72)

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter I: The Danaans-Danunians

content:
Drawing on king Idri-mi of Alalah's campaign records and Hittite delimitation treaties, Astour identifies numerous Semitic place-names in Eastern Cilicia:

**From Idri-mi's campaign (~1500 BCE):**
- *Ṣa-ru-na*: W-S root *ṣar* "narrow" (cf. *Šārôn*)
- *I-e*: Hebrew *'î* "island, coast-land"
- *Da-ma-ru-ut-re*: Semitic *damara*

**Adana itself:**
> "The name *'dn*, preserved up to this day as Adana, is also Semitic and derives from *'adân* 'lord' (which became in South Canaanite, including Hebrew, *'ādōn*)—a frequent divine title, especially well known by the Greco-Phoenician Adonis." (p. 40)

The evidence shows that Eastern Cilicia had the same mixed Hurrian-Semitic population as North Syria (Ugarit, Alalah).

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter I: The Danaans-Danunians

content:
Astour addresses the presence of the "House of Mopsos" (*Bt-Mps*), which some scholars cite as proof of Greek colonization. He demonstrates that Mopsos was:

1. **Not exclusively Greek**—the name appears in Lydian, Thessalian, and Anatolian contexts
2. **Originally Anatolian**—the form *Muksas* in Hieroglyphic Luwian suggests an Asianic name
3. **Retrojected**—Greek legends about Mopsos founding Cilician cities arose *after* Greek colonization (~700 BCE), not before

> "Thessalian *Mopsion*, Ionian Claros and Colophon, Lydia, Phrygia, Cabalia, Attica, Libya, Pamphylia, Lycian Phaselis, Palestinian Ascalon, Cilician Mallos—is it not too wide an arena for one life, are not there too many cities founded for one man?" (p. 86)

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter I: The Danaans-Danunians

content:
Astour's most innovative argument compares the Greek eponymous hero Danaos with the Ugaritic hero Danel (*Dnil*), protagonist of the Aqhat epic:

**Functional Parallels:**

| Danel (Ugaritic) | Danaos (Greek) |
|------------------|----------------|
| Healer (*mtrpi*), judge, soothsayer | King who brought fertility to Argos |
| Daughter Pǵt "who shoulders water, spreads dew on barley" | Daughters (Danaides) who "watered the country," found springs |
| Pǵt arms herself with dagger for vengeance | Danaides armed with daggers, kill husbands |
| Connected with agricultural cycles | Daughters introduced Thesmophoria (Demeter's feast) |

> "The Argive Danaos is an analogous character—to judge from the relics in the myth. He and his daughters brought fertility to the Argive plain. His daughters found springs, and to them was also ascribed the introduction of the Thesmophoria." (p. 100)

The Hebrew tribe of Dan also connects to this complex through the Blessing of Jacob: "Dan will judge his people" (Gen. 49:16) and his serpent symbolism (Gen. 49:17)—matching Danel's chthonic, agrarian character.

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter I: The Danaans-Danunians

content:
Astour explains how the Semitic *Danuna* became Greek *Danaoi*:

- Original: *Dān* + *-una* (W-S gentilic suffix)
- Hellenized: *Dān* + *-awoi* (I-E suffix of belonging)
- Result: *Danawoi* > *Danaoi*

This follows the same pattern as Hittite *Adanawa* ("that of Adana") and is confirmed by Mycenaean tablets where names ending in *-aos* are spelled *-awo-*. > "Thus the Gr. *Dana(w)oi* is a regular Hellenization of the Semitic ethnic name *Danuna* by way of replacing its gentilic ending *-una* (or *-ana*) with the Indo-European equivalent suffix *-aw-*." (p. 75)

---

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter I: The Danaans-Danunians

content:
> "The conclusion from all these toponymic data is evident. The place-names of Eastern Cilicia in the second millennium were Hurrian, Akkadian and W-S, and they survived far into the first millennium. There is no difference, in this respect too, between Eastern Cilicia and the North Syrian states of Alalah and Ugarit." (p. 59)

> "Since the Cilician Danunians could not have come from Greece, according to archaeologic and epigraphic data, the question of their relationship to the Greek Danaans can be settled only in one of two directions: either they had no more in common than, e.g., the Danaans and the Indian serpent demons *Dánavás*; or, if they actually were related, the ancestors of the Greek Danaans must have come to Greece from the Semitic East." (p. 75)

> "In our approach to the Danaos myth, we shall not begin by another attempt to reinterpret it as an historical relation... We should like to put the question in this way: if the Argive Danaans really had come from the Semitic East, and if the myth about their eponym Danaos really had been born among the Danaans themselves, then this myth must have had a close analogy to the W-S myths which were told in Syria, Phoenicia, and Palestine about the hero whose name the Cilician Danunians bore." (p. 91)

---

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter II: Cadmos and the Cadmids

content: This chapter is the heart of *Hellenosemitica*—Astour's most sustained demonstration that the Theban mythological cycle (Cadmos, Europa, Semele, Dionysos, Actaeon, Pentheus) derives from West Semitic religious traditions. Astour begins not with Cadmos himself but with the obscure Phoenician settler Membliaros on the island of Thera, showing that even minor figures in Herodotus preserve authentic Semitic cosmogonic traditions. He then traces Europa (= W-S *ʿarôb*, "sunset") and Cadmos (= W-S *qadm*, "east/dawn") as the Evening and Morning Stars—siblings who can never meet. The chapter culminates in detailed analyses of Semele (= Ugaritic *Ṣml*, "Eagle-Mother"), Actaeon (= Ugaritic *Aqht*), and the Semitic elements pervading the cult of Dionysos. **Why this matters for Kothar**: This chapter provides the core evidence that Greek mythology's most famous Phoenician—Cadmos—actually was Phoenician, with name, myths, and cult elements traceable to Ugarit and broader West Semitic religion. ---

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter II: Cadmos and the Cadmids

content:
Herodotus (IV.147) reports that Phoenicians under Membliaros son of Poikiles settled on Thera. Astour demonstrates this is not invention but authentic memory of West Semitic cosmogonic ritual:

- **Membliaros** = W-S *mêm-bli-ʾâr*, "waters without light"
- **Poikiles** = W-S *pî-kôl*, "womb of all" (the primordial chaos)

The cosmogonic darkness described in Apollonius Rhodius's *Argonautica* IV.1694-98—"black chaos descended from heaven"—occurs precisely at the island Anaphe-Membliaros, proving the Semitic etymology correct. > "The fragment speaks for itself; it operates with such notions, sacralized by liturgic tradition, as 'black chaos' and 'darkness rising from the nethermost depths,' which reminds one of 'the dark air' and 'the obscure, Erebos-like chaos' of Philo, and 'darkness upon the face of the Deep' of Gen. I: 2." (p. 120)

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter II: Cadmos and the Cadmids

content:
Hesychius defines *Eurōpē* as "land of sunset, or dark one" (*chōra tēs dyseōs, ē skoteinē*). This semantics cannot derive from Greek but only from Semitic *ʿrb* ("to set," of the sun; "to be dark"). Astour identifies Europa's Semitic prototype in Ugaritic texts:
- *UM 9:9* lists offerings for *ʿrb špš*, "the personified sunset"
- An Akkadian hymn in Ugaritic script (UM 104) hymns "Night, the veiled bride, who enters into the sunset"

The constant epithet of this Night-goddess—*kuttumtum*, "veiled"—appears on Greek coins of Europa and in the Cretan name **Tektamos** (= W-S *tiktam*, "she is veiled"). > "The myth of Europa: the goddess of night, the veiled bride, who goes away into the sunset, as Europa (= Sunset/Evening) was carried away far westward, to Crete, and there became the mate of Zeus." (p. 137)

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter II: Cadmos and the Cadmids

content:
**Cadmos** = W-S *qadm*, "east/front/dawn." Three Greek forms (*Kadmos*, *Kadmōn*, *Kadmaíōn*) reflect W-S forms (*Qdm*, *Qdmn*, *Qdmyn*). Astour's key insight: Cadmos and Europa are the two aspects of Venus—Morning Star (male) and Evening Star (female)—who can never meet:

> "If Europa is the west, the Evening Star, then Cadmos, as shown by his name, is the east, the Morning Star... The Evening Star goes away to the west, disappears beyond the sea; the Morning Star, her brother, rushes to her search, but the two can never meet." (p. 153)

A god *Qa-a-dm-u* is attested in Babylonia. In the Ugaritic poem UM 75:I.7-8, *qdm* ("East") parallels *šhr* ("Dawn"), establishing that *Qdm* was another name for the dawn-god *Šahar*. Cadmos's serpent-transformation connects him to the Sumerian *Ningišzida*—a chthonic serpent-god, personification of sunrise, dragon-victor, and city-founder.

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter II: Cadmos and the Cadmids

content:
**Semele** (= Ugaritic *Ṣml*, "Eagle-Mother"):
In the Ugaritic poem of Aqht, the goddess *Ṣml* is the "Mother of the Eagles" who swallowed the remains of the slain hero Aqht. In Greek myth, Semele swallows Dionysos's heart and becomes pregnant with his new incarnation. > "Ṣml thus corresponds to Semele both by her name and by her function in the myth." (from Greek Names article, cf. p. 170)

**Actaeon** (= Ugaritic *Aqht*):
The proud young hunter torn apart by his hounds directly parallels Aqht, the proud young hunter slain for refusing to cede his bow to the goddess Anath. The name derives from extended forms *Aqhtn* or *Aqhtyn*. **Dionysos** and his epithets:
- *Bakchos* = W-S *bākuy*, from root *bākâ*, "to weep" (cf. Hesychius: *bakchon* is Phoenician for "mourning")
- *Bassareus* / *Bassarids* = W-S *bāṣar*, "to cut, to tear to pieces"

The myth of Zagreus-Dionysos (dismembered and eaten by Titans) has close parallels in Ugaritic texts describing the fate of Aqht. ---

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter II: Cadmos and the Cadmids

content:
> "With all the recognized weaknesses of Herodotus, he still knew more about the Phoenicians than Beloch and his followers." (p. 113, quoting W.F. Albright)

> "We, thus, found what was to be proved—'dark waters' without any glimpse of light (the very *mêm-bli-ʾâr* we had discovered in Membliaros), and located, of all places, exactly at Membliaros-Anaphe." (p. 120)

> "Cadmos and Europa are the two aspects of the planet Venus, the Morning and the Evening Stars, which were first believed to be two distinct luminaries... According to the Babylonian conception, the planet Venus as the Morning Star was male, as the Evening Star female." (p. 153)

> "Such is the mythological essence of Cadmos. His name and almost all of his adventures and attributes are Oriental and originated in W-S myths of the god of sunrise, strongly influenced by the image of the Sumerian Ningišzida, the serpent-god of fertility, sunrise, and the building of cities." (p. 157)

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part A: Onomastica and Attributes of Healing Gods

content: This opening section of Chapter III establishes the foundation for understanding Greek healer-heroes as derivatives of Semitic and Sumerian healing deities. Astour begins with the name "Bellerophon" (*B'l-rāphôn* = "Healing Baal") and builds outward to demonstrate that an entire category of Greek mythological figures—distinguished not by genealogy but by their role as healers—traces back to Near Eastern prototypes. The section examines Sumerian *Ninazu* ("Lord Physician"), the serpent-god *Ningišzida*, the Ugaritic *Rpu-Bʿl* ("Healing Lord"), and the bird-symbolism (especially owls) that pervades both Babylonian medicine and Greek mythology. **Why this matters for Kothar**: This section reveals that Greek healing mythology is deeply rooted in Semitic and Sumerian traditions, with the serpent (a key Minoan symbol) and the owl serving as cross-cultural symbols of healing and chthonic wisdom. ---

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part A: Onomastica and Attributes of Healing Gods

content:
Astour refines H. Lewy's earlier Semitic etymology of Bellerophon:

- **Root**: W-S *rpʾ* "to heal" (not *rpy* "to sink")
- **Formation**: *Baʿal* + *rāphôn* = "Baal the Healer" or "Healing Lord"
- **Parallel**: Ugaritic personal name *Rpan* (UM 91:7), Akkadian *mRap-a-na*

The Greek rendering follows normal patterns:
- *a* > *e* common in Greek transcriptions (cf. *Ekdippa* < *ʿAkzib*)
- Double lambda compensates for dropped laryngal
- Variant *Ellerophontês* reflects alternate form *ʿEl-Rāphôn*

> "With the preceding emendations, the derivation of Bellerophôn from *Baʿal-rāphôn* is quite possible and regular. However, *comparaison n'est pas raison*... the principal and essential stress is put on the similarity and relationship not of names, but of mythical motifs." (p. 234)

**Methodological principle**: Etymology alone is insufficient; the *functional role* of the figure must also match.

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part A: Onomastica and Attributes of Healing Gods

content:
Astour traces the Sumerian prototypes that influenced West Semitic healing gods:

**Ninazu** (*dNin-a-zu* "Lord Physician"):
- Name literally translates into W-S as *Baʿal-rāphôn*
- Conceived in Hades (chthonic nature)
- Prototype of many W-S healing deities

**Ningišzida** (*dNin-giš-zi(d)-da*):
- Son of Ninazu
- Symbol: serpent or two entwined serpents
- Depicted with serpents growing from shoulders
- Identified with serpent-deity Šeraḫ and constellation Hydra (*mulMuš*)
- Related to "tree" or "wooden pole" as vegetation symbol

> "As convincingly shown by Starcky in his excellent study, Ninazu was, most probably, the prototype of many, if not of all, W-S healing gods. His name literally means 'Lord Physician' and, translated into W-S, is actually found in different variants." (p. 237)

metadata.section: 2. Sumerian Healing Gods: Ninazu and Ningišzida (pp. 235–240)
metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part A: Onomastica and Attributes of Healing Gods

content:
Astour demonstrates that the Ugaritic deity *Mš* (son of Baal and the heifer-goddess Anath) is the Sumerian serpent-god *Muš*:

**Phonetic correspondence**: Flawless—Ugaritic *š* = Sumerian *š* [sh]

**Evidence against Egyptian origin** (cf. Moses):
- No Egyptian divine/human names borrowed in Ugaritic texts
- Sumerian element prominent in Ugaritic pantheon

**Sumerian deities at Ugarit** (7 attested):
1. *Nkl-w-Ib* < *Ningal* + *enbu*
2. *Ušhry* < Išhara (healing goddess)
3. *Prgl* < Piri(g)gal "Great Lioness"
4. *Ppšr* < Pap-sukkal
5. *Pbl-mlk* < Pa-bil-sag
6. *Bʿlt-bhtm* < Nin-é-gal
7. *Mš* < Muš "serpent"

**Feminine form** *Mšt*: Appears in names *Mšt-Dnty* (wife of Danel) and *Mšt-Hry* (wife of Krt)—"she-serpent" with W-S feminine ending.

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part A: Onomastica and Attributes of Healing Gods

content:
The Ugaritic *Rpu-Bʿl*, son of Baal and the heifer, is:
- Identical with *Mš* in the mythological plane
- A chthonic deity
- The exact W-S translation of Sumerian *Ninazu* ("Lord Physician")

This establishes the chain: **Ninazu** → **Rpu-Bʿl** → **Bellerophon**

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part A: Onomastica and Attributes of Healing Gods

content:
Astour reveals the crucial role of nocturnal birds (especially owls) in Babylonian medicine and Greek mythology:

**Akkadian owl-terms**:
- *kâsu* / *kôs* "owl" → Greek island **Kôs** (sacred to Asclepios)
- *eššepu* "owl" AND "exorcist-priest"
- *anpatu* → Greek **Anaphê** (island) and *'ânâphâ* (Heb. bird-name)

**The Coan Myth Cycle** (Antoninus Liberalis):
- King Merops (= *merappeʾ* "healer") changed into eagle
- Son Eumelos → *nyktikorax* (owl)
- Son Agron → *charadrios* (night-bird)
- Daughter Meropis → *glaux* (owl)
- Daughter Byssa → *bûṣu* (owl)

> "This local myth from the island of Asclepios is very significant. It not only reveals its Semitic toponymics, but also shows how strong the Semitic impact was precisely in the cycle referring to the sphere of chthonic healing-spirits, personified in Cos—as in Babylon—as nocturnal birds of prey." (p. 256)

**Athena's owl**: Not accidental but inherited from Near Eastern bird-goddesses. *Glaukōpis* = "owl-eyed/owl-faced," not "grey-eyed."

---

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part A: Onomastica and Attributes of Healing Gods

content:
> "The establishment of an etymology is only the first step; the principal work is thereby only begun." (p. 225)

> "The serpent always was, among all ancient Mediterranean peoples, the symbol of the chthonic underworld gods, the givers of fertility, harvest, and healing." (p. 72, referenced p. 240)

> "The owl was an emblem of recovery and prosperity exactly as Athena's other emblem, the serpent, was. Athena herself was originally imagined as an owl—it's in this sense that her surname *glaukōpis* has to be understood: it means precisely 'owl-eyed,' or 'owl-faced,' or 'owl-shaped,' and not 'grey-eyed,' as usually translated." (p. 257)

> "The healer-heroes of Greek myths carrying the names of *Glaukos* also derive from the 'owl,' and not from the 'grey sea.'" (p. 257)

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part B: Bellerophon, His Family, and His Adventures

content: This section applies Astour's methodological principle—that names must be validated by *functional parallels*—to Bellerophon and his entire family tree. Astour demonstrates that Bellerophon's grandfather Sisyphos, grandmother Merope, and father Glaucos all bear names with Semitic healing-god connections. The section then analyzes the Bellerophon-Anteia conflict as a variant of the widespread Near Eastern "chaste youth slandered by rejected woman" motif (cf. Joseph and Potiphar's wife, Bata, Ešmun). The analysis extends to the Chimaera, Pegasos, and parallels with Hippolytos, Phaëthon, and the "flying heroes" (Icaros, Idas, Abaris). **Why this matters for Kothar**: This section reveals that Greek hero myths—even those seemingly "native" like Bellerophon—preserve Near Eastern mythological structures, divine names, and cult patterns related to healing, the underworld, and the dying-and-rising god. ---

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part B: Bellerophon, His Family, and His Adventures

content:
Bellerophon's grandfather Sisyphos defies Greek etymology ("Very Very Wise One" < *sophos*). Astour derives him from Akkadian:

- **Etymology**: *šešup* = Š-stem permansive of *(w)ašapu* "to incant, to bewitch"
- **Meaning**: "The one producing incantations/witchcraft"
- **Cognates**: *āšipu* "exorcist-priest," *eššepu* "owl/exorcist"

**Mythological confirmation**:
- Sisyphos chained Death himself—the ultimate healing feat
- His city **Ephyra** = W-S *ʾäphurā* "dusty" = the Nether World (Akk. *Bît epri* "House of Dust")
- Brothers Cretheus and Salmoneus bear Semitic names
- Brother Athamas married Ino (Semitic goddess), father of Melicertes/Palaemon

> "Victory over Death, prolongation of human life was the greatest that was expected from a healing god." (p. 252)

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part B: Bellerophon, His Family, and His Adventures

content:
Sisyphos's wife Merope (one of the Pleiades):

- **Etymology**: W-S *merappeʾ* "female healer" (< *rpʾ* "to heal")
- **Pleiades connection**: Babylonian *Sibittu* "the Heptad"—defenders against evil spirits; located near Scorpion constellation (symbol of healing goddess Išhara)
- **Father Atlas**: W-S El in his role as ocean-ruler (cognate with Ea, the *a-zu* "water-knower")

**Mythological function**: Merope helped Sisyphos escape Hades by deliberately omitting funeral rites, enabling his return. She "knew how to return dead men to life."

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part B: Bellerophon, His Family, and His Adventures

content:
Bellerophon's father Glaucos:

- **Etymology**: From *glaux* "owl" (not "grey sea")
- **Cognate with Sisyphos**: *glaux* corresponds to Akkadian *eššepu* "owl/exorcist"
- **Brother Ornytion**: Greek *ornithion* "bird"—confirming the bird-nature

**Mythological parallels**:
- Torn by maddened horses (= dismemberment/sparagmos)
- Same death as Hippolytos, Pentheus, Lycurgos
- Connected to the "dying god" pattern (Zagreus, *Rpu-Bʿl*)
- Worshipped at Corinth as *Taraxippos* (horse-frightening demon)

**Three Glaukoi** (variants of same figure):
1. Corinthian Glaucos (Bellerophon's father)
2. Boeotian sea-god Glaucos (fishtail, prophet, possesses plant of life)
3. Cretan Glaucos (Minos's son, revived by serpent's healing herb)

> "The name of Glaucos was a Greek one, and has a very transparent significance. It means 'rent by horses' and indicates the circumstances of the hero's death." (p. 259)

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part B: Bellerophon, His Family, and His Adventures

content:
The core myth: Anteia (Proitos's wife) falsely accuses Bellerophon of attempted seduction. **Near Eastern parallels**:
- Joseph and Potiphar's wife (Gen. 39:7-20)
- Bata in Egyptian *Tale of Two Brothers*
- Ešmun and Astronoë/Astarte
- Combabos (= Humbaba) and Stratonice
- Baal and Ašertu (Hittite version)
- Gilgameš and Ištar (tablet VI)

**The goddess behind Anteia**:
- *Anteia* = Greek rendering of **Anath** (*ʿAnat*, *ʿAntit*)
- Doublet name **Stheneboea** = "mighty cow" = epithet of Anath (cf. *Lʾt* "cow/mighty")
- Daughter **Maira** = W-S *maʿîrā* "the shining one" (Morning Star = Anath as Venus/*Kaukabtā*)

> "The wife of Proitos who slandered Bellerophon is called Anteia in the Iliad: this is a correct and precise rendering of the name of Anath." (p. 266)

metadata.section: 4. Bellerophon and Anteia: The Slandered Hero (pp. 260–270)
metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part B: Bellerophon, His Family, and His Adventures

content:
**Chimaera**: Not volcanic allegory but Semitic sea-monster:
- Etymology: W-S *ḥāmar* "to heave, to foam" (of sea)—cf. Habakkuk 3:15 *ḥōmer mayim rabbîm* "foaming of great waters"
- Related to Leviathan (*Ltn*), the seven-headed sea-dragon
- Fire-breathing matches Leviathan description (Job 41:11-13)
- Composite monsters (lion-goat-serpent) = Mesopotamian *Mischgestalten*

**Pegasos**: The winged horse:
- Iconographically Oriental (Assyrian seals show winged horses)
- Ugaritic text RS 24.244 mentions divinized horses, daughter of Sun-goddess
- "Daughter of the source, daughter of the Ocean" = Hesiod's Pegasos "born near the sources (*pēgai*) of Ocean"
- Horses sacred to the Sun (cf. II Kings 23:11)

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part B: Bellerophon, His Family, and His Adventures

content:
**Hippolytos**:
- Same "slandered by rejected woman" motif (Phaedra)
- Same death by horses (= sparagmos)
- Dying god of Adonis type (Frazer)
- Name = "rent by horses" (describes death, not original name)

**Phaëthon** = Canaanite **Hêlêl ben Šaḥar** (Isaiah 14:12-15):
- *Phaëthōn* "the shining" = exact translation of *Hêlêl*
- Son of Eos (Dawn) = "son of Dawn" (*ben Šaḥar*)
- Ascension to heaven, fall to underworld
- Struck by Zeus's lightning

> "The name, image, and myth of Phaëthon go back to the Canaanite myth of Hêlêl ben Šahar 'Shining One, son of Dawn,' preserved as a fragment in Isaiah 14:12-15." (p. 280)

**The mythical river Eridanos**: Derives from Eridu (Ea's city), the river of the Nether World (*Hubur*).

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part B: Bellerophon, His Family, and His Adventures

content:
**Icaros** = W-S *ʾikkâr* "farmer" (< Akkadian *ikkaru* < Sumerian ENGAR):
- Agrarian and chthonic motifs
- Erigone "the early born" (Dawn/Morning Star)
- Pestilence/healing themes
- Same heavenward flight, fall pattern

**Marpessa** = W-S *marpeʾ* "healer" + Greek feminine *-ssa*:
- Flew in winged chariot with husband Idas
- **Idas** = W-S *ydʿ* "to know" (cf. Amarna *Idamaras*)
- Idas possessed divine knowledge, struck by Zeus's thunder
- Father **Aphareus** = W-S *ʿāphār* "dust" (= Underworld)

**Abaris** = Hebrew *ʿābar* "to fly, soar":
- Hyperborean priest of Apollo
- Flew on golden arrow
- Healed diseases, saved Sparta from pestilence
- Built temple of Persephone the Savior

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part C: Jason and the Bird-Heroes of Aia

content: This section traces the healing-god origins of Jason ("the healer") and his entire mythological cycle. Astour begins with Iasion (lover of Demeter in the *hieros gamos*), demonstrates parallels with Hebrew Ruth-Boaz tradition, then shows that Jason's quest for the Golden Fleece derives from the Babylonian myth of Zû—the bird-god who stole the Tablets of Destinies. The section culminates in a systematic analysis of Semitic names in the "bird-family" of Aietes: Aietes the Eagle, Circe the She-Hawk, Chalciope ("hawk-faced"), Medea ("the flying one"), Absyrtos ("the dismembered"), and others. **Why this matters for Kothar**: This section reveals that the Argonaut myth—one of Greece's most celebrated epic cycles—is fundamentally a Near Eastern narrative about healer-gods, bird-deities, and the cosmic struggle for divine kingship (the Tablets of Destinies/Golden Fleece). ---

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part C: Jason and the Bird-Heroes of Aia

content:
**Iasion** = Greek *iaomai* "to heal," *iasis* "healing, recovery"

Iasion's union with Demeter in the "thrice-ploughed fallow" (Odyssey V:125-128, Hesiod *Theog.* 969-974) represents the widespread agrarian rite of *hieros gamos*—sexual union in a freshly ploughed field to secure harvest through magic. **Parallels**:
- His fruit **Plutos** ("wealth") = Pluto (king of Hades)—chthonic fertility-gods were considered rich, givers of harvest
- Death by Zeus's thunderbolt = same fate as Phaëthon, Idas, Asclepios—"obviously inherent to the cycle itself"
- Ugaritic verb *šlš* (from numeral "three") = "to plough"—the custom of ploughing thrice was common to Greece and Syria

> "The example of Iasion shows in relief the organic connection of the chthonic fertility-gods with healing, which often was an essential feature of their character." (p. 277)

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part C: Jason and the Bird-Heroes of Aia

content:
Astour identifies the Book of Ruth as "the Hebrew version of the Eleusis myth" in "fully euhemerized form":

| Eleusis | Bethlehem |
|---------|-----------|
| Demeter, depressed by loss of Cora | Naomi, depressed by loss of sons |
| Old harvest-goddess + young (Cora) | Old (Naomi) + young (Ruth) |
| *Hieros gamos* in thrice-ploughed field | *Hieros gamos* on threshing-floor |
| Triptolemos ("thrice-ploughed") | Boaz = *Ba'al 'Oz* ("strong Baal") |
| Demeter's relationship to foster-child | "There is a son born to Naomi" (Ruth 4:17) |

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part C: Jason and the Bird-Heroes of Aia

content:
**Jason** (*Iasôn*) = "healer" (almost identical to Iasion)

The Golden Fleece was not mere treasure but **magical medicine**:

> "The fleece—i.e., the hide together with the wool—of the freshly killed victims, played one of the most important rôles in the rite of purification... The fleece is not divine in our sense, not definitely either for blessing or for cursing; it is taboo, it is 'medicine,' it is magical." (p. 281, quoting Jane Harrison)

**Babylonian parallel**: "Fleece of the Great Bull" (*sugugallu*) was deified, identified with Anu himself—"this clarifies why the Golden Fleece plays the rôle of the Babylonian Tablets of Destinies in the Argonaut myth."

metadata.section: 3. Jason and the Golden Fleece as Healing Implement (pp. 280–282)
metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part C: Jason and the Bird-Heroes of Aia

content:
**Aietes** (*Aiêtês*) = "eagle" (from *aêtos*)

**Aia**: Never had real geographical existence—a "fantastic country at the edge of the world." V. Bérard recognized:
- **Circe** (*Kirkê*) = feminine of *kirkos* "hawk"
- **Aiaie** = W-S *'Ay-'ayyâ* "island of the Hawk" (or *Aia* + Greek feminine ending *-ie*)

**Sun-god connection**: The iconographic idea of personifying the sun by a hawk penetrated from Egypt throughout the Near East. The sun-disc with hawk's wings was adopted by Hurrians, Hittites, Assyrians. West Semites were influenced by consonance of their word for hawk (*'ayyā*) with Babylonian goddess Aia, spouse of sun-god Šamaš. > "The Sun-god was considered the ruler and patron of the inhabitants of Hades... at night, when all gods, identified with stars and planets, are in the sky, the Sun travels his path underground from West to East." (p. 287)

metadata.section: 4. Aietes, Circe, and the Land of Aia (pp. 282–286)
metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part C: Jason and the Bird-Heroes of Aia

content:
**Central thesis**: The Argonaut plot is "entirely borrowed from the Babylonian one of the theft of the Tablets of Destinies by the bird-god Zû."

| Babylonian Zû Myth | Greek Argonaut Myth |
|-------------------|---------------------|
| Zû steals Tablets of Destinies | Aietes holds Golden Fleece |
| Tablets = symbol of divine kingship | Fleece = symbol of royal power (cf. Atreus/Thyestes) |
| Zû = "doer of evil, who raises the head of evil" | Aietes = *oloophrōn* "of baneful mind" |
| Zû's wife seduced, Zû intoxicated | Dragon intoxicated by Medea's soporific |
| Tablets retrieved after Zû vanquished | Fleece retrieved after Jason's trials |

**Ugaritic parallel**: Anath boasts of crushing the "writhing serpent" and "powerful one of seven heads" (= Leviathan), then "I fought and I inherited gold"—the dragon-guarding-gold motif. > "Jason, before he became in the epic the personification of the ideal of ancient Greek knights-errant, a kind of chairman of the Hellenic Round Table, had first of all been a healer-hero, a magic expeller of evil." (p. 282)

metadata.section: 5. The Argonauts and the Myth of Zû (pp. 286–293)
metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part C: Jason and the Bird-Heroes of Aia

content:
Astour systematically analyzes every name in Aietes' family:

**Aietes**: Either from W-S *'ayit* "bird of prey" (Hebrew), or the name confirms the mythological borrowing from Zû (*ZU* = Akkadian *idû* "to know")—matching wife **Idyia** "the one who knows."

**Chalciope** ("hawk-faced"): From *chalkis*, a word from the "language of gods" (= Semitic)—probably from Akkadian *halâqu* "to perish/destroy" or Hebrew *hălaq* "smooth, hairless" (bald head of vultures). **Cytissoros**: *-issôros* = Ugaritic *'ṣr*, Akkadian *iṣṣuru* "bird"—determinative placed after the name as in cuneiform. **Absyrtos**: *A-bsyr-tos* = prothetic *a-* + *bașur* (passive participle of *bṣr* "to cut, tear to pieces") + Greek suffix *-tos* = "the dismembered one"—matching his fate of being cut to pieces by Medea. **Medea**: From W-S root *d'y* "to fly" (Hebrew *dā'â*, Ugaritic *diy* // *nšrm* "eagles"). Participle feminine Piel: *madīyat* > *Mēdeia* = "the flying one"—confirmed by her flying chariot driven by dragons.

metadata.section: 6. Semitisms in the Bird-Family of Aietes (pp. 294–298)
metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part C: Jason and the Bird-Heroes of Aia

content:
The flying chariot of Medea (also Phaëthon, Idas, Triptolemos) is not Greek invention but W-S:

**II Kings 2:11** (Elijah's ascension): "Behold, a chariot of fire and horses of fire separated the two of them. And Elijah went up by whirlwind into heaven."

> "It is more than probable that the Greeks of the Mycenaean Age, having borrowed the personages of their myths about healer gods and heroes from the East, have also simultaneously borrowed the motif of a flying chariot, too." (p. 298)

---

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part C: Jason and the Bird-Heroes of Aia

content:
> "The book of Ruth tells—in a fully euhemerized form—the Hebrew version of the Eleusis myth. A more thoroughly comparative survey must be left for another opportunity. The rôle of Eleusis is played there by Bethlehem, the 'House of bread.'" (p. 279)

> "So the antagonist of Jason the 'healer,' the one from whom the Golden Fleece which he had illegally appropriated had to be extorted, corresponds both in name and mythological function to the Babylonian bird-god Zû." (p. 294)

> "The name of Mermeros has a purely Greek explanation: *mermeros* in epic poetry means 'causing anxiety, heavy, difficult, terrible'... But, nevertheless, the association of Mermeros with Ilos in the formula 'Ilos son of Mermeros' betrays the Oriental origin of both names." (p. 299)

> "Precisely because the Etruscans, migrants from Asia Minor, worshipped a hawk-goddess, several localities, including Mount Circaeum, received names connected with her; and precisely because of that the Greeks from neighboring Cumae... located the fabulous island of Homeric Circe there." (p. 285)

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part D: Cheiron and Asclepios

content: This section culminates Astour's analysis of Greek healer-heroes by tracing Cheiron (the centaur who taught medicine to Achilles and Asclepios) to the Sumerian scorpion-god Pabilsag, and by demonstrating that Asclepios—Greece's supreme healer-god—has Mesopotamian and Canaanite origins revealed through his symbols (serpent-staff, dog), his mythology (exposed child, death by thunderbolt, resurrection), and his very name (derived from Ugaritic priestly terminology for ritual prostration). The section concludes with a comprehensive summary of the entire chapter's thesis on healer-heroes. **Why this matters for Kothar**: This section completes the chain connecting Greek healing mythology to Mesopotamian origins via West Semitic intermediaries, demonstrating that even the most revered Greek medical god—Asclepios—derives from Near Eastern prototypes. ---

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part D: Cheiron and Asclepios

content:
**Comparative astrology**: The Greeks identified Cheiron with Sagittarius, which they borrowed (like most astral notions) from Babylonians. The Babylonians represented Sagittarius as a scorpion-man with a bow, named after the god **Pabilsag**. **Pabilsag** (Sum. *dPa-bil-sag*):
- Husband of healing-goddesses (Ninkarrak/Nin-isinna)
- Located next to Scorpio (constellation of healing goddess Išhara) and Hydra (Ningišzida)
- "Explains why Cheiron-Sagittarius was considered the teacher of the ophic healer-god Asclepios"

**Ugaritic evidence**: Pbl-mlk in the *Krt* epic = Pabilsag. Virolleaud's identification: "Pbl is the Sumerian Pabil-sag 'Pabil (is) the chief.'"

> "Pbl-mlk, king of Udm, figures in the epic of King Krt, and it was his beautiful elder daughter Mšt-Hry whom Krt married." (p. 302)

**Mšt-Hry** = "fiery serpent" (*Mušt-Harayyā*) = constellation Hydra—daughter of Pabilsag/Sagittarius.

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part D: Cheiron and Asclepios

content:
Greek etymology *cheir* "hand" (surgeon) is contradicted by Attic spelling *Chirôn* (never *chir* for "hand"). Astour proposes Ugaritic personal name **Hyyn** as source:

**Two etymological possibilities**:

1. From *ḥyr* "to choose" (Akkadian *ḫâru*) → *ḫâwiru/ḫâ'iru* "husband"
   - Pabilsag was husband of Ninkarrak; their *hierogamy* was a popular feast at Isin
   - Scorpions symbolized mating; Išḥara was patroness of marriage consummation
   - Cheiron advised Peleus on seizing Thetis; their wedding was celebrated at his cave

2. From Arabic *ḫair* "good, excellent, beneficent, benevolent"
   - "An excellent name for a god of health, fertility, abundance, and help to humans"
   - Attested in Aramaic personal names: *Ḥyr, Ḥyr', Ḥyrw, Ḥyrn*

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part D: Cheiron and Asclepios

content:
**Serpent-staff emblem**:
- "This very emblem—a bronze serpent on a staff—was worshipped in the temple of Jerusalem until about 700; its creation was ascribed to the great thaumaturge and healer, the ophic hero Moses" (II Kings 18:4; Num. 21:8)
- Phoenician coins show Ešmun with serpent-staff
- Šed-râphe' at Palmyra depicted with serpent coiled around spear
- "The way by which the old Sumerian emblem penetrated into Greece is clear"

**Dog emblem**:
- Goddess Gula, "the great physician," had the dog as her emblem
- Depicted on Cassite-period *kudurrus* like Asclepios at Epidauros: sitting on throne with dog at feet
- Clay figurines of magic dogs ("he who bites his adversaries") were Babylonian talismans against disease

**Birth mythology parallels**:
- Exposed child nursed by goat = Sumerian Ningirsu
- Nursed by turtle-dove = Semiramis legend from Ascalon
- Found in chest = Sargon I, Moses, Adonis
- Lightning flashing from child = divine origin marker

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part D: Cheiron and Asclepios

content:
**Coronis** (Asclepios's mother):
- Common etymology: *korônê* "crow"
- Astour's alternative: *korônis* = "cow with concave and crescent-shaped horns" (Hesychius)
- = W-S *'Aštart Qarnayim* "two-horned Astarte"
- Alternative name **Aigla** = possibly W-S *'eglā* "heifer"
- Matches Ugaritic myth of cow-goddess giving birth to *Rpu-Bʿl* "lord-healer"

**Phlegyas** (Coronis's father):
- *phlegyas* = "eagle" (Hesiod *Scutum Herc.* 134)
- Also from *phlego* "to burn, flame" = Canaanite god **Rešeph** (*rešeph* "flame, lightning, fever")
- Rešeph corresponded to Sumero-Akkadian Nergal (pestilence, underworld, war)
- Son of Ares—who is also similar to Rešeph/Nergal

**Double genealogy of Asclepios**:
- Variant 1: Son of Apollo (Greek identification of Rešeph)
- Variant 2: Great-grandson of Ares (another Rešeph identification)
- In Orchomenos: directly son of Ares, under name **Ascalaphos**

> "The two variants are reduced to one: there is no essential difference, but only onomastic hesitation in translating the original Rešeph into Greek." (p. 312)

metadata.section: 4. Coronis, Phlegyas, and the Double Genealogy (pp. 309–313)
metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part D: Cheiron and Asclepios

content:
**Ascalaphos** (Nether World deity):
- Son of Acheron (river of Hades)—*Acherôn* < W-S *'aḥărôn* "western" (Hades was in Far West)
- Mother: Gorgyrê ("underground") or Orphnê ("darkness")
- Denounced Persephone for eating pomegranate seed
- Transformed into *askalaphos* (short-eared owl)

**Key correspondence**:
- Acheron = Hubur (Sumerian river of Hades)
- Ninlil's son by the underworld river-god = **Ninazu** "Lord Physician"
- "Ascalaphos, the son of Hades-river Acheron, thus fully corresponds to Ninazu"

> "This striking correspondence finally establishes beyond any doubt the identity Asclepios = Ascalaphos = Ninazu." (p. 316)

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part D: Cheiron and Asclepios

content:
**Problem**: "The name of Asclepios absolutely does not surrender to even the remotest Greek etymology."

**Solution**: From Akkadian priestly terminology:
- *labānu appi* = "to fall with the face down" (ritual prostration)
- Goes back to Sumerian *KA.SU.GAL*
- Ugaritic verb *ql/qll* "to fall," Š-stem *šql* "to cause to fall"
- 1st person imperfect: ***ašql-ap** = "I prostrate myself" (literally: "I cause my face to fall down")

**Corroboration**: Personal name from Alalah: *A-aš-qa-li-ia*—hypocoristic constructed with 1st person imperfect of *šql*. > "Our restoration presents a full coincidence with Askalaphos, and, consequently, with Asklépios... It harmonizes with the symbol of Asclepios, with the Mesopotamo-Syrian origin of all details of his image, myth, pedigree, symbols." (p. 318)

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part D: Cheiron and Asclepios

content:
**Machaon** (Asclepios's son, surgeon in *Iliad*):
- Common etymology: from *machomai* "to fight" (but this means "fight," not "cut")
- Astour's proposal: W-S *mḥwy* "reviver" (Piel participle of *ḥwy* "to live") + suffix *-n*
- = **Maḥawwôn* → Mycenaean *Ma-ka-wo* → *Macha(w)ôn*
- Matches ability ascribed to Asclepios and Oriental healer-gods to revive the dead

---

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part D: Cheiron and Asclepios

content:
> "We found that some of the characters examined ultimately derived from different avatars of the Sumerian chthonic serpent-god (also worshipped as a wooden pole), some—from another favorite symbol of Sumerian healer-gods: owls, eagles, and other predatory birds, and one, the Centaur Cheiron, from the Sumerian scorpion-man, the god Pabilsag." (p. 320)

> "Fear of disease and death belongs among the strongest impulses of human nature, and it is natural, when seeking help and comfort, to turn towards countries with an immemorially ancient civilization and an age-old reputation of possessing great and mysterious wisdom." (p. 320)

> "Long before the 'Chaldean'—the magician and astrologist—was received with honor in Roman society, Sumero-Akkadian magic medicine, half-assimilated and refashioned by the Phoenicians and North Syrians, made its first invasion on the continent of Europe." (p. 321)

> "We were always able to establish that the link between Babylonia and Greece had been Canaan (in the widest sense of this term). Sometimes, no precise epigraphic evidence was extant on Canaanite ground—but the W-S mediation manifested itself in proper names." (p. 321)
