metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter IV: Evidence of Archaeology and Epigraphy

content:
This concluding chapter marshals the archaeological, epigraphic, and documentary evidence for West Semitic penetration into the Aegean during the Bronze Age. Astour systematically dismantles Beloch's 1894 argument that archaeology contradicts Phoenician presence in Greece, presenting material proofs: Schaeffer's "Torque-Bearers" who brought bronze metallurgy from Syria to Europe via the Aegean, Mari texts mentioning Kaptara (Crete), Syrian architectural influence on Minoan palaces (Woolley), Cyrus Gordon's decipherment of Linear A as West Semitic and Eteocretan inscriptions as "Phoenician," documentary evidence of massive Ugaritic ship-building capacity, the Cape Gelidonya shipwreck, and the remarkable testimony of circumcision among the Achaeans in Merneptah's inscription. The chapter concludes that Mycenaean civilization was "essentially a peripheral culture of the Ancient East, its westernmost extension."

**Why this matters for Kothar**: This chapter provides the physical and documentary proof for the cultural transmission argued in Chapters I–III, establishing that Semitic presence in the Aegean was not merely mythological but archaeologically and epigraphically attested. ---

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter IV: Evidence of Archaeology and Epigraphy

content:
Astour begins by confronting Julius Beloch's influential 1894 article *Die Phoeniker am aegaeischen Meer*, which "had a baneful influence out of proportion to its modest size."

**Beloch's claims**:
- Phoenicians never visited the Aegean before the VIIIth century
- Their ships were too small for such voyages
- Semitic words could only have entered Greek via land-route through Asia Minor
- "The last word belongs here, as everywhere in prehistoric questions, to the monuments"

**Astour's response**: "Now, in our own time, Beloch's argumentation makes an almost ridiculous impression. What did he know about ancient navigation and the minimum size of a ship able to sustain a voyage from Syria to Crete?"

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter IV: Evidence of Archaeology and Epigraphy

content:
Claude F.-A. Schaeffer discovered at Ras Shamra bronze weapons and ornaments characteristic of Central European Early Bronze, which he traced to a specific population group:

**The "Torque-Bearer" assemblage** (Middle Ugarit I, 2100–1900):
- Triangular daggers with hilts finished in crescents
- Spears with sockets
- Flat axes with blades pierced by "windows"
- Massive bronze neck rings (*torques*)
- Toggle-pins and wire spirals

**Distribution**: Found identically at Ugarit, Byblos, Qaṭna, Megiddo, Sidon, Gezer—and in Central Europe (Hungary, Bohemia) from about 1800–1700. **The sea-route**: "According to the investigations, the Torque-Bearers did not take the land route—the 'torque' is lacking on this route [i.e., in West Anatolia and the Balkans]. This compels us to admit that the Torque-Bearers of Syria, the prospectors and artisans of metal, took the sea." (Schaeffer)

> "The Torque-Bearers were originally no Semites, but they rapidly became Semitized after their establishment in Syria. And, certainly, without the commercial genius of the Proto-Phoenicians, without their experience of the seas, they would not have been able to traverse the Mediterranean." (Schaeffer, quoted p. 328)

metadata.section: 2. Schaeffer's Torque-Bearers: Syrian Bronze Metallurgy to Europe (pp. 326–330)
metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter IV: Evidence of Archaeology and Epigraphy

content:
**Mari texts** (18th century): Mention **Kap-ta-ra** (Kaphtor/Crete), confirming mutual relations between Crete and Mesopotamia via North Syrian coastal cities. **Akkadian votive inscription from Cythera** (18th century): Corroborates archaeological data of Syro-Aegean contact. **Woolley on Alalah**: After excavating the palace of King Yarim-Lim (Level VII), Woolley traced "unmistakable connections with Crete":
- Construction methods identical to Knossos
- Frescoes "identical in colouring, technique, and style"

> "There can be no doubt but that Crete owes the best of its architecture, and its frescoes, to the Asiatic mainland. And we can say more than this... These professional techniques require direct contacts, and we are bound to believe that trained experts, members of the Architects' and Painters' Guilds, were invited to travel overseas from Asia." (Woolley, quoted p. 333)

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter IV: Evidence of Archaeology and Epigraphy

content:
Astour summarizes Cyrus H. Gordon's decipherment findings:

**Linguistic milieu of Linear A**: "Exactly the same as in Ugarit, where a mixed West-Semitic (W-S) and Hurrian Semitized population lived in a state of perfect symbiosis."

**Onomastic evidence**: "While names of Syrian origin in the Mycenaean (Linear B) texts form only a minority in a predominantly Greek milieu, the Minoan (Linear A) onomastica known so far is practically all Syrian."

**Implication**: "This betrays the existence of a solid and compact Semitic population in the eastern and central parts of Crete. It was by far more important than mere commercial foreign enclaves in harbor cities."

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter IV: Evidence of Archaeology and Epigraphy

content:
Gordon's 1962 discovery that Eteocretan ("true Cretan") inscriptions—written in Greek characters but in a non-Greek language—are West Semitic:

**Examples Gordon deciphered**:
- *me y mar krk o kl es y es* = *mē hū' mar krak 'ô kol 'îš we-'îš* "whosoever (whether) son of the city or any man at all"
- *mosel os phraiso* = *môšel 'oz Prays-* "the mighty ruler of Praisos"

**Historical significance**: The Eteocretans did not use the Phoenician alphabet, proving "they were not recent migrants from Phoenicia, but direct descendants of the W-S Minoans from mid-second millennium, who settled in Crete before the invention of the Phoenician alphabet."

> "When Beloch tendentiously tried to ridicule Phoenician presence in any spot of Greece, he ironically asked: if there were Phoenicians in Crete, why are they not listed among the five peoples of the island?... Now C. H. Gordon demonstrated that precisely one of those five peoples, the Eteocretans, were Phoenicians!" (p. 352)

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter IV: Evidence of Archaeology and Epigraphy

content:
**RS 20.212** (late 12th century): Hittite court requests one Ugaritic ship to transport 2,000 *kor* (≈6,000 hectoliters = 450 metric tons) of grain in one or two trips. > "Nougayrol, in his recently published report, tries to evaluate the capacity of that ship... 'The author of the letter admitted thus that the king of Ugarit disposed, or could dispose, of ships capable of carrying about 500 tons, or perhaps even more.' A vessel of 500 tons—even half as big—certainly could even cross the Atlantic, not only the short sea-distances on the route: Ugarit-Cyprus-Southwest Asia Minor-Crete." (p. 354)

**RS 16.238**: Documents a Ugaritic merchant returning with his ship from **Kapturi** (Crete). **RS 20.238**: Reveals that the Ugaritic fleet was stationed "in the Lycian country" defending against the Sea Peoples—"at the very entrance into the Aegean."

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter IV: Evidence of Archaeology and Epigraphy

content:
The University of Pennsylvania underwater archaeology expedition found an ancient wreck off Cape Gelidonya in Lycia (c. 1200):

- Ship heavily loaded with Cypriot copper ingots (stamped with Cypro-Minoan signs)
- Scarabs, oil-lamp, and skipper's seal are Syrian
- Wood analysis shows "the ship was probably made with Syrian wood"
- A smith traveled on board as "an ambulant metallurgic workshop"

> "We are in presence of a Syrian vessel which not only carried copper to the Aegean, but also served as an ambulant metallurgic workshop to supply with tools the harbors it visited." (p. 358)

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter IV: Evidence of Archaeology and Epigraphy

content:
Astour refutes the theory (Dussaud, Webster) that Greeks settled at Ugarit and transmitted Eastern culture back to Greece:

**Documentary evidence against Mycenaean presence**:
- "Among the ethnic names listed in Ugaritic administrative texts, we find Assyrians, Egyptians, Subaraeans, Mittanites, Hittites, Arzawians, Hurrians, Amorites, Canaanites, Nuhaššeans, Alašiots, and natives of several Phoenician and Palestinian cities"
- "No Achaeans, Aeolians, Ionians, Cretans, Caphtorians, Cnossians, Rhodians or any other ethnic or geographical names of the Greco-Aegean world can be found in Ugaritic texts"

**Conclusion**: "These indications are quite precise. They prove that no Mycenaean settlement existed at Ugarit in the XIVth and XIIIth centuries."

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter IV: Evidence of Archaeology and Epigraphy

content:
Merneptah's inscription (c. 1225) describes carnal trophies from the Sea Peoples:
- From Libyans: phalli cut off (they had *qrn't* "foreskin")
- From Sardana, Šak(a)ruša, Turuša, and **'Aqiyawaša**: hands cut off, "who had no *qrn't*"

**'Aqiyawaša** = Ahhiyawā = Achaeans—they were circumcised. > "Only the settlement in Greece of an important group of population whose religious and ritual principles would be adopted by large masses of the people, could have introduced the general spread of circumcision among the Achaeans... Circumcision among the Achaeans, attested by the eye-witness Merneptah, shows most convincingly how strongly W-S ritual customs became rooted among them." (p. 368)

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter IV: Evidence of Archaeology and Epigraphy

content:
> "Not only was Phoenician spoken in several parts of Mycenaean Greece, but the entire Mycenaean civilization was essentially a peripheral culture of the Ancient East, its westernmost extension." (p. 370)

**Geopolitical parallel**: "Greece and Syria-Palestine were very similar in their geographical and natural conditions. Both were broken, geographically dismembered territories without a central organizing axis."

**The two swings of the Mediterranean pendulum**:
> "Long before Hellenism imposed itself over the ancient civilizations of the East, Semitism had exercised no less an impact upon the young civilization of Greece. Hellenism became the epilogue of the Oriental civilizations, but Semitism was the prologue of Greek civilization." (p. 374)

---

metadata.section: 10. Concluding Thesis: Greece as Peripheral Eastern Culture (pp. 369–374)
metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter IV: Evidence of Archaeology and Epigraphy

content:
> "The famous archaeologist and historian of civilization V. Gordon Childe wrote about the transition from Neolithic to Bronze in Crete: 'The neolithic phase was ended by a quickening impulse from the Nile, which permeated the rude island culture and transformed it... At the same time even more explicitly Asiatic traits can be detected among the innovations.'" (p. 325)

> "In 1939, some scholars assumed that the Ugaritic king Nqmd was the Greek Nikomédés... But it was soon clarified that Nqmd (Niqmadu) was a pure W-S name signifying 'Hadd is the avenger.'" (p. 361)

> "Kšr is a good W-S name: 'the appropriate, the useful, the one who adjusts things'—a most fitting name for the artisan and artist of the divine family. If Kaphtor was assigned to him as his domain, this was because Crete, before it was conquered by the Greeks, was considered a part of the Canaanite world." (p. 364)

> "It would be one-sided to consider the Greek polis, evolved from the conditions of the Homeric age, as something exclusively Greek, and to oppose it to the Mycenaean order, which is characterized as Asiatic... Canaanite cities, as early as the Amarna Age, were far from being despotic bureaucratic monarchies." (p. 373)

metadata.title: Some New Divine Names from Ugarit (1966)

content:
This article analyzes newly discovered Ugaritic texts from the 24th excavation campaign at Ras Shamra (1961), focusing on divine names appearing for the first time in Ugaritic literature. Astour identifies key deities including: the Mare-goddess *Phlt* (parallel to Phigalian "Black Demeter"); *Ttt/Kmt* (earliest attestation of Chemosh); *Ngh w Srr* (prototype of Isaiah's Lucifer/Morning Star); *Dqt* (goat-goddess paralleling Cretan Dikte); *Trt* ("wine" deity = possible Bacchus prototype); and *Itm* (guilt-offering personified = earliest form of Phoenician *Ešmûn*). The article demonstrates extensive Greco-Semitic religious parallels and contributes to understanding the "Aegean Oriental religious *koinē*."

**Why this matters for Kothar**: This article provides direct textual evidence from Ugarit for the Semitic origins of Greek divine figures, including the prototype of Lucifer, the etymology of Bacchic *thyrsoi*, and the mare-goddess parallel to Black Demeter—all supporting the broader Hellenosemitic thesis. ---

metadata.title: Some New Divine Names from Ugarit (1966)

content:
**Text introduction**: "*um. phl. phlt. bt. 'n. bt. abn. bt šmm w thm... qrit. l špš. umh*" = "the mother of Phl, Phlt, daughter of the Spring, daughter of the Stone, daughter of the Sky and of the Ocean, calls to Špš her mother"

**Phigalian parallel**: Pausanias (VIII:42:1-13) describes an archaic wooden image (xoanon) of "Dēmētēr Melaina" (Black Demeter) or "Dēō Hippolechos" (Deo who bore a horse) in southwestern Arcadia:
- "The Phigalian xoanon had the body of a woman with the head and mane of a horse"
- "There grew out of her head images of serpents and other beasts"
- Located near a spring of cold water (cf. *bt 'n* "daughter of the Spring")
- Sitting on a rock (cf. *bt abn* "daughter of the Stone")
- Having dolphin and dove, symbols of sea and sky (cf. *bt šmm w thm* "daughter of the Sky and Ocean")

> "RS 24.244, unearthed thirty years after V. Bérard's death, offers an exact parallel to all details given by Pausanias. We may safely ascribe the introduction of this iconographic entity into southwestern Arcadia to the Mycenaean Age."

metadata.section: 1. The Mare-Goddess Phlt and Black Demeter (RS 24.244)
metadata.title: Some New Divine Names from Ugarit (1966)

content:
**The binomial**: *Tttw Kmt* (RS 24.244:36) = *'ttw Kmt* (RS 24.271:5)

**Kmt identification**: "The second component of the binomial... is identical with the later chief god of the Moabites, Heb. *Kěmôš*, LXX *Chamôs*, Moabite inscriptional *Kmš*, Assyrian *Ka-a-mu-su*."

**Ttt etymology**: "*Ttt* (Heb. *tīt*, Akk. *tītu*) signifies 'clay' which, together with 'dust' and 'darkness,' was one of the attributes of the Babylonian Nether World."

**Alternate name 'tt**: Virolleaud explained as Heb. *'āyiṭ* "bird of prey" (eagle or vulture)—"an image from the Babylonian 'Land without return,' the residents of which are described as winged and feathered bird-like creatures."

**Tityos connection**: "The doublet *Ttt='tt* leads us to a Greek mythological character, Tityos, son of Earth, who in the Nekyia... is depicted as being punished in the Hades by having his liver eternally torn by two vultures."

metadata.title: Some New Divine Names from Ugarit (1966)

content:
**First attestation**: "*ars w šmm*" (RS 24.643:obv. 5)—"This is the first time that Earth and Heaven appear in a Ugaritic text as a divine entity."

**Sequence significance**: "The sequence—Earth standing before Heaven—is the opposite of the Sumerian and Akkadian usage (*an.ki*, *šamû w erṣetu*)... but is the same as in the creation story of J (Gen. 2:4b) which has preserved the Canaanite pattern."

**Philo parallel**: "According to Philo of Byblos, *Ilos* with his brothers and sisters were born of a union of *Uranos* and *Gē*."

content:

metadata.title: Some New Divine Names from Ugarit (1966)

content:
"Seven hypostases of the next highest ranking god: *Adad bursa Hazi*, *Adad 1*, *Adad 2*, and so on up to *Adad 6* in the Akkadian version; [*B'l Spn*], then *B'l-m* repeated six times, in the Ugaritic."

**Parallel**: "An Assyrian text from Assur also lists seven Adads"—differentiated by their renowned shrines.

metadata.title: Some New Divine Names from Ugarit (1966)

content:
**Etymology**:
- *NGH* "to shine" (Ugaritic, Syriac, Ethiopic; Hebrew *nôgah* = "brightness," Mishnaic = Venus)
- *SRR* "to rebel" (Hebrew, Akkadian D-form *sarāru*)

**Isaiah parallel**: "We have here the earliest occurrence of the rebellious hero of the magnificent mythological poem, Isaiah 14:12-15: *Hēlel ben-Šahar*, 'Morning Star... son of Dawn,' who tried 'to ascend to heaven,' to 'sit on the Mount of Assembly in the far North' and to make himself 'like the Most High (*'Elyôn*),' but was brought down to Sheol."

> "One feels a certain emotion in discovering its prototype in a Ugaritic tablet written some six or eight hundred years before the dirge in Isaiah 14 and some three thousand years before Milton's *Paradise Lost*."

metadata.title: Some New Divine Names from Ugarit (1966)

content:
**Identification**: "Personifications of 'righteousness' and 'justice,' Babylonian *Kettu* and *Mēsaru* (personified as sons of *Šamaš*, the god of justice), Philo's sixth pair of primeval brothers, *Misôr* and *Sydyk*."

**First attestation**: "The nouns *sdq* and *mšr* have been known in Ugaritic literary texts... but this is the first time that they are found as a divine pair."

metadata.title: Some New Divine Names from Ugarit (1966)

content:
**The divine pair**: *Šgr w Itm* (RS 24.643:rev. 9)

**Itm etymology**: "*Itm* is the same word as the Ugaritic noun *iṭm* = Arab. *'iṭm* = Heb. *'āšām*, i.e., 'guilt,' 'transgression,' and 'guilt offering.'"

**Ešmûn connection** (quoting Astour's 1951/52 work):
> "Disease was considered the result of some fault or guilt (*'āšām*) that had first to be identified and then atoned... Therefore the healer-god, too, received the name *'Āšām*... Amos 8:14 mentions this deity as *'Āšēmāt* of Samaria; II Kings 17:30 knows him, in the Aramaic form *'Ašima'*, as a god of the men of Hamath. The Phoenician healer-god *'Ešmûn* bears the same name with the suffix *-ûn*."

**Confirmation**: "We have here the earliest recorded mention of the god that later, in the first millennium B.C., was worshipped all over the West Semitic world under names derived from the root *'TM*."

metadata.title: Some New Divine Names from Ugarit (1966)

content:
**Etymology**: "*Dqt*, literally 'a female head of small cattle for sacrifices'... pronounced... *daqqatu* or *diqqatu*."

**Cretan parallel**: "Now *Di-ka-tu* was the Linear A name of Cretan Mt. *Dikte* (*Di-ka-ta* in Linear B) which Hesiod (Theog. 481) called *Aigaion oros*, 'Goat's Mountain.'"

**Cross-reference**: "Among the nine Cretan and Peloponnesian toponyms in a recently published list of Amenophis III, the name *Di-qa-* figures with the determinative 'high.' I recognized in it the Semitic spelling *Dqt*."

metadata.title: Some New Divine Names from Ugarit (1966)

content:
**Etymology**: "*Trt*, literally 'grape-juice' (synonym of 'wine'), Heb. *tirōš*, Phoen. (Karatepe) *trš*, Ugar. *trt*."

**Albright's hypothesis confirmed**: "'This hitherto unknown divinity may perhaps have been a kind of Bacchus from whose name the Israelites got their poetic word *tirōš* for "wine."' This hypothesis has now been completely confirmed by the occurrence of the deity *Trt* in two Ugaritic lists of gods."

**Thyrsoi connection**: "The proposed derivation of the term *thyrsoi*, the sacral wands carried at the festivals of Dionysos, from this West Semitic word for 'wine,' has also been strengthened by the disclosure that *trt* had a religious connotation in the West Semitic world."

metadata.title: Some New Divine Names from Ugarit (1966)

content:
**The epithet**: "*Ušhr hlmt*"—the healer-goddess Išhara with epithet *hlmt* = Akkadian *hulmittu*, "a kind of snake."

**Significance**: "The connection of fertility- and healer-gods with snakes is extremely old and widespread... the serpent or dragon was indeed an emblem of *Išhara*... but this is so far the only piece of evidence on the existence of serpent-cult in Ugarit."

metadata.title: The Decipherment of Minoan and Eteocretan (1975)

content: This technical article presents Gordon's mature methodology for deciphering Minoan and Eteocretan inscriptions. He outlines six methods of decipherment, works through the Dreros bilinguals, demonstrates the Semitic character of Eteocretan through variant phrases, and connects Minoan Linear A to Eteocretan through shared vocabulary (*ku-ro* "all/total", *u* "and"). The Psychro stone inscription is fully translated as a Northwest Semitic dedication formula. **Why this matters for Kothar**: This is Gordon's most methodologically rigorous article, establishing the six-method framework for Minoan-Eteocretan decipherment and providing detailed bilingual readings that anchor the Northwest Semitic identification. ---

metadata.title: The Decipherment of Minoan and Eteocretan (1975)

content:
Gordon explicitly outlines six methods applicable to Minoan and Eteocretan:

| Method | Description |
|--------|-------------|
| (i) **Bilingual method** | Greek-Eteocretan bilinguals provide known-to-unknown equations |
| (ii) **Phrase translation** | Whole Eteocretan phrases tested for meaning and internal consistency |
| (iii) **Inner variants** | Synonyms and alternative idioms within Eteocretan texts confirm readings |
| (iv) **Parallel unilinguals** | Greek and Eteocretan unilinguals from same sites provide equivalences |
| (v) **Contextual method** | All readings must fit context |
| (vi) **Collateral evidence** | Interpretation within known East Mediterranean epigraphical usage |
| (vii) **Pictograms/determinatives** | For Minoan, meaning fixed through accompanying pictographs |

**Key quote**: "The material dictates the methods. There is no one prefabricated methodology for deciphering all scripts and languages."

metadata.title: The Decipherment of Minoan and Eteocretan (1975)

content:
**First Dreros Bilingual:**
- Eteocretan opens with *]φμαF* = Greek *EΦ AΔE* "they decreed"
- Eteocretan ends with *λμο* = Greek *[τα]ματρίτα[τα]ο* "for his mother"
- Analysis: *λμο* = Hebrew *l-immō* "for his mother"

**Second Dreros Bilingual:**
- Demonstrates additional Greco-Eteocretan correspondences
- Confirms Northwest Semitic character

**Key quote**: "The Greek version tells us to equate λμο with Hebrew לִאמוֹ *l'immô* 'for his mother'."

metadata.title: The Decipherment of Minoan and Eteocretan (1975)

content:
Gordon demonstrates that Eteocretan contains standardized adjuration formulas found throughout East Mediterranean epigraphy. **Eteocretan phrase**: *ετ·μενυμαρκρκοκλες·νες...*
- = Hebrew *...מי הוא מר כרכו כל איש ואיש* "whosoever he be, citizen of his fortress (or) any (other) man and man of..."

**Variant phrasing**: *vas φονκλες* "the people of his city and every (other) man"

**Parallel construction in known languages:**
- **Phoenician (Tabnit)**: *m y't k l'd m's...* "whosoever thou art, any man who..."
- **Phoenician (Eshmunazar)**: *qnmy't kl mmikt wkl'd m* "my oath is with every ruler and every (other) man"
- **Phoenician (Azitawadd)**: *w'm mlk bmlkm wrzn brznm'm'd m's' 'd m šm* "and if any king among kings..."

**Key insight**: The two Eteocretan variants provide synonymous pairs—*mar krk* "lord of fortress" and *vas ir* "people of city"—that only make sense in Northwest Semitic.

metadata.title: The Decipherment of Minoan and Eteocretan (1975)

content:
Two key words bridge Minoan (Bronze Age) and Eteocretan (Early Iron Age):

**1. *ku-ro* / *kull-* "all, total"**
- Introduces numerical totals in Hagia Triada tablets
- = Semitic *kull-* "all"
- Biblical parallel: 2 Sam. 23:39 sums up David's heroes with *kol* "total: 37"

**2. *u* "and"**
- Connects parallel utterances in Minoan dedications
- Example: *ya-ta-no-x u ya-[...]* "he donated it and set [it up as votive offering]"
- = Phoenician *ytn wytn'* "he donated and set up as votive offering"

**Key quote**: "We have shown that two common words (of types not likely to be borrowings) are shared by Minoan and Eteocretan: *kull-* 'all', *u* 'and'."

metadata.title: The Decipherment of Minoan and Eteocretan (1975)

content:
The complete translation of the Psychro stone inscription from the Dictaean Cave:

**Text**: *επιθίζηθανθη* + syllabic *i-pi-ti*

**Translation**: "I, E. the son of S., have donated this engraved stone."

**Analysis:**
- *epithi* = *e-pth* "the engraved stone" (with definite article *e-*)
- = Phoenician *pth* "engraved stone" (cf. YHWMLK inscription: *pthy z* "this engraved stone of mine")
- *ζηθανθη* = *ytnt-* "I have donated" (cf. Punic *ytnty*)
- The first word repeated in Minoan syllabary (*i-pi-ti*) proves scribe knew both scripts

**Addendum**: Robert Stieglitz solved the third line *ενετηπαρσιφαι* as "E. the son of S." where *par* = "son" (standard Aramaic, also Phoenician KLMW inscription and Hebrew Prov. 31:2).

metadata.title: The Decipherment of Minoan and Eteocretan (1975)

content:
**Wine (*ya-ne*):**
- Inscribed on Knossos pithos fragment
- = NW Semitic *yayn-* "wine"
- Michael Astour noted: Ugaritic place "Yan(a)" written *ya-na* or GESTIN-*na* (where GESTIN = wine)
- This gives an isogloss connecting Minoan and Ugaritic

**Wheat (*ku-ni-su*):**
- Four occurrences in Hagia Triada tablets, twice with wheat determinative
- = Akkadian *kunnishu* "emmer wheat"
- Position in tablets fixes meaning as commodity (not personal name)

content:
> "Like virtue, it should be practiced, but not necessarily talked about." (p. 148, on methodology)

— *Context*: Gordon's wry observation that method should be applied constantly but need not be discussed at every turn. > "Neither the scholars who oppose the Semitic identification of Minoan... nor those who are bringing welcome support to it should go on ignoring the existence of Eteocretan." (p. 152)

— *Context*: Gordon's frustration that scholars treat Minoan and Eteocretan as separate problems when they form a linguistic continuum. > "Blind denial is no more scientific than blind acceptance. What is needed is understanding the facts of the case; not disregard, polemics, denigration, nor the polarization of scholars into opposing camps." (p. 152)

— *Context*: Gordon's call for scholarly engagement with the actual evidence rather than ideological positioning. ---

content:
- **Type**: Monograph (Chapters I–VII)
- **Full Title**: *Evidence for the Minoan Language*
- **Author**: Cyrus H. Gordon
- **Publisher**: Ventnor Publishers, Ventnor, N.J. - **Date**: 10 February 1966
- **Pages**: 3–25 (this section)
- **Dedication**: To Minnie and Philip Sagoff
- **Acknowledgment**: Brandeis University research grant; Helen Sagoff Slosberg memorial gift

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 1: Bilinguals & Eteocretan

content: This opening section establishes the bilingual method as the foundation for Gordon's decipherment. Using Greek-Eteocypriote and Greek-Eteocretan bilinguals, Gordon demonstrates that the pre-Greek languages of Cyprus and Crete are Northwest Semitic dialects closely related to Phoenician. The bilinguals from Amathus and Dreros provide the "Rosetta Stones" that unlock the linguistic identity of the Minoan world. **Why this matters for Kothar**: These bilinguals establish the empirical foundation for the Minoan-Semitic thesis. The Dreros equations (*lmo* = "for his mother," *ihia* = "it will be") prove continuity from Bronze Age Minoan through Hellenistic Eteocretan. ---

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 1: Bilinguals & Eteocretan

content:
Gordon frames Minoan civilization within the East Mediterranean koiné of the second millennium BC:

> "A comparative study of Ugaritic, Greek and Hebrew literatures points to a single culture that permeated the East Mediterranean throughout the second millennium B.C." (§1)

The fall of Knossos (ca. 1400–1200 BC) dispersed the Minoans, explaining:
- The sudden appearance of Ugaritic literature after 1400 BC
- References to Caphtor (Crete) as home of **Kothar-wa-Khasis**
- The spread of hide-shaped ingots from Crete to Anatolia and Sardinia

> "That god (Kothar-wa-Khasis) has a pure Semitic name, indicating that Caphtor had been the artistic center of the linguistic, cultural and religious sphere to which Ugarit belonged." (§1)

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 1: Bilinguals & Eteocretan

content:
The Greco-Eteocypriote bilingual from Amathus (Cyprus), inscribed on black marble, provides the first key equations. **The Greek epitome**:
> Ἡ ΠΟΛΙΣ Ἡ ΑΜΑΘΟΥΣΙΟΝ ΑΡΙΣΤΩΝΑ ΑΡΙΣΤΩΝΑΚΤΟΣ ΕΥΠΑΤΡΙΔΗΝ
> "The city of the Amathusians (has honored) the noble Ariston (son) of Aristonax."

**Key Eteocypriote readings** (§7–17):

| Eteocypriote | Semitic | Meaning |
|--------------|---------|---------|
| *a-na ma-to-ri* | הַנָּה מְתוֹרֵי | "the city" (= ἡ πόλις) |
| *a-na* | הַנָּא (Syriac *hānā*) | "the, this" |
| *sa-na* | זֶנָה | "this" (m. sg. demonstrative) |
| *-o-se* | אז | "this" (enclitic) |
| *la* | ל | "for" |
| *a-lo* | עָלָיו | "over him" |
| *ka* | כ | "like, as" |

**Double demonstrative construction**: *sa-na a-ri-si-to-no-se* "this Ariston" parallels Aramaic idiom (§17).

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 1: Bilinguals & Eteocretan

content: Two bilinguals from Dreros, Crete, with Eteocretan text preceding Greek—indicating Eteocretan was the principal local language.

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 1: Bilinguals & Eteocretan

content:
**Eteocretan** (retrograde, with word dividers):
```
]ΙΡΜΑΦ . ΕΤ . ΙΣΑΑΒΡ ΕΤ ΚΟΜΝ
]Σ . ΜΕΝ . ΙΝΑΙ . ΙΣΑΑΤΡΙΑ . ΑΜΟ
```

**Greek** (boustrophedon):
```
]Σ ΤΟΝ ΤΥΡΟΝ Μ[ΥΝ]Α ΤΟ ΑΟΙ ΕΦΑΣ[Ε
ΤΑΙ] ΜΑΤΡΙ ΤΑΙ Α[ΥΤΟ]
```

**Critical equation** (§22):
> "The final word in the Eteocretan is ΑΜΟ corresponding to ]ΜΑΤΡΙ ΤΑΙ Α[. Since ΜΑΤΡΙ can only be the dative for 'mother,' the Eteocretan ΑΜΟ is the equivalent of Hebrew לְאִמּוֹ *l'immō* 'for his mother.'"

**Other equations from First Dreros** (§23–27):

| Eteocretan | Greek | Semitic | Meaning |
|------------|-------|---------|---------|
| ΕΤ ΚΟΜΝ | τὸν τυρόν | אֶת גֹּבֶן | "the cheese" (accusative) |
| ΕΤ | — | אֶת | sign of definite accusative |
| ΑΜΟ | μητρὶ | לְאִמּוֹ | "for his mother" |
| ΙΣΑΑ- | μύνα | אִשָּׁה | "woman" |
| ΑΒΡ | — | חָבֵר | "companion" |
| ΤΡΙΑ | — | רֵעַ | "friend" |

> "The First Dreros Bilingual provides Greek evidence that establishes the close Eteocretan correspondents of Hebrew/Phoenician ל 'to,' ו 'his,' אם 'mother' and the accusative indicator את. Even if we set aside the other Eteocretan readings, these four would fix the Dreros dialect as Northwest Semitic." (§27)

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 1: Bilinguals & Eteocretan

content:
**Eteocretan**: `]Σ . ΤΥΣΡ ΜΗΡ ΙΗΙΑ`

**Greek**: `ΟΜΟΝΤΑΙ ΔΑΙΠΕΡ ΕΝ ΟΡΚΙΟΙΣΙ . Α[ ] ΚΑΘΑΡΟΝ ΓΕΝΟΙΤΟ`

**Critical equation** (§30–31):
> "What is clear is that Eteocretan ΙΗΙΑ corresponds to Greek γένοιτο 'let there be.' The Semitic ΙΗΙΑ (in Hebrew יִהְיֶה *yihyeh*) by itself means 'he will be.'"

This establishes the Hebrew verb היה "to be" in the Dreros dialect—a crucial morphological confirmation.

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 1: Bilinguals & Eteocretan

content:
Four funerary inscriptions from Praisos, spanning ca. 600–300 BC. **Recurring element**: ΜΙΤ = Hebrew מֵת *mēt* "died" appears in all three texts where the first line survives. **Key readings from Praisos**:

| Eteocretan | Hebrew | Meaning |
|------------|--------|---------|
| ΜΙΤ | מֵת | "died" |
| Υ | ו | "and" (as in Punic) |
| ΣΦΑΑ | שֶׁבַע | "7" |
| ΣΑΡ | עֶשֶׂר | "10" |
| ΤΖΑΑ | תֵּשַׁע | "9" |
| ΣΑΝΟ | זֶנָה | "this" (m. sg.) |
| ΟΣ | אז | "this" (enclitic) |
| ΜΟΣΕΛ | מוֹשֵׁל | "ruler" |
| ΚΑΡΚ | כַּרְךְ | "town" |
| ΝΑΣ | נָשׁ | "people" |
| ΙΡ | עִיר | "city" |

**Double demonstrative** (§37): ΣΑΝΟ ΜΟΣΕΛ ΟΣ = זה מושל זה "this ruler"—same construction as Eteocypriote. **Formulaic phrase** (§33, 41): ΜΕ Υ ΜΑΡ ΚΡΚΟ ΚΑ ΕΣ Υ ΕΣ = מי הוא מר כרכו כל איש ואיש "whoever he be, lord of his town, every man and man"

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 1: Bilinguals & Eteocretan

content:
A unique **digraphic** text from the Dictaean Cave (ca. 300 BC) where the scribe rewrites ΕΤΙΘΙ in Minoan syllabary as *i-pi-ti*:

```
ΕΤΙΘΙ
Ζ ΗΘΑΝΘΗ
ΕΝΕΤΗ ΠΑΡΣΙΦΑΙ
i-pi-ti
```

**Key readings**:

| Eteocretan | Phoenician | Meaning |
|------------|------------|---------|
| ΕΤΙΘΙ / *i-pi-ti* | הַפֵּתַח | "the engraved monument" |
| Ε | ה | "the" (definite article) |
| Ζ | ז | "this" or "which" (relative) |
| ΗΘΑΝΘΗ | יְתַנְתִי | "I have given/set" |

> "Four key words are clear: Ε = ה 'the,' ΙΤΙΘΙ = Minoan *pi-te* = פתח 'engraved monument,' Ζ = Minoan *za* = ז 'this' or 'which,' and *ytn* 'to give, set' as in Minoan and Phoenician." (§49)

This text proves **continuity from Minoan to Eteocretan**—the same terminology for votive monuments persisted for over a millennium.

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 1: Bilinguals & Eteocretan

content:
Gordon argues the Greek alphabet with vowels was developed on Crete:

> "When the Cretans adopted the consonantal Phoenician alphabet, they added to it the means of expressing the five vowels to which they had so long been accustomed from their long use of the native syllabary." (§51)

**Key evidence**: Omicron corresponds to Phoenician ע (*'ayin*), which was pronounced *o* in Minoan words like *bol* (< *ba'l*) "Baal" and *nol* (< *na'l*) "sandal" (§53).

> "This monograph aims at providing qualified scholars with all the evidence they need for understanding the Northwest Semitic character of Minoan." (Foreword)

- **Publisher**: Ventnor Publishers, Ventnor, N.J. - **Date**: 10 February 1966
- **Pages**: 26–39 (this section)

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 2: Linear A Decipherment

content: This central section presents Gordon's methodology for deciphering Linear A through virtual bilinguals, contextual analysis, and comparison with the Eteocretan evidence. Building on Ventris's Linear B values (since most Linear A signs recur in Linear B), Gordon establishes that Minoan is Northwest Semitic through systematic vocabulary analysis. The section culminates in comprehensive word lists proving the Semitic character of Minoan. **Why this matters for Kothar**: This is the technical core—the actual decipherment work. The vocabulary tables (§113, §126) provide the linguistic evidence that Minoan Crete spoke a language ancestral to Phoenician. ---

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 2: Linear A Decipherment

content:
Gordon accepts Ventris's 1952 Linear B decipherment as the basis for pronouncing Linear A:

> "The decipherment of Mycenaean Linear B by Michael Ventris in 1952 was confirmed by a 'virtual bilingual' from Pylos in which various pots are drawn pictographically as well as defined syllabically in Mycenaean Greek... Since most of the Linear A signs recur in Linear B with the same phonetic values, Ventris's decipherment enables us to pronounce many names and words in the Minoan Linear A texts." (§114)

**Proof of sign continuity**: The same proper names appear in both scripts (e.g., *pa-i-to* "Phaistos"), implying identical phonetic values.

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 2: Linear A Decipherment

content:
Like the Pylos tablet that confirmed Linear B, Hagia Triada tablet HT 31 shows pictographs of pots with their Minoan names spelled syllabically. **Four of five legible pot names are Semitic** (§115):

| Minoan | Semitic | Meaning |
|--------|---------|---------|
| *qa-pa* | Hebrew כַּף *kap* | "pan, vessel" |
| *su-pu* | Hebrew/Ugaritic סַף *sap* | "jar" |
| *ka-ro-pa* | Akkadian *karpu* (cf. Ug. *krpn*) | "vase" |
| *su-pa-ra* | Hebrew/Ugaritic סֶפֶל *sefel* | "pot" |

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 2: Linear A Decipherment

content:
> "The WHEAT determinative following *ku-ni-su* tells us that the word means 'wheat.' In Akkadian *ku(n)nisu* means 'emmer wheat.' Its Aramaic cognate כֻּנָּתָא (a masculine noun from the Semitic root *\*knt*) is defined as 'spelt' wheat."

The parallel: Linear B *si-to* + WHEAT = σῖτος "wheat"

**Result**: Minoan *ku-ni-su* = Mycenaean *si-to* — a Greco-Semitic equation via the WHEAT determinative.

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 2: Linear A Decipherment

content:
Totals on Minoan tablets are labeled *ku-ro* = Semitic *kull-* (Hebrew כֹּל *kōl*) "all."

**Example** — HT 88 (§117):
```
ki-ro ku-pa-nu    1
ka-x              1
ku-pa-nu          1
pa-ya-re          1
sa-ma-ro          1
da-ta-re          1
—————————————————
ku-ro             6
```

**"Grandtotal"**: HT 122 uses *po-to-ku-ro* = בַּת כֹּל "daughter of all" = "grandtotal" (§118)

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 2: Linear A Decipherment

content: A magic bowl from Knossos (II,2) opens with *a-ka-nu* = Hebrew/Aramaic אַגָּן *'aggān* "bowl"—the same term used for magic bowls in Aramaic incantations.

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 2: Linear A Decipherment

content:
**The *ya-ta-no* formula** (§121):

Several stone cult objects begin with *ya-ta-no-* (var. *a-ta-no-*) = Phoenician יָתַן *yātan-* "he has given/donated."

A libation bowl (I,14) contains:
> *ya-ta-no-x u ya-[* ] = Phoenician יתן ויתנא *ytn wytn'* "he has given and set up as a votive offering"

Note: The conjunction "and" appears as *u* (as in Punic, Akkadian). **The *ta-nu-a-ti* formula** (§122):

A libation table from Knossos (I,8) contains:
> *ta-nu-a-ti ya-sa-sa-ra-ma-na* = "I have set up this votive offering"

The verb תנא *tn'* "to set up (as a votive offering)" is common in Phoenician dedications. **Wine on wine jars** (§123):

Pithoi from Knossos bear the word *ya-ne* flanked by word dividers = Hebrew יַיִן *yayin* "wine"—found on vessels with the WINE determinative.

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 2: Linear A Decipherment

content:
Gordon's key continuity proof:

> "An inscribed libation table from Palaikastro (I,4:b) refers to itself as *pi-te za* (with a word divider on each side) = Phoenician זה פתח 'this engraved monument.'"

**The chain**:
- Bronze Age Minoan: *pi-te* + *za*
- Hellenistic Eteocretan: ΕΙΤΙΘΙ + Ζ (Psychro text)
- Both = Phoenician פתח + ז

> "The Psychro text thus shows the continuity of the language and tradition since Minoan times." (§49, referenced in §124)

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 2: Linear A Decipherment

content:
Libation table I,3 from the Dictaean Cave contains:

> *ki-te-te-bi k[i]-re-[ya]-tu* = כי תיטב קריה "so that the city may thrive"

The word *ki-re-ya-tu* = קִרְיָה *qiryāh* "city" (Hebrew, Ugaritic *qryt*) is "virtually certain."

**Core vocabulary table**:

| *ki-re-ya-tu* | קרית | קִרְיָה | "city" |

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 2: Linear A Decipherment

content:
| Sign Series | Covers | Examples |
|-------------|--------|----------|
| p-signs | *b* and *p* | *su-pu* (*sp*), *te-te-pi* (*yṭb*) |
| t-signs | *t* and *ṭ* | *ya-ta-no* (*ytn*), *ma-ka-we-te* (*mqwṭ*) |
| d-signs | *d* and *ḏ* | *da-we-da* (דוד), *da-ku-na* (דגן) |
| k-signs | *k*, *g*, *q* | *ku-ro* (*kl*), *ku-pa-nu* (*gpn*), *ki-re-ya-tu* (*qryt*) |
| r-signs | *r* and *l* | *ki-re-ya-tu* (*qiryatu*), *ku-ro* (*kull*) |
| s-signs | *s*, *š*, *ṯ* | *su-pu* (*sp*), *ya-sa-sa-ra-mu* (*yšslm*), *ku-ni-su* (*knt*) |

**Length not indicated**: *a-ka-nu* = *'aggān*, *ku-ro* = *kull-*, *ya-mu* = *yammu*

**Diphthongs**: *ay* is omitted in *ya-ne* (pronounced *yayn-* = יין); *aw* written as *u* in *ka-u-do-ni*

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 2: Linear A Decipherment

content:
**The ʿayin > o shift** (§150):
> "The ʿ (cayin) at least in certain combinations, shifts to *o*. Thus *ʿa > o* in: *baʿl- > bōl-* (written *pu-ra*) 'Baal' and *naʿl- > nōl-* 'sandal.'"

This explains why the SANDALED FOOT sign has value *no* (from *nōl* < *naʿl*).

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 2: Linear A Decipherment

content:
| Feature | Minoan | Semitic Parallel |
|---------|--------|------------------|
| Nominative -u | *ku-ni-su*, *ki-re-ya-tu*, *a-du* | Triptotic noun system |
| Feminine -atu | *ku-pa-na-tu* (vs. m. *ku-pa-nu*) | Standard Semitic f. sg. |
| Feminine -ti | *da-ku-se-ne-ti*, *pa-da-su-ti* | Feminizes names |
| Relative *dū* | *du ra-re* "that of the night-demon" | Arabic *ḏū*, Aramaic *dī* |
| Verb + suffix | *ya-ta-no-x* "he gave it" | Object suffix |
| Causative *yaš-* | *ya-sa-sa-ra-mu* | Shafel (as in Ugaritic) |
| Preposition *re* | *re ya-sa-[sa-ra-m?]* "as a votive offering" | Arabic *li* (vs. Hebrew *la*) |
| Conjunction *u* | *ya-ta-no-x u ya-[* ]* | Punic, Akkadian form |

content:
| Term | Definition | Source |
|------|------------|--------|
| *Virtual bilingual* | Parallel texts allowing linguistic inference without true translation | §115 (e.g., WHEAT + *ku-ni-su*) |
| *Determinative* | Semantic classifier following a word (WHEAT, WINE) | Linear A/B convention |
| *Acrophony* | Sign value from initial CV of depicted word | §167 (developed in Part 3) |
| *Shafel causative* | Semitic causative with *š-* prefix | §160 (cf. Ugaritic) |
| *Triptotic noun* | Noun with three case endings (-u, -a, -i) | §151 |

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 3: Phaistos Disc & Origins

content: This concluding section applies Gordon's acrophonic method to the Phaistos Disc, proposes a historical origin for the Minoans (Northwest Semites from the Egyptian Delta), and synthesizes the dialect evidence. Though Gordon acknowledges the Disc interpretation is "especially subject to correction" (Foreword), his acrophonic readings and the Delta hypothesis provide the capstone to his Minoan-Semitic thesis. **Why this matters for Kothar**: The Phaistos Disc analysis demonstrates how acrophony works—the principle underlying the entire Linear A decipherment. The Delta hypothesis explains *why* a Semitic-speaking civilization arose on Crete ca. 1800 BC. ---

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 3: Phaistos Disc & Origins

content:
> "The Phaistos Disc was found in a context of Linear A tablets and should go with Linear A linguistically. The script is related to Linear A as Egyptian Hieroglyphs are to Hieratic."

**Key insight**: The signs were pressed with dies into wet clay—"a simple kind of printing."

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 3: Phaistos Disc & Origins

content:
> "What has emerged is that the phonetic values are derived acrophonically from the Semitic words that the pictographs portray. This means that the script was devised for the Minoan language and not for some still undeciphered tongue."

**Implication**: Once a pictograph is matched with the right Semitic word, the sign can be pronounced.

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 3: Phaistos Disc & Origins

content:
The Disc is written spirally, continuing the tradition of:
- Knossos magic bowl II,1
- Aramaic Incantation Bowls of Sasanian Mesopotamia

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 3: Phaistos Disc & Origins

content: A peculiarity: All bodies and heads are in profile. The LIONESS head corresponds to the Linear A *ma*-sign (which faces front).

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 3: Phaistos Disc & Origins

content: H. D. Ephron determined on mechanical grounds that the script runs **left to right**, beginning at the center—like the magic bowls.

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 3: Phaistos Disc & Origins

content:
Gordon and B. Schwartz identified several sign values:

| Sign | Value | Semitic Word | Meaning |
|------|-------|--------------|---------|
| FLYING BIRD | *ku* | *kudr-* (Ugaritic/Syriac) | "vulture, bird of prey" |
| SANDALED FOOT | *no* | *nōl-* < *naʿl-* | "sandal" (with ʿayin > o shift) |
| BOAT | *su* | Hebrew *sĕfīnā* | "boat" |
| MOUTH | *pe* | Hebrew *pē* | "mouth" |
| BARLEY | *ʾi* | Egyptian *it* | "barley" (loanword) |
| MAN | *pu/bu* | Ugaritic *bu-nu-šu* | "man" |
| HOUSE (ground plan) | *pa/ba* | Semitic *bayt* | "house" |
| HORN | *kr-* | Semitic *karn-* | "horn" → "town" (*krk*) |
| LIONESS | *ma* | Egyptian *mꜣit* | "lioness" (loanword) |
| BREAST | *ha* | *haynīq* | "to suckle" |
| CORNER | *pi* | Hebrew *pinnā* | "corner" |

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 3: Phaistos Disc & Origins

content:
A word occurs thrice: once simple, twice with suffix. | Form | Syllables | Linear A Parallel |
|------|-----------|-------------------|
| ⌂⚪⟁⟠ | *no-ha-na-ma* | *no-x-na-ma* |
| ⌂⚪⟁⟠⊗ | *no-ha-na-ma-ti* | *no-x-na-mi-na* (m. pl.) |

The suffix *-ti* is feminine plural, vs. Linear A masculine plural *-mi-na*.

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 3: Phaistos Disc & Origins

content:
> "A frequent word occurring five times in the Disc is written HORN + *ku*. The Semitic word for 'horn' is *karn-*. However, we know from the early Eteocretan text from Praisos (§33) that the word for 'town' was pronounced *krk* (as distinct from *kark*, which appears later). Accordingly, *krn-* (rather than *karn-*) would be the Minoan pronunciation of the word for 'horn.' HORN + *ku* should therefore be read *kr-ku* 'town.'"

This matches the high frequency of "town" in both the Disc and the Praisos texts.

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 3: Phaistos Disc & Origins

content:
| Disc Signs | Reading | Ugaritic Parallel |
|------------|---------|-------------------|
| BOAT-MOUTH-BARLEY-? | *su-pe-ʾi-ti* | *spīt* "I have eaten" |

> "Now the latter [*spīt*] is used in a magico-religious context 'to eat a ceremonial meal in the house of Baal.'"

**Full phrase**: *su-pe-ʾi-ti* followed by CORNER-MAN-*te-ha-da* = *pi-pu-te-ha-da*

**Interpretation**: The combination *pu-te* (occurring 5 times) = Ugaritic *bwt* "house, temple"

The final syllables *ha-da* = oblique case of הדד *Hadda* = Ugaritic *hd* = another name of Baal. > "We have here a parallel to the religious rite of eating a ceremonial meal in the Shrine of Baal (cf. Ugaritic *spī ksmh bt bʿl* in text 2 Aqht:I:32)... If this is correct, the shrine connected with the Phaistos Palace is the Temple of Baal/Hadd." (§174)

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 3: Phaistos Disc & Origins

content: The HOUSE sign depicting a ground plan should have value *pa/ba* (from *bayt* "house"). > "Since a repeated cluster begins with *pa-i-* in a context that mentions *kr-ku* 'town,' the cluster may begin with *pa-i-to* 'Phaistos': as it is spelled out in both Linear A and B."

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 3: Phaistos Disc & Origins

content:
> "More work remains to be done on the Disc but it seems to be in the same Semitic language as Linear A. It shows that the Minoan script is acrophonic. Its analogues with Egyptian writing confirm what should have been evident from the orthographic convergence of l and r and from the similarity of certain signs like that for WINE: the Minoan script reflects the Egyptian system."

---

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 3: Phaistos Disc & Origins

content:
Professor Clark Hopkins observed that Minoan architecture points to southern origins:

- **Absence of hearth** (essential in Greece, Anatolia)
- **Emphasis on light and air**
- **Stress on birds and flowers in ornamentation**

Hopkins suggests: Cyprus, Cilician coast, Syria (even south of the Orontes).

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 3: Phaistos Disc & Origins

content:
> "When we ask ourselves what historic factor impelled the palace builders to occupy Crete in MM I, we must consider the establishment of the Middle Kingdom under Upper Egyptian leadership against the non-Egyptians who had become too strong in the Delta."

**Gordon's argument**:

1. The entire East Mediterranean was permeated with Northwest Semites
2. The Delta was never "pure Egyptian" like Upper Egypt—it was "Levantine" with large Semitic population
3. Egypt was called "The Two Lands" for good reason
4. At the end of the First Intermediate Period (= MM I), Upper Egypt expelled non-Egyptians from the Delta
5. The palace-building Minoans arrived on Crete precisely then (MM I)

> "We can now answer, in broad outline, who the palace-building Minoans were, that imposed their already highly developed Bronze Age civilization on Neolithic Crete. They were Northwest Semites mainly from the Delta. However, they were essentially the same people as the other Northwest Semites in Libya, Palestine, Phoenicia, Syria, etc., so that it would be a mistake to insist that all of the early Minoans came exclusively from the Delta." (§178)

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 3: Phaistos Disc & Origins

content:
> "Greek tradition tells us that Belos and his sons Aigyptos and Danaos were from Northeast Africa but were not Egyptians; they were Phoenicians. We can now understand the tradition."

As F. H. Stubbings noted: "Aeschylus is at pains to demonstrate that though [Danaos] came from Egypt he was not an Egyptian."

---

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 3: Phaistos Disc & Origins

content:
> "Our survey of Minoan, Eteocretan and Eteocypriote shows that we are dealing with a variety of very closely related Northwest Semitic dialects. The ancient Greeks applied the name 'Phoenician' to the language and the people who spoke it."

**The dialect spectrum**:
- Phoenician proper (Byblos, Tyre, Sidon, Arvad, Cilicia, Cyprus)
- Minoan-Eteocretan-Eteocypriote

All were **mutually intelligible**.

metadata.title: Minoica (1962)

content: This foundational article moves beyond the Hagia Triada tablets to analyze dedicatory formulas from cultic objects across eastern and central Crete. Gordon establishes that Linear A represents "West Semitic, of the Phoenician type" through analysis of vocabulary (*ki-re-ya-tu* "city," *ya-ne* "wine," *bi-ti za* "this house"), morphology (prefixed *t-* verbs, the particle *ki* "so that"), and syntax. He also identifies the conjunction *u* "and" as West Semitic rather than East Semitic, revising his earlier position on the Hagia Triada dialect. **Why this matters for Kothar**: This is Gordon's key methodological article establishing Linear A as specifically Phoenician-type West Semitic, providing the linguistic foundation for the Minoan-Semitic thesis that connects Crete to the Canaanite world from which Kothar-wa-Hasis originates. ---

metadata.title: Minoica (1962)

content:
**Thesis**: The dedicatory formula proves Semitic morphology and syntax, not just vocabulary. **Reading:**
- *le ya-sa-[sa-ra-mu]* = "to the deity Y." (with preposition לְ)
- *ki-te-te-bi ki-re-ya-tu* = "so that the city may be well"
- *ki-re-ya-tu* = קִרְיָה (*qiryat-*) "city" (Hebrew/Ugaritic)
- *ki-* = כִּי "so that, because" particle

**Analysis**: Gordon identifies three West Semitic features in one inscription:
1. Preposition *le-* = לְ "to, for"
2. Particle *ki* = כִּי "so that"
3. Noun *qiryat-* = קִרְיָה "city"

**Key quote**: "The fact remains that any single one of these West Semitic features (לְ, 'to,' כִּי 'so that,' קִרְיָה, 'city') would suffice to indicate the West Semitic character of the Minoan texts."

metadata.title: Minoica (1962)

content:
**Thesis**: The word *ya-ne* inscribed on a pithos fragment means "wine."

**Evidence:**
- Two-syllable word with word-dividers on either side
- Following Linear B orthographic rules, *yai-* would be written *ya-*
- Therefore *ya-ne* = *yain-* = יַיִן "wine"
- Context: label referring to pithos contents

metadata.section: 2. Wine on the Knossos Pithos (Text II,3)
metadata.title: Minoica (1962)

content:
**Thesis**: The phrase *bi-ti za* means "this house" (i.e., the shrine). **Reading**: *bi-ti za* = Phoenician בַּיִת זֶה "this house"

**Orthographic problem and solution**: If *ya-ne* "wine" uses *ya-* for diphthong *ai*, why does *bi-ti* "house" use *bi-*? Gordon's answer: Hebrew shows the same variation:
- בַּיִת < **bait* (with diphthong preserved)
- חַיִּים *haiq-* (with different treatment)

Alternative: *bi-ti za* may represent "בּיתי זה" = "this house of mine" with regressive vocalic assimilation (*baitī* > *bittī* = *bītī*), as known from Ugaritic.

metadata.title: Minoica (1962)

content: **Thesis**: "Eteocretan" is simply a late survival of Phoenician on Crete. **Evidence**: The Psychro stone (ca. 300 BC) opens with EΠIΘI ZH (also rendered *i-bi-ti* in Minoan characters), possibly equivalent to Phoenician (הַ)בַּיִת "the house" with definite article. **Key quote**: "The collocation of EΠIΘI ZH in the Psychro 'Eteocretan' text with Minoan Linear A *bi-ti za* hints at the possibility of the 'Eteocretan' language being simply a late survival of Phoenician on Crete."

metadata.title: Minoica (1962)

content:
**Thesis**: Minoan uses *u* "and" rather than expected *wa*, requiring revision of the East Semitic hypothesis. **Evidence:**
- Text I, 4:c: *a-[sa]-sa-ra-mu u-na-ru-ka-na* = "(Y)asasaramu and Nergal"
- HT 28:a:1-2: *a-ne-ya-ka u-mi-na-ne* = "A. and Minan"

**Significance**: Gordon had previously argued for East Semitic identity based on *u* (instead of *wa*). This article acknowledges *u* occurs in West Semitic Minoan, necessitating re-examination. **Key quote**: "Since the use of *u* (instead of *wa*) was my main reason for maintaining an East Semitic identity of the Hagia Triada dialect, the whole Hagia Triada problem requires re-examination."

metadata.title: Minoica (1962)

content:
**Thesis**: The formula *(y)a-ta-no-L88* parallels Phoenician votive inscriptions. **Evidence:**
- Five dedications open with *(y)a-ta-no-L88*
- Phoenician root *ytn* "to erect or set up (as a dedication)" is common from Karatepe onward
- Text I, 14: *ya-ta-no-L88 u ya-[ ]* parallels Phoenician יִתֵּן וְיָטַנְא "gave and set up"
- Text I, 8:a: *ta-nu-a-ti* = form of *tn'* "to set up"

metadata.title: Minoica (1962)

content:
> "We are now in the second phase of determining the Linear A language. The first phase began in 1957 with the Semitic identification of 'Minoan A'; the present study shows that the language is West Semitic, of the Phoenician type. Further refinements lie ahead."

— *Context*: The concluding methodological statement, marking the transition from general "Semitic" to specifically "Phoenician-type West Semitic."

> "Indo-Europeanists, including a dedicated group of Classicists, have been advancing our knowledge of the Mycenaean Greek Linear B tablets. Semitists have no right to expect the Indo-Europeanists to shoulder the responsibility of interpreting the Linear A documents as well. I hope this article will lead some Semitists—particularly young Hebraists—into a new and challenging field that will yield rich results in West Semitic linguistics."

— *Context*: Gordon's call for Semitists to engage with Minoan studies, challenging disciplinary boundaries. > "That the Semitic names of Hagia Triada are primarily West Semitic has been abundantly clear for some time; e.g., *da-we-da*, 'David,' *da-gu-na*, 'Dagon,' *gu-pa₃-nu* = Ugaritic 'Gupanu,' and its feminine counterpart *gu-pa₃-na-tu*, etc."

— *Context*: Evidence for West Semitic deity and personal names at Hagia Triada. ---

metadata.title: Ugarit and Caphtor

content: This article argues that Caphtor (Minoan Crete) was "the principal source of inspiration for early Greek and Hebrew culture." Gordon demonstrates connections through: (1) the Ugaritic craftsman god Kothar-wa-Hasis whose workshop was on Caphtor, (2) the Kret legend linking Cretan and Semitic epic traditions, (3) the Moses-Minos and Daedalus-Bezalel parallels, and (4) linguistic evidence from the term *srn* "tyrant" found at both Ugarit and in the Bible for Philistine rulers. **Why this matters for Kothar**: This article provides the most direct connection between Kothar-wa-Hasis (the Ugaritic craftsman god after whom Kothar is named) and Crete, establishing Caphtor as his workshop and as the cultural bridge between Greek and Hebrew civilization. ---

metadata.title: Ugarit and Caphtor

content:
**Thesis**: "Throughout the second millennium B.C., but especially during its latter half, the islands and coastal mainland of the East Mediterranean shared a large cultural common denominator. The focal point of the unifying forces was Crete together with culturally related Aegean areas."

**Evidence for Caphtor = Crete:**
- Egyptian *kftîw* "Caphtor" attested since 18th Dynasty; as divine name *hr-kftî* ("Horus of Caphtor") back to Middle Kingdom
- Hebrew "Caphtor" = homeland of Philistines (Amos 9:7)
- "Philistines" interchangeable with "Cretans" (Ezekiel 25:16) and "Caphtorians" (Deuteronomy 2:23)
- Consonantal skeleton *kft* = *KPT* with variants *kp tr* (Hebrew-style) and *hkpt* (prefixed form)

**Phonetic note**: Ugaritic variant *hqkpt* shows double writing of palatal stop (*-qk-*) because "Caphtorian *k* was not quite the same as Semitic *k*, but between Semitic *k* and *q*."

metadata.title: Ugarit and Caphtor

content:
**Thesis**: The Ugaritic god of arts and crafts (*Ktr w Hss*), resembling Hephaestus, had his workshop located in Caphtor. **Key textual evidence:**
- Workshop appears in two poetic forms: *kp tr* and *hkpt* (to suit parallelistic poetry requirements)
- Text 51:I:35: Kothar fashions *hdm id* "a footstool of Ida" — the Idaean footstool

**The word *hdm* "footstool":**
- Hebrew: *hădōm*
- Egyptian: *hdmw* (not attested before 18th Dynasty)
- NOT Semitic (absent from Akkadian, Arabic, Ethiopic)
- Conclusion: Loan from Caphtorian into Hebrew and Egyptian

**Mount Ida:** "In all probability *id* refers to Mount Ida in Crete, though we should note that 'Ida' is also found in Asia Minor; cf. the Mount Ida overlooking Troy."

metadata.title: Ugarit and Caphtor

content:
**Thesis**: The Caphtorian word *srn* appears at both Ugarit and in the Bible, proving the Caphtorian settlers in both localities spoke the same language. **Semantic development:**
- Primary meaning: "axle" (cf. Syriac *surna*, Hebrew *sarnê nêhōšet* "copper axles" in 1 Kings 7:30)
- Secondary meaning: "tyrant, king" — applied to Philistine rulers (1 Samuel 6:16–18)
- Parallel: Hebrew *'ōfan* "wheel" also designates an angel in the hierarchy
- "Apparently the state was pictured as a chariot, which depended on the strength of its axles and wheels."

**At Ugarit:**
- *srn* and *bn srn* "Son of Srn" occur as personal names (= "King" and "Son of the King")
- Parallel: Semitic names *mlk* and *bn mlk* meaning "King" and "Son of the King"
- Phrase *yn srnm* = "wine of kings"

metadata.title: Ugarit and Caphtor

content:
**Thesis**: The Legend of King Kret links Cretan and Semitic epic traditions and serves as the "connecting link between Greek and Hebrew epic."

**The Helen-of-Troy motif:**
- King *Krēt* loses his beautiful wife *Hurray* (cf. Helen)
- He gathers an army and marches to *Odom* (cf. Troy) to recover her
- He gets his wife back, as in the Iliad

**Parallels with Homer (general):**
- Mingling of men and gods
- *Krēt* is a divine king; head of pantheon attends his wedding
- In Iliad: divine heroes; gods give wedding gifts to Peleus and Thetis

**Parallels with Homer (specific):**
- Lavish gifts offered (short of the heroine herself) to induce invading army to leave
- Offers rejected by *Krēt* outside *Odom* and by Achaeans outside Troy

**Parallels with Hebrew epic:**
- David weds princess Michal; she is taken away; he must get her back
- "Thus the legend of the Cretan hero *Kret* is the connecting link between Greek and Hebrew epic."

**Key quote**: "No matter how different Homer and the Hebrew 'Epic of Kings' may be in spirit, they draw on the same epic repertoire for content."

metadata.section: 4. The Kret Legend as Epic Bridge
metadata.title: Ugarit and Caphtor

content:
**Moses-Minos:**
- Minos: giver of divine law, obtained (according to some traditions) on a mountain
- Moses: got the Law from God on Mount Sinai
- Both lay down foundations of society

**Daedalus-Bezalel:**
- Daedalus: master craftsman of Minoan tradition
- Bezalel: Moses's master craftsman
- Bezalel's creations include *kaftōrîm* "caphtors" (Exodus 37:17, 19–22)
- The word *kaftōrîm* bears the name of "the homeland of early Israel's major source of cultural inspiration"

**Key quote**: "What has not been noted is that the second greatest figure in Minoan tradition, namely Daedalus, has his counterpart in Moses's master-craftsman Bezalel."

metadata.title: Ugarit and Caphtor

content:
**Time limit**: Caphtorian influence on Israel "stops rather abruptly with the end of David's reign."

**Evidence from hair style:**
- Long hair "in the Cretan manner" in time of Deborah (Judges 5:2), Samson (Judges 16:19), Absalom (2 Samuel 14:26; 18:9)
- Also frequent in Iliad ("the long-haired Achaeans")
- "After the Davidic period it is never mentioned again"

It therefore follows that, in the years ahead, the field covered by 'Minos' is destined to be the cornerstone of the study of the origin of Western Civilization."

— *Context*: The concluding statement, asserting Minoan studies as central to understanding Western origins. > "The Hebrew account from Abraham through David's reign is based on East Mediterranean epic sources, just as Homer's epics are. Both are due to the Caphtorian impact."

— *Context*: Gordon's thesis that both Greek and Hebrew epic traditions derive from Caphtorian influence. > "Just as the Mycenaean offshoot of Caphtor was the basic civilizing factor of Achaean Greece, so too was the Philistine offshoot of Caphtor the basic civilizing factor of nascent Israel."

— *Context*: The parallel development of Greek and Israelite civilization from common Caphtorian roots. ---

metadata.title: Ugarit and Its Significance (Ugarit and Minoan Crete, Chapter I)

content:
This introductory chapter establishes the historical significance of Ugarit as the crossroads of Bronze Age civilizations. Gordon describes the 1928 discovery, the rapid decipherment of Ugaritic cuneiform, and Ugarit's position at the center of the "Amarna Order"—the international synthesis linking Mesopotamia, Egypt, the Hittites, and the Sea People. He argues that Ugarit provides the common backdrop to both Greek and Hebrew literatures, and explicitly challenges scholars who wish to keep Minoan civilization "free of Asiatic—and particularly Semitic—'contamination.'"

**Why this matters for Kothar**: This chapter establishes the methodological framework for the entire book—Ugarit as the link between East and West Mediterranean, and the argument that relationship and individuality are not mutually exclusive. ---

metadata.title: Ugarit and Its Significance (Ugarit and Minoan Crete, Chapter I)

content:
**Narrative**: In 1928, a peasant accidentally plowed into an ancient Mycenaean-style tomb near the Syrian coast. French authorities sponsored excavations at Ras Shamra ("Fennel Head"), the mound marking ancient Ugarit. **Rapid decipherment:**
- Cuneiform tablets in a new script discovered early 1929
- Published by Charles Virolleaud before the close of 1929
- Three scholars independently deciphered the script in 1930:
  1. Hans Bauer (first to publish)
  2. Edouard Dhorme (second)
  3. Charles Virolleaud (third)

**Key quote**: "It is to the lasting credit of French scholarship that the tablets were published in record time before the close of 1929."

metadata.title: Ugarit and Its Significance (Ugarit and Minoan Crete, Chapter I)

content:
**Thesis**: Ugarit derived its importance from its location at the center of what was destined to become the cradle of Western civilization. **The International Order (ca. 1400–1200 BC):**

| Direction | Power | Significance |
|-----------|-------|--------------|
| East | Mesopotamia | "Outstanding pioneer in literate culture and international trade" |
| South | Egypt | "The aristocrat of the international Order" |
| North | Hittite Empire | Leading power after defeating Mitannians |
| West | Sea People | Mycenaean Greeks emerging as dominant factor |

**Canaan's position**: Ugarit was near the northwest corner of Canaan, "the land that nurtured a number of linguistically related groups, including the Phoenicians and Hebrews."

**Key quote**: "Ugarit was in contact with the forerunners of the classical Greeks and Hebrews, who were destined to found Western civilization by their combined and parallel achievements."

metadata.title: Ugarit and Its Significance (Ugarit and Minoan Crete, Chapter I)

content:
**Definition**: The period (late 15th–early 14th century BC) when "the entire Near East form[ed] an Order centered on the East Mediterranean."

**Evidence**: The Tell el-Amarna tablets (found 1887–1933) contain Babylonian letters exchanged between Pharaohs and monarchs of Mesopotamia, Anatolia, Canaan, and Cyprus. **Key insight**: "The ancestors of the classical Hebrews and Greeks were then on the scene in the Levant. The Ugaritic texts therefore give us the backdrop to the earliest Greek and Hebrew literatures."

metadata.title: Ugarit and Its Significance (Ugarit and Minoan Crete, Chapter I)

content:
**Thesis**: The Ugaritic alphabet embodies the same tradition that came down through Phoenicians/Hebrews, Greeks, and Romans. **Evidence**: Ugaritic school texts list letters in fixed order: *a b g h d h w z h t y k š l m d n z s° p s q r t ġ t i u ṣ*

**Comparison:**
- English ABC: *a b—d—h—k l m n—p q r—t* appears in same Ugaritic sequence
- Hebrew: *a b g d h w z h t y k l m n s° p s q r—t* agrees even more strikingly

**Key quote**: "This alphabet is the most important and useful single invention of civilized man. Greece and Israel shared it—and much else besides."

metadata.title: Ugarit and Its Significance (Ugarit and Minoan Crete, Chapter I)

content:
**Evidence**: School tablets list words in three or four parallel columns:
- Three-column: Sumerian, Akkadian, Hurrian
- Four-column: adds Ugaritic

**Implication**: "A community that fostered a school system in which the advanced scribes studied texts to qualify them in four languages at a time, was highly sophisticated."

**Key quote**: "The earliest Greek and Hebrew literatures stem from a highly cultured and international milieu. There is nothing primitive about either of them."

metadata.title: Ugarit and Its Significance (Ugarit and Minoan Crete, Chapter I)

content:
**Thesis**: The tacit assumption that Israel and Greece were "independent cultures, poles apart" is contradicted by the Ugaritic epics. **The Athens-Sparta analogy**:
- "It would be hard to imagine two cultures more different than those of Athens and Sparta in the Age of Pericles, and yet because they were both Greek we know that they were related."
- "The newspapers in the homes of the English village and in the apartments of Manhattan are better historical and cultural criteria than the buildings."

**Against scholarly resistance**: Gordon explicitly challenges "some writers who want to keep Minoan civilization free of Asiatic—and particularly Semitic—'contamination.'"

**Key quote**: "What is often misunderstood is that relationship and individuality are not mutually exclusive."

metadata.section: 6. Against Separating Greece from the Semitic World
metadata.title: Ugarit and Its Significance (Ugarit and Minoan Crete, Chapter I)

content:
**Thesis**: The decipherment of Linear A moves Minoan studies from prehistory to history. **Key quote**: "There are veteran Minoan scholars who have not really come to grips with the fact that with the decipherment of Linear A, their field has emerged from prehistory into history."

---

metadata.section: 7. The Shift from Prehistory to History
metadata.title: Ugarit and Its Significance (Ugarit and Minoan Crete, Chapter I)

content:
> "Ugarit was the heir of the great cultures that had gone before, from Sumer to Egypt. Ugarit had the closest relations with people such as the Hittites and Hurrians, who were of prime importance in Mycenaean times, but were destined to disappear and require the spade of the archaeologist to revive their memory."

— *Context*: Establishing Ugarit's position as inheritor and transmitter of ancient traditions. > "We need not and must not withhold credit from the Ugaritians themselves. They were a talented and enterprising people in their own right. But they were lucky to be living in the right place at the right time: at the crossroads of the Western world when the seeds of Hellas and Israel had been planted and were producing their first fruits."

— *Context*: Balancing Ugarit's derivative and original contributions. > "A tacit assumption has it that Israel and Greece were independent cultures, poles apart. Speciously, a case can be made for such a view. For when did Israel produce a Parthenon, and when did Greece bring forth an Isaiah? But the Ugaritic epics, as will appear below, have unmistakable and organic parallels that link the preprophetic Hebrews with the prephilosophical Greeks."

— *Context*: The central thesis of the book, challenging disciplinary separation. ---

metadata.title: Ugaritic Literature and Its Greco-Hebrew Affinities (Ugarit and Minoan Crete, Chapter II)

content: This chapter establishes the cultural mechanisms by which Ugaritic literature connects Greek and Hebrew traditions. Gordon demonstrates how guild mobility (craftsmen, traders, priests) spread cultural complexes across the East Mediterranean, then traces specific parallels: the Baal-Mot cycle's sabbatical structure, Kothar-wa-Hasis coming from Caphtor to build Baal's palace, the Helen-of-Troy motif linking Homer's Iliad to the Epic of Kret to Genesis, and the shared vocabulary of Danel's curse and David's lament over Gilboa. **Why this matters for Kothar**: This chapter explicitly places Kothar-wa-Hasis as the link between Crete and Ugarit, shows how the Helen-of-Troy motif bridges Greek and Hebrew epic, and provides the cultural context for understanding Minoan-Semitic connections. ---

metadata.title: Ugaritic Literature and Its Greco-Hebrew Affinities (Ugarit and Minoan Crete, Chapter II)

content:
**Thesis**: The international spread of cultural patterns in the Bronze Age East Mediterranean resulted from the mobility of guildsmen—craftsmen, potters, warriors, traders, and priests. **Evidence:**
- "There was no point in importing fragile ceramics for ordinary household use. It was the potters, rather than their wares, who could move without breakage."
- Warriors organized into guilds (like the *maryannu* charioteers) served on both sides of conflicts
- Ugaritic text 81 mentions mobile traders (*mkrm* = Hebrew *môkērîm*) and two priestly guilds: *khnm* (= Hebrew *kōhănîm*) and *qdšm* (= Hebrew *qĕdēšîm*)

metadata.title: Ugaritic Literature and Its Greco-Hebrew Affinities (Ugarit and Minoan Crete, Chapter II)

content:
Gordon's footnote 4 provides a crucial insight into how the Hebrews selectively adopted and rejected Canaanite religious institutions:

> "This illustrates the fact that the Hebrews sometimes **borrowed from** (as in the case of the *kōhănîm*), and at other times **reacted against** (as in the case of the *qĕdēšîm*), their Canaanite milieu."

- **Kōhănîm** (כֹּהֲנִים): The legitimate priestly guild, borrowed from Canaanite practice and retained throughout biblical history to the present day
- **Qĕdēšîm** (קְדֵשִׁים): Temple functionaries associated with Asherah's cult, eliminated by King Josiah around 621 BC (II Kings 23:7)

**Significance**: This demonstrates that Hebrew religion was not created *ex nihilo* but emerged through selective adoption and deliberate rejection of existing Canaanite institutions. The same Ugaritic text documenting both priestly guilds shows they operated side by side in Canaanite religion; Israel's choice to keep one and eliminate the other reveals the theological priorities of emerging Yahwism. **Key quote**: "The international spread of religious guilds helped disseminate cultic practices and religious beliefs far and wide."

metadata.title: Ugaritic Literature and Its Greco-Hebrew Affinities (Ugarit and Minoan Crete, Chapter II)

content:
**Thesis**: West Semitic divine names reached Greek soil, proved by the site name "Sapyselaton" near Epidauris. **Analysis:**
- Pausanius (2:25:10) records the name "Sapyselaton"
- "Sapys" = Ugaritic *Spš*, the sun "goddess" (*elat*)
- The *p* (not *m*) and feminine gender link it to Ugaritic, not Akkadian
- This is distinctively Northwest Semitic: "unmistakably with the Ugaritic branch"

metadata.section: 2. Sapyselaton: West Semitic Divine Names in Greece
metadata.title: Ugaritic Literature and Its Greco-Hebrew Affinities (Ugarit and Minoan Crete, Chapter II)

content:
**Thesis**: The word for "bull" connecting El/Thôr to Greek/Latin *taur-* entered the Aegean through Semitic channels. **Evidence:**
- El is called *Thôr* "the Bull" at Ugarit
- In Judges 6:25, God is mentioned as *ha-š-Šôr* "the Bull"
- Cognates: Arabic *thawr-*, Hebrew/Akkadian *šôr-*, Aramaic *tôr-*, Greek/Latin *taur-*
- "The role of the bull in religion and sport is strikingly similar in both the Semitic and Indo-European segments of Mediterranean civilization, especially in the Minoan-Mycenaean sphere."

metadata.title: Ugaritic Literature and Its Greco-Hebrew Affinities (Ugarit and Minoan Crete, Chapter II)

content:
**Thesis**: Text 52 shows the sabbatical cycle as a Canaanite institution predating Hebrew adoption. **Content:**
- El sires progeny from two human wives
- First: Dawn (*Šaḥar*) and Dusk
- Later: Seven Good Gods of fertility (seven-year cycle of plenty)

**Significance:**
- "A milestone in the evolution of the drama"—equipped with stage directions
- "The sabbatical cycle of the Old Testament is a religious and agricultural institution taken over by the Hebrews from the older, native population of Canaan"
- Anticipates Hosea and Ezekiel (23:1ff) in the "God with two women" theme

metadata.section: 4. El's Drama and the Sabbatical Cycle (Text 52)
metadata.title: Ugaritic Literature and Its Greco-Hebrew Affinities (Ugarit and Minoan Crete, Chapter II)

content:
**Thesis**: The dualistic conflict between good and evil entered biblical tradition through Canaanite heritage. **Key text**: Anath boasts of aiding Baal against "the monster of evil, Leviathan"

**Parallels:**
- Psalm 74:14 attributes victory over many-headed Leviathan to Yahweh
- Isaiah 27:1: "the evil serpent," "the crooked serpent," "Tannin"
- "The terminology... is verbally identical in Ugaritic and Hebrew. We are dealing with a specific borrowing, not with the reappearance of a universal theme."

metadata.title: Ugaritic Literature and Its Greco-Hebrew Affinities (Ugarit and Minoan Crete, Chapter II)

content:
**Thesis**: Kothar-wa-Hasis coming from Caphtor (Crete) to build Baal's palace proves Crete was part of the Northwest Semitic sphere. **The Palace:**
- Built of gold, silver, lapis lazuli
- Columns from cedars of Lebanon
- Architect: Kothar-wa-Hasis, who proposes including a window
- Through the window comes Mot (cf. Jeremiah 9:20-21)

**The Caphtor Connection:**
- "Kothar-and-Hasis is represented as coming to Baal from Caphtor (Crete); his name is pure Semitic."
- "All this can only mean that Crete was part of the same Northwest Semitic sphere as Ugarit, culturally, religiously, and linguistically."

**Solomon parallel**: "As Solomon (in the tenth century BC) turned to Phoenicia, so Ugarit (around the middle of the second millennium BC) looked to Crete, for the best art in the contemporary West Semitic sphere."

metadata.title: Ugaritic Literature and Its Greco-Hebrew Affinities (Ugarit and Minoan Crete, Chapter II)

content:
**Thesis**: Dagon as fish-god of the sea-faring Philistines from Crete. **Etymology**: *Dag-on* = *dāg* "fish" + suffix *-ôn*
- "An appropriate name for the god of a sea people such as the Philistines, who came from Crete"
- Name spelled *Da-gu-na* in Minoan tablets from Hagia Triada

metadata.title: Ugaritic Literature and Its Greco-Hebrew Affinities (Ugarit and Minoan Crete, Chapter II)

content:
**Thesis**: The Ugaritic moon cult text contains an annunciation formula anticipating Isaiah 7:14. **Text**: "The virgin will give birth" and "lo the maid will bear a son"

**Context**: Wedding of moon god Yarih and goddess Nikkal, predicting fertile union

metadata.title: Ugaritic Literature and Its Greco-Hebrew Affinities (Ugarit and Minoan Crete, Chapter II)

content: **Thesis**: The form *Yw-il* in Ugaritic shows Yahweh as El's son before monotheistic synthesis. **Key quote**: "By identifying a particular god (*Yaw-* or Yahweh) with the head of the pantheon (El), and equating him with the principle of godhood (*Elohim*), the Hebrews arrived at the monotheism that has taken root in Western civilization."

metadata.title: Ugaritic Literature and Its Greco-Hebrew Affinities (Ugarit and Minoan Crete, Chapter II)

content:
**Thesis**: The Epic of Aqhat was known to the Hebrews and provides pre-Hebrew literary sources. **Parallels:**
- Levi's son Qehat ("Kohath") = variant of Aqhat
- Ezekiel 14:14; 28:3 mentions Danel by name
- Incubation and sacrifice for obtaining a model son = Abraham/Isaac pattern
- *Kosharot* (songstresses/muses) appear in Psalm 68:7
- Pughat's transvestism = why Deuteronomy forbids cross-dressing

**Danel's Curse:**
> "Seven years may Baal afflict thee / Eight, the Rider of Clouds! / Let there be no dew / Let there be no rain / Let there be no surging of the Two Deeps / Let there be no goodness of Baal's voice!"

**David's Lament (II Samuel 1:21):**
> "O mountains of Gilboa / Let there be no rain / Let there be no dew upon you!"

**Key quote**: "Danel and David react in the same way and express themselves in almost identical words because the culture and literature of heroic Israel stemmed from the heritage of Canaan."

metadata.title: Ugaritic Literature and Its Greco-Hebrew Affinities (Ugarit and Minoan Crete, Chapter II)

content:
**Thesis**: The Epic of Kret bridges the gap between royal epic in Homer and Genesis through the Helen-of-Troy motif. **Pattern**: A king whose destined wife has departed must retrieve her from another king's palace. | Epic | King | Wife | Retriever |
|------|------|------|-----------|
| Kret | Kret | Hurrai | Kret |
| Iliad | Menelaus | Helen | Achaeans |
| Genesis 12 | Abraham | Sarah | Abraham (from Pharaoh) |
| Genesis 20 | Abraham | Sarah | Abraham (from Abimelech) |

**Key quote**: "Today an attempt would be made to hush up such a story; but in Mycenaean times, no East Mediterranean royal epic was complete without it."

**Kret in Bible:**
- Brook *Kret* in I Kings 17:3, 5
- Eponymous ancestor of Cretans/Philistines in Zephaniah 2:6
- Name occurs commonly in Hagia Triada tablets

---

— *Context*: The key passage establishing Crete's position in the Semitic cultural sphere through Kothar-wa-Hasis. > "It should thus be apparent that Ugarit has the most intimate connections with the Old Testament in language and literature. At the same time, Ugarit has close Aegean connections. Through the Helen-of-Troy motif in the Epic of Kret, Ugaritic literature bridges the gap between the Iliad and Genesis."

— *Context*: The concluding summary of the chapter's thesis. > "Danel and David react in the same way and express themselves in almost identical words because the culture and literature of heroic Israel stemmed from the heritage of Canaan."

— *Context*: On the verbal parallels between Danel's curse and David's lament over Gilboa. ---
