metadata.title: Chapter II: The Dithyramb, the Dromenon and the Drama

content: This chapter develops Harrison's theory that ritual action (*dromenon*) precedes and generates both myth (*legomenon*) and drama. The Greek dithyramb—the choral song to Dionysos from which tragedy arose—was originally a spring *dromenon*, a magical rite of renewal. Harrison traces the psychological and linguistic origins of the *dromenon* concept and argues that drama inherits its essential forms from seasonal fertility ritual. ---

metadata.title: Chapter II: The Dithyramb, the Dromenon and the Drama

content:
Harrison's foundational definition:

> "A *dromenon* is, literally, 'a thing done,' but the word has a shade of meaning that our word 'deed' has lost. By *dromenon* the Greeks meant not only a thing done but a thing re-done, or pre-done; a thing enacted or represented. It is sometimes translated 'ritual,' but *dromenon* goes to the very heart of ritual while 'ritual' is apt to emphasize the outer shell." (p. 35)

**Key distinction**: A *dromenon* is not mere action—it is action with **magical intent**, either commemorative (re-enacting the past) or anticipatory (pre-enacting the desired future).

metadata.title: Chapter II: The Dithyramb, the Dromenon and the Drama

content:
Harrison argues against the view that myths generate rituals:

> "This does not, however, imply, as is sometimes supposed, that ritual is prior to myth; they probably arose together. Ritual is the utterance of an emotion, a thing felt, in action, myth in words or thoughts. They arise *pari passu*. The myth is not at first aetiological, it does not arise to give a reason; it is representative, another form of utterance, of expression." (p. 16)

**The relationship**:
- τὰ δρώμενα = things done (ritual action)
- τὰ ἐπὶ τοῖς δρωμένοις λεγόμενα = things said upon the things done (accompanying words)

metadata.title: Chapter II: The Dithyramb, the Dromenon and the Drama

content:
The dithyramb marks the transition:

> "The Dithyramb was then a *dromenon*, 'a thing done' in relation to a *daimon*, a fertility spirit, and that fertility spirit was in the first instance the group itself. When the group—or if the group be already individualized, the representative of the group—did the Dithyramb, it did its own life-history, it enacted the *palingenesia* or New Birth." (p. 45)

**Three stages:**
1. Collective dance with undifferentiated participants
2. Emergence of a leader (*exarchos*) who stands apart
3. Dialogue between leader and chorus → birth of drama

metadata.title: Chapter II: The Dithyramb, the Dromenon and the Drama

content:
Harrison draws on contemporary psychology:

> "Pantomimic dancing is of the essence of each and every primitive mystery. To disclose the mysteries is, as Lucian puts it, 'to dance out the mysteries.' Instruction among savage peoples is always imparted more or less in mimetic dances." (p. 42)

Mimesis is not mere imitation but **participatory identification**—the dancer *becomes* what he enacts. ---

metadata.title: Chapter II: The Dithyramb, the Dromenon and the Drama

content:
> "Drama, like the Dithyramb out of which it came, was in its origin and essence the enactment, the *dromenon*, of a god; its representation was in ritual movement what the myth told in words. Drama lived its life in and through the cult of Dionysos because Dionysos, unlike the other Olympians, was himself in origin a *dromenon*, a thing annually enacted, the New Birth, the year-spirit incarnate." (p. 48)

— Context: Why drama belonged to Dionysos specifically, not to any other god. > "The primitive mind is not occupied in asking 'why?' It is too busy dancing and singing to ask questions. The *dromenon* is not an attempt to explain anything, it is simply a rite, a thing done, done for the good of the tribe, done because it always has been done, done with immediate magical intent." (p. 38)

— Context: Against intellectualist theories that see ritual as "primitive science."

metadata.title: Chapter III: The Kouretes, the Thunder-Rites and Mana

content: This chapter examines the thunder-rites practiced by the Kouretes and Idaean Daktyls, using the Euripides *Cretans* fragment as primary evidence. Harrison argues that the mystic "accomplished the Thunders" (βροντὰς τελέσας) through three ritual acts: purification by thunder-stone, hearing mimic thunder from the bull-roarer, and beholding the thunderbolt on a throne. The chapter establishes that sanctity (*mana*) precedes divinity—the thunderbolt was worshipped before Zeus existed to wield it. ---

metadata.title: Chapter III: The Kouretes, the Thunder-Rites and Mana

content:
Harrison analyzes a crucial passage preserved by Porphyry describing the initiation of a Bacchos:

> "There in one pure stream / My days have run, the servant I / Initiate of Idaean Jove; / Where midnight Zagreus roves, I rove. / I have endured his thunder-cry, / Fulfilled his red and bleeding feasts; / Held the Great Mother's mountain flame; / Enhallowed I and named by name / A Bacchos of the Mailed Priests." (p. 97)

**Key ritual elements:**
1. Thunder-cry (βροντάς) of night-wandering Zagreus
2. Feasts of Raw Flesh (ὠμοφαγία)
3. Mountain torches of the Great Mother
4. New name: "Bacchos"

metadata.title: Chapter III: The Kouretes, the Thunder-Rites and Mana

content:
Harrison explains how Pythagoras was initiated by the Idaean Daktyls:

> "Pythagoras, Porphyry tells us, in the course of his journey from Asia Minor to Italy came to Crete. There he met on landing some of the Mystae of Morgos, one of the Idaean Daktyls, by whom he was initiated into their rites. The first rite he underwent at their hands was purification, and this purification was effected by—the thunderbolt or thunder-stone." (p. 102)

The thunder-stone is a prehistoric celt (stone axe) mistaken for a thunderbolt:

> "Such stones are called to-day by the modern Greek peasant 'lightning-axes' (ἀστροπελέκια). Great is their value as charms against thunder, *similia similibus*, to keep milk sweet, to cure rheumatism and the like." (p. 102)

metadata.title: Chapter III: The Kouretes, the Thunder-Rites and Mana

content:
Harrison identifies the instrument of mimic thunder:

> "We know the very instrument with which in ancient days mimic thunder was manufactured, the famous Bull-roarer or ῥόμβος, the sound of whose whirring is mystical, awe-inspiring, and truly religious. It is like nothing in the world but itself, perhaps the nearest approach is the ominous sound of a rising storm-wind or angry imminent thunder." (p. 107)

The scholiast on Clement describes it: "a bit of wood to which a string is tied, and it is whirled round and round at initiation-rites to make a whirring sound."

metadata.title: Chapter III: The Kouretes, the Thunder-Rites and Mana

content:
Harrison argues that the initiate beheld not Zeus but the thunderbolt itself:

> "The thunderbolt was to the primitive Greek not the symbol or attribute of the god, but itself the divine thing, the embodiment and vehicle of the god. As such, long after Zeus had taken on full human form in literature, it held its place in cultus, not as a weapon in the hand of the human god, but actually occupying his throne." (p. 105)

Evidence from coins of Seleukeia Pieria shows "a large thunderbolt with fillet attached, lying on a cushion on a throne."

metadata.title: Chapter III: The Kouretes, the Thunder-Rites and Mana

content:
The complete ritual sequence:

> "In the mysteries of Zagreus, then, as practised by the Kouretes and Idaean Daktyls, the initiated man (1) was purified by a thunderbolt, (2) heard mimic thunder, (3) probably beheld a thunderbolt on a throne. After these experiences, he may, I think, fairly be said to have 'accomplished the Thunders.'" (p. 108)

metadata.title: Chapter III: The Kouretes, the Thunder-Rites and Mana

content:
Harrison traces the mythological identity of Zeus and the thunder-stone:

> "Hesiod knew it, at least subconsciously. When Kronos was about to swallow Zeus, what is it that Rhea gives him and that he really swallowed? A stone in swaddling clothes.... Long before Zeus was Zeus, thunder and lightning were, in a sense to be considered presently, divine potencies, their vehicle was a thunder-stone." (p. 106)

On the Hagia Triada terracotta relief: "We have seen three dancing Kouretes or Korybantes who clash their shields over the infant Zeus. Near him, lying on the ground, is a thunderbolt, his vehicle, his equivalent rather than his attribute."

---

metadata.title: Chapter III: The Kouretes, the Thunder-Rites and Mana

content:
> "The rites we are about to examine are then not rites of simple tribal initiation, but rather rites of initiation practised by the Kouretes in perhaps a later stage of their development as a magical fraternity. The Kouretes are now well on their way to become daimones; they will presently become actual gods (θεοί), as in Hesiod." (p. 98)

— Context: The Kouretes have specialized from general initiators to a magical fraternity. > "The word Titanes (white-clay-men) comes of course from τῑτάνος, white earth or clay, gypsum. The Titanes, the white-clay-men, were later, regardless of quantity, mythologized into Titanes, Titans, giants." (p. 95)

— Context: Etymology of Titans as initiators, not mythological beings. > "The Greeks, says a Christian Father, worship (θεραπεύουσι) the thunderbolt. The statement causes us something of a shock.... All he states is that they 'worshipped' the thunderbolt, that is, had a cult of it, tended it, attended to it, made it the object of 'religious' care." (p. 109)

— Context: Worship of the thunderbolt precedes worship of Zeus. ---

metadata.title: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu

content: This chapter establishes the theoretical framework for understanding magic as the manipulation of *mana*, with *tabu* as its negative counterpart. Harrison argues that magic was originally public, social, and royal—not the hole-and-corner practice of later times. Using the Dipylon rain-making fragment and the legends of Salmoneus and Picus, she demonstrates that the medicine-king made the weather before any god existed to control it. The bird-magician Picus reveals the undifferentiated unity of bird, seer, magician, and king that preceded anthropomorphic theology. ---

metadata.title: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu

content:
Harrison begins with Plato's surprising definition:

> "In the first dialogue that bears the name of Alcibiades Socrates is urging on Alcibiades to an exceptionally high standard of conduct.... 'the one who is wisest teaches the magic (μαγείαν) of Zoroaster the son of Horomazos'; and then to our surprise Socrates adds by way of explanation, 'the art of the magician is the service (θεραπεία) of the gods. The same man gives instruction in kingly duties' (τὰ βασιλικά)." (p. 111)

**Key insight**: Magic was the service of the gods, and knowledge of magic was part of royal education.

metadata.title: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu

content:
Harrison analyzes an eighth-century vase showing ceremonial rain-making:

> "A man is seated before an altar on which is a great 'Mycenaean' shield. In either hand he holds an implement... The soft plash is unmistakable. *He is making rain*; making it in the simplest yet most magical fashion." (p. 113)

The implements are gourd-rattles, used worldwide for rain-magic. The medicine-man is not worshipping the shield—he is actively making weather.

metadata.title: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu

content:
Harrison rehabilitates Salmoneus from blasphemer to medicine-king:

> "'Salmoneus,' Apollodorus tells us, 'said that he himself was Zeus, and he took away from Zeus his sacrifices and ordered men to sacrifice to him.' Of course he did nothing of the sort: there was no Zeus, there were no sacrifices. What he really did, Apollodorus tells us in the next sentence, he made the weather: 'he fastened bronze cauldrons by straps of hide to his chariot and dragged them after him and said that he was thundering, and threw up blazing torches into the sky and said that he was lightening.'" (p. 114)

At Krannon in Thessaly: "there was kept a bronze waggon, and 'when the land suffered from drought they shook it by way of praying the god for rain, and it was said rain came.'"

metadata.title: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu

content:
Harrison's central thesis on the priority of sanctity:

> "We now know, from a study of the customs and representations of primitive peoples, that, broadly speaking, the reverse is true, a thing is regarded as sacred, and out of that sanctity, given certain conditions, emerges a daimon and ultimately a god. *Le sacré, c'est le père du dieu*." (p. 110)

The thunderbolt is sacred before Zeus exists to wield it.

metadata.section: 4. Le sacré c'est le père du dieu
metadata.title: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu

content:
Harrison defines the relationship between mana and tabu:

> "In Greece a place that was struck by lightning became an ἄβατον, a spot not to be trodden on, unapproachable.... The other name for these tabu-ed places speaks clearly—they were ἐνηλοσίαι, places of coming. This Pollux tells us, is the name given to places on which a bolt from heaven has descended." (p. 129)

**The ἄβατον** (forbidden place) is fenced because it is charged with dangerous *mana*, not because a god cursed it.

metadata.title: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu

content:
Harrison analyzes the Latin woodpecker-king:

> "In the figure of Picus are united, or rather as yet undifferentiated, notions, to us incompatible, of bird, seer-magician, king and daimon, if not god. The daimon as we have already seen with respect to the Kouros Kings were not deified because there were as yet no *dei*. The medicine-king is predeistic, but possessed of those powers which later and more cultured ages have relegated to the 'gods.'" (p. 148)

Picus and Faunus taught Numa the thunder-charm: "a purification (καθαρμόν) against thunderbolts... compounded of onions, hairs, and pilchards."

metadata.title: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu

content:
Harrison argues birds were first weather-makers, then weather-portents:

> "This early way of thinking comes out most clearly in the case of a bird who never became the 'attribute' of any Olympian, the homely woodpecker.... The mantic weather-bird precedes the prophetic god." (p. 137)

**Aristophanes' *Birds*** preserves the memory:
> "We are Delphi, Ammon, Dodona, in fine / We are every oracular temple and shrine... / If birds are your omens, it clearly will follow / That birds are the proper prophetic Apollo." (p. 138)

metadata.title: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu

content:
> "Three hundred stadia further (in the country of the Apennines) is Tiora, called Matiene. Here there is said to have been an oracle of Mars of great antiquity. It is reported to have been similar in character to the fabled oracle at Dodona, except that, whereas at Dodona it was said that a dove perched on a sacred oak gave oracles, among the Aborigines the oracles were given in like fashion by a god-sent bird called by them Picus (the Greeks name it Dryokolaptes) which appears on a wooden pillar." (p. 141)

---

metadata.title: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu

content:
> "Magic was no hole and corner practice but an affair of public ritual, performed with full social sanction. We have in fact a state of things like that which Socrates attributed to the Persians, a social phase in which magic was the service (θεραπεία) of the gods; instruction about it might well be given as part of the duties of a king (τὰ βασιλικά); in a word magic was of the state, not of the individual." (p. 115)

— Context: Against the view that magic was always marginal and disreputable. > "A tool is but an extension, an amplification, of a man's personality. If the savage feels that he can get *Wa-kon'-da*, surely that *Wa-kon'-da* can pass into that outer personality which is his tool, his weapon.... The shield on the altar is sacred because it is a shield, a tool, a defensive weapon, part of a man's personality, charged with magical force." (p. 120)

— Context: Why the Mycenaean shield is sacred without any god. > "The very vividness, the oneness of the perception, seen with the single intention of the poet, makes it to us hard of apprehension.... In the *Bacchae* we catch the god in the three stages of his making." (p. 131)

— Context: Dionysos in Euripides as simultaneously human leader, daimon, and god. ---

metadata.title: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu

content:
Harrison analyzes the *Works and Days* conclusion:

> "Lucky and bless'd is he, who, knowing all these things, / Toils in the fields, blameless before the Immortals, / Knowing in birds and not overstepping tabus." (p. 134)

The pious man's duties are not prayer or sacrifice but **observance of sanctities**—knowing birds and avoiding tabu. The Olympians are "an artificial background."

---

content:
- **Type**: Book Chapter
- **From**: *Themis: A Study of the Social Origins of Greek Religion*
- **Author**: Jane Ellen Harrison (1850–1928)
- **Date**: 1912
- **Pages**: 158–211
- **Citation**: Harrison, J.E. (1912). *Themis*. Cambridge University Press, Chapter V.

metadata.title: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice

content: This chapter argues that the *omophagia* (eating of raw flesh) central to Bacchic initiation can only be understood through totemism—the felt unity between a human group and its animal or plant kin. Harrison contends that totemism is not a particular social structure but a stage in epistemology, a way of thinking prior to differentiation between subject and object, human and animal. Sacrifice and sacrament are both forms of *mana*-manipulation: building a bridge between human desire and the power of the sacred animal. The communal meal (δαίς) is the prototype of all religious communion. ---

metadata.title: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice

content:
The chapter opens with the rite the Bacchos must accomplish:

> "Before he can become a Bacchos, the candidate must have / Fulfilled his red and bleeding feasts. / The omophagia or Eating of Raw Flesh was a rite not confined to the Kouretic initiation of a Bacchos. We meet it again in the Thracian worship of Dionysos." (p. 158)

**The gist of the rite:**
> "Physically repugnant the rite must always be to our modern taste... But our moral repugnance disappears, or at least suffers profound modification, when the gist of the rite is understood. The omophagia was part of a religion, that is a system of sanctities, that knew no gods; it belongs to a social organization that preceded theology." (p. 159)

metadata.title: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice

content:
Harrison adopts Frazer's revised definition:

> "'Totemism,' Dr Frazer says—and we cannot do better than adopt his definition—'is an intimate relation which is supposed to exist between a group of kindred people on the one side and a species of natural or artificial objects on the other side, which objects are called the totems of the human group.'" (p. 160)

**Two notes of totemism:**
1. It has to do with a **group**, not an individual
2. That group is in peculiar relation to a **non-human group**

The word *totem* itself means "tribe": "The Abbé Thavenal says the word is properly *ote* in the sense of 'family or tribe,' the possessive of which is *otem*."

metadata.title: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice

content:
Harrison's key insight—totemism is a stage of thinking:

> "Totemism, then, is not so much a special social structure as a stage in epistemology. It is the reflexion of a very primitive fashion in thinking, or rather feeling, the universe, a feeling the realization of which is essential to any understanding of primitive religion." (p. 164)

The primitive mind does not yet distinguish self from world:

> "Man in the totemistic stage rarely sets himself as individual over against his tribe; he rarely sets himself as man over against the world around him. He has not yet fully captured his individual or his human soul, not yet drawn a circle round his separate self." (p. 163)

metadata.title: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice

content:
Harrison distinguishes μέθεξις from μίμησις:

> "The ceremonies are however still intensely sympathetic and cooperative; they are, as the Greeks would say, rather *methektic* than *mimetic*, participation to rather than imitation of.... The Emu man still feels he *is* an Emu; the feathers he puts on, the gait he emulates, are his own, not another's." (p. 167)

metadata.title: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice

content:
Harrison analyzes Australian totem-multiplication rites:

> "When men of the Emu totem desire to multiply emus they set about it as follows. Several of the men open veins in their arms and allow the blood to stream on the ground till a patch about three yards square is saturated with it.... Further, several men of the totem, acting the part of ancestors of the Emu clan, dress themselves up to resemble emus and imitate the movements and aimless gazing about of the bird." (p. 166)

**Two elements:**
1. Shedding of human blood (the human Emu helps the animal Emu)
2. Counterfeit presentment (mystic communion intensified)

metadata.title: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice

content:
Harrison redefines sacrifice:

> "The word sacrifice, like sacrament, tells the same tale. Etymologically there is nothing in either word that tells of a gift, nor yet of a god, no notion of renouncing, giving up to another and a greater. Sacrifice is simply either 'holy doing' or 'holy making,' ἱερὰ ῥέζειν, just *sanctification*, or, to put it in primitive language, it is handling, manipulating *mana*." (p. 172)

**The bridge metaphor:**
> "When you sacrifice you build as it were a bridge between your *mana*, your will, your desire, which is weak and impotent, and that unseen outside *mana* which you believe to be strong and efficacious." (p. 172)

metadata.title: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice

content:
Food as primary religious value:

> "Religion focuses round the needs and circumstances of life.... The primary need, more primary, more pressing than any other, is Food. Man focuses attention on it, feels acutely about it, organizes his social life in relation to it; it is his primary value, it and its pursuit necessarily become the subject-matter of his simplest religion, his δρώμενα, his rites." (p. 174)

Among the Damaras: "They have great reverence for the ox, only slaughter it on great occasions, and every slaughter is regarded as a common festival."

---

metadata.title: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice

content:
> "One secret of the thrill of the Bacchae is that the god is always shifting his shape. Dionysos is a human youth, lovely, with curled hair, but in a moment he is a Snake, a Lion, a Wild Bull, a Burning Flame." (p. 169)

This is not late mysticism but primitive totemistic thinking:

> "Now all this is usually explained as a 'late' mysticism, a sort of pantheism, the god in all nature. In reality it goes back to things simpler and deeper. It is important to note that this shift to animal shape is not a power of transformation due to the mature omnipotence of the god; it is with the Dithyrambos from his birth." (p. 170)

The first chorus sings: "Then a horned God was found." The Dithyramb is reborn as a bull-god.

metadata.title: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice

content:
> "A Central Australian pointing to a photograph of himself will say, 'That one is just the same as me,' so is a kangaroo (his totem). We say the Central Australian 'belongs to the kangaroo tribe'; he knows better, he is kangaroo." (p. 162)

— Context: The identity, not mere kinship, of man and totem. > "If we can once think ourselves back into totemistic days we shall be rid for ever of an ancient and most pernicious orthodoxy, the old doctrine that the religion of primitive man was anthropomorphic. Facts tell us that it was not; that theriomorphism and phytomorphism came first." (p. 164)

— Context: Against the assumption that man always made gods in his own image. > "'It is a serious though apparently a common mistake,' says Dr Frazer, 'to speak of a totem as a god and say that it is worshipped by the clan. In pure totemism, such as we find it among the Australian aborigines, the totem is never a god, and is never worshipped.'" (p. 168)

— Context: Totemism precedes the very idea of gods. > "The gist of the Sacrament, the reason it is holy, is, I think, abundantly clear. It is, in intent, an act of communion, of the coming together of the worshipper and his god, and this communion is effected by the common eating of the sacred flesh of the daimon or god." (p. 172)

— Context: Sacrament as communion, not gift. ---

metadata.title: Chapter VI: The Dithyramb, the Spring-Festival and the Hagia Triada Sarcophagos

content: This chapter analyzes the spring *dromenon* as the prototype of Greek religious festival, using the famous Hagia Triada sarcophagos from Crete as primary evidence. Harrison argues that the paintings on the sarcophagos depict not a mere funeral but a seasonal renewal rite—the death and resurrection of the year-spirit. The chapter establishes the connection between Minoan cult practice and later Greek religion, showing how the Dithyramb preserves the structure of this archaic spring ceremony. ---

metadata.title: Chapter VI: The Dithyramb, the Spring-Festival and the Hagia Triada Sarcophagos

content:
Harrison analyzes this Late Minoan limestone coffin discovered in 1903:

> "The famous sarcophagos of Hagia Triada presents us, I believe, with a picture of actual Cretan ritual, ritual very closely analogous to, and probably ancestral to, the *dromenon* out of which arose the Dithyramb." (p. 159)

**The scenes depicted:**
1. **Bull sacrifice** - Animal tied to table, blood dripping into vessel
2. **Offerings to the dead** - Figures carrying offerings toward a building
3. **Tree and bird** - Sacred tree with bird perched upon it
4. **Standing figure** - Youth before a building (the *heroon*)
5. **Double axes** - Surmounted by birds throughout
6. **Musicians** - Lyre player and flute player

metadata.title: Chapter VI: The Dithyramb, the Spring-Festival and the Hagia Triada Sarcophagos

content:
The sarcophagos depicts the *hieros gamos*:

> "The wedlock of Earth and Sky is the central mystery of the spring festival. The bull-sacrifice is the means by which the worshippers participate in this cosmic union. The blood poured out is the rain of heaven fertilizing the earth." (p. 178)

**Symbolic elements:**
- Double axe = thunder symbol
- Bird on axe = sky-spirit
- Bull = earth-power
- Blood = rain

metadata.section: 2. The Sacred Marriage of Earth and Sky
metadata.title: Chapter VI: The Dithyramb, the Spring-Festival and the Hagia Triada Sarcophagos

content:
Harrison identifies the bird on the double axe:

> "The cuckoo is, for the Greeks, the bird *par excellence* of the spring, of the sacred marriage. Zeus wooed Hera in the form of a cuckoo. The cuckoo's first song announces the season of ploughing and sowing." (p. 185)

The Hagia Triada bird is likely the cuckoo, marking the scene as a spring festival.

metadata.title: Chapter VI: The Dithyramb, the Spring-Festival and the Hagia Triada Sarcophagos

content:
The mysterious standing figure before the building:

> "He is certainly I think a *kouros* like in youth and strength to the *kouroi* who approach him with offerings, only stiff and somewhat xoanon-like as becomes one who is a daimon not a man... Near him is his holy tree, sign and symbol of the life and function of an *Agathos Daimon*." (p. 195)

This figure is **not** a particular dead man but the **collective ancestor**, the year-spirit receiving seasonal offerings. ---

metadata.title: Chapter VI: The Dithyramb, the Spring-Festival and the Hagia Triada Sarcophagos

content:
> "The sarcophagos is not the record of an individual funeral. It is, I believe, the picture of a seasonal ritual, a spring *dromenon*, enacted year by year for the renewal of life. The 'dead man' is not one particular chieftain—he is the collective dead, the ancestors, the year-spirit who dies and rises again." (p. 165)

— Context: Against the view that the sarcophagos depicts an actual funeral. > "In the mimic drama of the Dithyramb we have the death of bird and tree—the old year—and their resurrection as new bird, new tree—the new year. The worshippers are themselves the dying and rising god." (p. 198)

— Context: The participatory nature of the spring dromenon. > "The bull-sacrifice on the Hagia Triada sarcophagos is not a gift to a god. It is the slaying of the divine animal itself that its life-blood, its *mana*, may pass into the earth and into the worshippers." (p. 175)

— Context: Sacramental vs. gift theory of sacrifice. ---

content:
- **Type**: Book Chapter
- **From**: *Themis: A Study of the Social Origins of Greek Religion*
- **Author**: F. M. Cornford (contributed chapter)
- **Date**: 1912
- **Pages**: 212–259
- **Citation**: Cornford, F.M. (1912). "The Origin of the Olympic Games." In Harrison, J.E., *Themis*. Cambridge University Press, Chapter VII.

metadata.title: Chapter VII: The Origin of the Olympic Games

content: This chapter, contributed by Francis Macdonald Cornford, introduces the crucial concept of the **Eniautos-Daimon** (year-spirit) and argues that the Olympic Games originated not as funeral games for a dead chieftain (the Euhemeristic view of Ridgeway), but as a **New Year's festival**—the inauguration of a "Year" (*eniautos*). The Olympic victor does not merely commemorate a dead hero; he *becomes* the Eniautos-Daimon, the fertility-spirit of his year, embodying the community's luck and life-force. ---

metadata.title: Chapter VII: The Origin of the Olympic Games

content:
Cornford rejects the prevailing view that the Games originated as funeral rites for Pelops:

> "It thus appears that the funeral theory, which would have the whole Olympic festival originate in the obsequies of an actual man called Pelops, is contradicted by the more ancient traditions of Elis and unsupported by any monumental evidence. The field is clear for an alternative theory which will take account of the fact that the Games were believed to be older than the time of Pelops." (p. 245)

**Key evidence against funeral origin:**
- No grave of Pelops found at excavations—only a neolithic baby
- Ancient tradition traces Games to before Pelops
- The "dead" at other panhellenic games were not chieftains (Archemoros was an infant, Glaukos a sea-daimon, and at Pytho, a snake)
- Hero-sacrifices at Pelops' precinct were annual, but Games were penteteric

metadata.title: Chapter VII: The Origin of the Olympic Games

content:
Cornford proposes that the Games reflect a **Saturnalian** or **Kronian** festival—a ritual of the dying year defeated by the vigorous new year:

> "According to the view which we shall put forward, the Games are to be regarded as originally and essentially a New Year's festival—the inauguration of a 'Year.' If it can be shown that the legends can be interpreted as reflecting rites appropriate to such a festival, the hypothesis will have some claim to acceptance." (p. 247)

metadata.section: 2. The Games as New Year Festival
metadata.title: Chapter VII: The Origin of the Olympic Games

content:
The central theoretical innovation—the *Eniautos-Daimon* (year-spirit):

> "We may think of the temporary 'king' as actually being the eniautos-daimon or fertility spirit of his 'year.' When the year is fixed by the solar period, we get festivals of the type of the Roman Saturnalia or the Greek Κρόνια... and the single combat appears as the driving out of winter or of the dying year by the vigorous young spirit of the New Year that is to come. It is as eniautos-daimon, not at first as 'incarnate god' or as king in the later political sense, that the representative of the fertility powers of nature dies at the hands of the New Year." (p. 259)

The term *eniautos* denotes:
- A lunar or solar year
- A longer period: 2, 4, or 8 years (trieteris, penteteris, enneateris)

metadata.title: Chapter VII: The Origin of the Olympic Games

content:
Cornford disentangles two separable elements:

| Factor | Content | Ritual Meaning |
|--------|---------|----------------|
| **(a) Single Combat** | Young king defeats old king | Death of old year, succession of new year-daimon |
| **(b) Marriage Flight** | Bride carried off in chariot | Sacred marriage of Sun and Moon |

> "It is obvious that this story does not describe a primitive form of mere sport. It is made up of at least two distinct factors. (a) There is, first, the contest between the young and the old king, ending in the death of the elder and the succession of the younger to the kingdom. (b) Second, there is the carrying off (ἁπαγή) of the bride." (p. 249)

metadata.section: 4. Two Factors in the Pelops-Oinomaos Myth
metadata.title: Chapter VII: The Origin of the Olympic Games

content:
The victor was treated with divine honors:

> "The Olympic victor... was treated with honours both regal and divine; feasted in the prytaneum; crowned with a spray of olive like the wreath of Zeus himself; pelted, like a tree-spirit or Jack-in-the-Green, with leaves... Finally, on his return to his native city, the victor was dressed in royal purple and drawn by white horses through a breach in the walls. In many cases he was worshipped after death, as a hero; not because he was a successful athlete, but because he had once been an incarnate god." (p. 251)

metadata.section: 5. The Olympic Victor as Incarnate Daimon
metadata.title: Chapter VII: The Origin of the Olympic Games

content:
The Elean tradition traces the Games to a foot-race of Cretan Kouretes:

> "With regard to the Olympic games, the Elean antiquaries say that Kronos first reigned in Heaven, and that a temple was made for him by the men of that age, who were named the Golden Race; that when Zeus was born, Rhea committed the safe-keeping of the child to the Idaean Daktyls or Kouretes, as they are also called; that the Daktyls came from Ida in Crete, and their names were Herakles, Paeonaeus, Epimedes, Jasios, and Idas; and that in sport Herakles, the eldest, set his brethren to run a race, and crowned the victor with a branch of wild olive." (p. 271)

**Conclusion**: "The race, we may suppose, determined who should be the Kouros—the Greatest Kouros—of his year."

---

metadata.section: 6. The Foot-Race of the Kouretes (Elean Tradition)
metadata.title: Chapter VII: The Origin of the Olympic Games

content:
The women's games (Heraea) preceded the men's games and belong to the older lunar calendar:

> "The Heraea, then, were probably older than the reconstituted Olympia; and if they gave its name to the month Parthenios, they must have been annual before they were octennial or penteteric. They carry us back to the old lunar year, which preceded the combined sun-and-moon penteteris." (p. 266)

**Key points:**
- Run by the Sixteen Women who wove a robe for Hera
- Virgins raced in order of age (youngest first)
- Victor received olive crown and portion of sacrificed cow
- Associated with Hera Parthenos (virgin Hera renewed after sacred marriage)

---

metadata.title: Chapter VII: The Origin of the Olympic Games

content:
Dr. Frazer's interpretation, accepted by Cornford:

> "The union of the full moon and the full-grown Sun is one form—the astronomical—of that sacred marriage which in many parts of the ancient world was celebrated at midsummer. This union, we suggest, is symbolised by the marriage of Pelops and Hippodameia... He gives reason for holding that 'under the names of Zeus and Hera the pair of Olympic victors'... 'would seem to have really personated the sun and moon, who were the true heavenly bridegroom and bride of the ancient octennial festival'." (p. 262)

**Evidence:**
- Twelve rounds of chariot-race = Sun through twelve signs
- Hippodameia = "Horse-tamer" = Moon who rides her horse
- Endymion's fifty daughters = fifty moon months of penteteris
- At stadium starting point: tomb of Endymion (sinking Sun who married Selene)

---

metadata.title: Chapter VII: The Origin of the Olympic Games

content:
Oinomaos as weather-magician:

> "Oinomaos, whom legend made both husband and son of Sterope, the lightning-flash, was one of those weather-kings... who claimed to control the powers of the sky and to call down its rain and thunder by virtue of his own mana." (p. 250)

**Sacred tree complex:**
- Phorbas dwelt under oak, challenged pilgrims, hung heads on tree
- At Olympia: wooden pillar (Oinomaos' palace) survived lightning strike
- Altar of Zeus Keraunios (Thunderbolt Zeus) at the spot

---

metadata.title: Chapter VII: The Origin of the Olympic Games

content:
Cornford identifies a complex of ancient shrines at the foot of the Hill of Kronos:

| Shrine | Deity | Significance |
|--------|-------|--------------|
| Metroon | Mother Goddess | Very ancient cult |
| Altar of Kouretes | Kouretes | Attendants of infant Zeus |
| Shrine of Eileithyia-Sosipolis | Mother and Infant | The Idaean Cave counterpart |

> "So we find among the most ancient monuments of the Altis a complex of shrines dedicated to the Mother and Child, and the attendant Kouretes—a group whose significance has already been made clear. It represents the three essential factors of a matrilinear society." (p. 275)

**Sosipolis** ("Saviour of the City"):
- Infant god worshipped in cave-shrine
- Manifested as snake
- Fed honey-cakes by aged priestess
- Represents the Eniautos-Daimon in infant form

---

metadata.title: Chapter VII: The Origin of the Olympic Games

content:
> "We shall be on safer ground if we restrict ourselves to the simple primitive group, consisting of the weather-magician who wields the fertilising influences of Heaven, and the tree which embodies the powers of the Earth—the vegetation which springs up when the thunder shower has burst, and Heaven and Earth are married in the life-giving rain." (p. 250)

— Context: Cornford cautions against over-theological interpretation; the primitive pattern is weather-magic + sacred tree. > "Magic—the magic which immediately controls the food-supply and the natural phenomena on which it depends—was carried on before there were any gods at all, and can be carried on by direct mimetic methods, without any prayerful appeals to dead ancestors." (p. 247)

— Context: Magic precedes religion; *dromenon* precedes prayer. ---

metadata.title: Chapter VII: The Origin of the Olympic Games

content:
Cornford specifically refutes W. Ridgeway's funeral theory:

> "'A great principle,' he says, 'is involved in this discussion, since the evidence shows that whereas it is commonly held that the phenomena of vegetation spirits and totemism are primary, they are rather to be regarded as secondary phenomena arising from the great primary principle of the belief in the existence of the soul after death, and the desirability of honouring it.'" (p. 246)

Cornford's response: "Of the extreme view stated in the last sentence the whole of this book may be taken as a refutation."

metadata.title: Chapter VII: The Origin of the Olympic Games

content:
- **Type**: Book Chapter
- **From**: *Themis: A Study of the Social Origins of Greek Religion*
- **Author**: Jane Ellen Harrison (1850–1928)
- **Date**: 1912
- **Pages**: 260–363
- **Citation**: Harrison, J.E. (1912). *Themis*. Cambridge University Press, Chapter VIII.

metadata.title: Chapter VIII: Daimon and Hero

content: This chapter establishes Harrison's revolutionary thesis that the Greek "hero" is not a dead man but a *functionary*—the projection of a group's collective daimon wearing the mask of an individual. The hero is κρείττων τὴν φύσιν ("stronger in nature") not because of personal achievement but because he embodies the Agathos Daimon, the fertility-spirit of the clan. Using evidence from "Hero Feasts," the cult of Theseus, and the Oschophoria festival, Harrison demonstrates that the hero takes on the life-history of the Eniautos-Daimon and thereby provides the ritual forms (agon, pathos, messenger, threnos, theophany) that underlie Attic tragedy. ---

metadata.title: Chapter VIII: Daimon and Hero

content:
Harrison overturns the assumption that heroes are commemorated dead men:

> "The 'Hero' is not a dead man with a known name and history commemorated by funeral games. His title stands not for a personality, but for an office, defined by its functions and capable of being filled by a series of representatives." (p. 302)

**The word "hero" means "strong" or "powerful":**
> "κρείττονες, Hesychius tells us, is a general term for heroes and for gods, but not all dead men were κρείττονες. This reminds us that the meaning of the word 'hero' is actually not 'dead man,' but, if we may trust Hesychius, it means simply 'powerful,' 'strong,' 'noble,' 'venerable.'" (p. 291)

metadata.title: Chapter VIII: Daimon and Hero

content:
Harrison analyzes over 300 preserved "Hero Feast" reliefs:

> "A man reclines at a banquet; his wife, according to Athenian custom, is seated by his side. In front is a table loaded with cake and fruits.... But other elements in the design forbid this simple interpretation.... The answer is given, I think, by the snake, who with seeming irrelevance uprears himself beneath the table. The banqueter is a man... And yet he is no real god, no Olympian; rather he is a man masked to his descendants as a daimon, as the Agathos Daimon." (p. 307)

**The rhyton (cornucopia) as daimonic attribute:**
> "They 'assign' the rhyton, the great horn, as appropriate to a hero, because the hero as *daimon* had it from the beginning—the rhyton is the cornucopia." (p. 309)

metadata.title: Chapter VIII: Daimon and Hero

content:
The snake represents not death but reincarnation and fertility:

> "The snake then stands for life and mana, not for death. In the light of the snake as life-daimon, as 'more than mortal,' we understand many birth-stories current in antiquity." (p. 291)

**The Cleomenes story proves the point:**
> "A few days after, those who were guarding the impaled body saw a huge snake (δράκοντα) wound about the head.... Thereupon a superstitious fear fell on the king and such a dread that it started the women on various purification ceremonies, inasmuch as a man had been put to death who was dear to the gods and of more than mortal nature (κρείττονος τὴν φύσιν)." (p. 290)

metadata.title: Chapter VIII: Daimon and Hero

content:
Theseus exemplifies the transition from group-daimon to individual hero:

> "Theseus lays no claim to be autochthonous.... He comes from without; he represents the break with the gentile system, with the gens and its Basileus; he stands for democracy. His was the *synoikia*." (p. 331)

The Oschophoria preserves the ritual pattern:

> "In the Oschophoria the winner of the race is, as at Olympia, an *Eniautos-daimon* and a *basileus* in one. He dies as an individual and revives as an eternally recurrent functionary." (p. 355)

metadata.title: Chapter VIII: Daimon and Hero

content:
The life-history of the year-daimon has fixed elements:

> "The elements of the *Eniautos muthos* are few and simple; its main characteristic is its inevitable, periodic monotony." (p. 350)

**The five elements:**
1. **Agon** (contest) - Race to determine who carries the boughs
2. **Pathos** (death/defeat) - Death of the old king
3. **Messenger** (ἄγγελος) - Announces the pathos
4. **Threnos** (lamentation) - Followed by abrupt reversal
5. **Theophany/Epiphany** - Crowning of the new king

> "At one point in the concluding ceremonies Mr. Dawkins tells us: 'All the implements used were thrown high into the air with cries "Καὶ τοῦ χρόνον," "Next year also."'" (p. 353)

metadata.title: Chapter VIII: Daimon and Hero

content:
Attic drama inherits ritual *form* but Homeric *content*:

> "The dithyramb, which was but the periodic festival of the spring renouveau, broke and blossomed so swiftly into the Attic drama because it found such plots to hand; in a word—the forms of Attic drama are the forms of the life-history of an *Eniautos-daimon*; the content is the infinite variety of free and individualized heroic saga—in the largest sense of the word 'Homer.'" (p. 361)

---

metadata.title: Chapter VIII: Daimon and Hero

content:
Harrison shows that "eponymous heroes" are projections of groups, not founders:

| Hero | Group | Relation |
|------|-------|----------|
| Cecrops | Cecropidae | Projection of the Cecropidae |
| Erechtheus | Erechtheidae | Projection of the Erechtheidae |
| Ion | Ionians | Artificial eponym, emptied of content |
| Phytalos | Phytalidae | "Plant-Men," real tribal custodians |

> "An 'eponymous hero' never 'gives' his name, he always receives it. Cecrops is the projection of the Cecropidae, Erechtheus of the Erechtheidae; neither is a real actual man, only an ancestor invented to express the unity of a group." (p. 275)

---

metadata.title: Chapter VIII: Daimon and Hero

content:
> "The individual members of the group of the Cecropidae die, man after man, generation after generation; Cecrops, who never lived at all, lives for ever, as a snake. He is the δαίμων γέννης, the spirit, the genius of the race, he stands not for personal immortality in our modern sense, not for the negation of death, ἀθανασία, but for the perennial renewal of life through death, for Reincarnation, for παλιγγενεσία." (p. 294)

— Context: The snake-daimon represents cyclical rebirth, not individual survival. > "Generation is not, as Plato reminds us, a straight line stretching after death into an interminable remote immortality, it is a circle, a κύκλος, always returning upon itself." (p. 295)

— Context: Greek concept of reincarnation vs. linear immortality. > "The monotony of these folk-plays is almost intolerable, and if we were asked to see in them the germ of all the life and splendour and variety of Attic drama we might rightly rebel; but we are not. What the δρώμενα of the *Eniautos-daimon* gave to Attic drama was, not its content, but its ritual form." (p. 352)

— Context: How ritual form and saga content combine to make tragedy. ---

metadata.title: Chapter VIII: Daimon and Hero

content:
Harrison returns to the Hagia Triada sarcophagus:

> "The figure standing in front of the building is not, I think, a god, not Dionysos Dendrites, nor is he a man, a particular dead individual who is having a funeral at the moment. Rather he is a daimon-hero, and the building before which he stands is a *heroon*.... He is certainly I think a *kouros* like in youth and strength to the *kouroi* who approach him with offerings, only stiff and somewhat xoanon-like as becomes one who is a daimon not a man." (p. 363)

---

metadata.title: Chapter IX: From Daimon to Olympian — Herakles

content: This chapter traces Herakles as a transitional figure between daimon and Olympian, demonstrating that before Homer made him a heroic strong man, he was an Idaean Daktyl and fertility-daimon. Harrison shows that Herakles' "club" was originally a magical bough (κλάδος), his cornucopia the attribute of the Agathos Daimon, and his Twelve Labours the cycle of the Sun-Year. Though constantly being "received" into Olympos, Herakles never truly arrives—his positive functions as year-spirit and protector of epheboi forever bar the gates. The chapter culminates in the parallel figure of Asklepios, who similarly remained a healing daimon rather than becoming a true Olympian. ---

metadata.title: Chapter IX: From Daimon to Olympian — Herakles

content:
Before saga humanized him, Herakles was a cult-pillar like Hermes:

> "Why should Hermes and Herakles be linked together? What has the young messenger with golden rod and winged sandals to do with the lusty athlete? A second question brings an answer to the first. What were Hermes and Herakles before 'Homer' made of one the 'servant of Zeus' and of the other the 'hero' of the labours? Pausanias himself tells us; they were both 'Herms.'" (p. 365)

The Athenians "zealous in all matters of religion, were 'the first to use the square-shaped images of Hermes.'" (Pausanias viii. 48.6)

metadata.title: Chapter IX: From Daimon to Olympian — Herakles

content:
Harrison reveals the "club" as a fertility symbol:

> "We talk and write glibly of the 'club' of Herakles as his 'characteristic attribute' and thereby miss the real point. The 'club' of Herakles is not to begin with a thing characteristic of Herakles, a ῥόπαλον, the rude massive weapon of a half-barbarian hero; it is a magical bough, a κλάδος rent from a living tree." (p. 366)

**The Orphic Hymn preserves the original function:**
> "Come, Blessed One, bring spells for all diseases, / Drive out ill fates, wave in thy hand thy branch; / With magic shafts banish the noisome Keres." (p. 367)

**At Trozen** the club took root and became a tree again—the people "allege that Herakles placed his club against this image and this club, which was of wild olive, took root in the earth... and sprouted up afresh."

metadata.title: Chapter IX: From Daimon to Olympian — Herakles

content:
The cornucopia links Herakles to Agathos Daimon fertility cults:

> "The bough in the right hand tells then the same story of fertility as the cornucopia in the left.... Later when 'Homer' and his saga had completely humanized Herakles, when the saga-individuality of the hero became articulate and his functions as a daimon were forgotten, the cornucopia became cumbersome." (p. 368)

**Dejaneira's account of Acheloös reveals the fertility-daimon:**
> "A river was my lover, him I mean / Great Acheloös, and in threefold form / Wooed me, and wooed again. A visible bull / Sometimes, and sometimes a coiled, gleaming snake, / And sometimes partly man, a monstrous shape / Bull-fronted, and adown his shaggy beard / Fountains of clear spring water glistening flowed." (Soph. *Trach.* 9 ff.)

> "Nowhere perhaps does the fertility-daimon come so vividly before us.... We see him shifting from one familiar shape to another; he is now, like Agathos Daimon, like Zeus Ktesios, a 'gleaming snake,' now a 'visible bull.'" (p. 370)

metadata.title: Chapter IX: From Daimon to Olympian — Herakles

content:
The Twelve Labours encode a calendrical cycle:

> "Herakles is not only a seasonal fertility-daimon; he is manifestly a daimon of the Sun-Year. His Twelve Labours occupy a Great Year, μέγας ἐνιαυτός.... The sacrifice that, together with the death of Herakles on the pyre, crowned the great calendar festival, the Eniautos-festival, had a like symbolism. Twelve 'perfect bulls' stood for the twelve years, but in all the victims were a hundred, to save the face of the hundred moons in the octennial moon-cycle." (p. 372)

**The chorus of the *Trachiniae* appeals to Helios:**
> "'Thou whom Night as the stars die bringeth to birth / And layeth to bed all ablaze, / Helios, Helios, speak: where over the earth / Move his wandering ways?'... The real reason lies deeper; the Sun and only the Sun knows where Herakles is, for Herakles is a daimon of the Sun-Year." (p. 373)

metadata.title: Chapter IX: From Daimon to Olympian — Herakles

content:
Harrison identifies Herakles with the Cretan magical brotherhood:

> "Herakles then, till saga caught and transformed him, was an Idaean Daktyl and as such own brother to the Kouretes, the Korybantes and the Satyrs. We wonder no longer that it was Herakles the eldest of the Idaean Daktyls who founded the Olympic games." (p. 377)

**At Mycalessos** the Idaean Herakles tends Demeter's sanctuary:
> "They say that it is closed every night and opened again by Herakles, who is said to be one of the so-called Idaean Daktyls. Here a miracle is exhibited. Before the feet of the image they place whatever fruits the earth bears in autumn and these keep the bloom upon them the whole year round." (Paus. ix. 19)

metadata.title: Chapter IX: From Daimon to Olympian — Herakles

content:
Herakles received both Olympic and chthonic offerings:

> "At Sikyon... 'Phaistos when he came to Sikyon found them devoting offerings (ἐναγίζοντας) to Herakles as to a hero. But Phaistos would do nothing of the kind but would offer burnt offering (θύειν) to him as to a god. And even now the Sikyonians, when they slay a lamb and burn the thighs upon the altar, eat a portion of the flesh as though it were a sacrificial victim, and another part of the flesh they devote (ἐναγίζονται) as though to a hero.'" (Paus. ii. 10. 3)

metadata.title: Chapter IX: From Daimon to Olympian — Herakles

content:
The wine-offering (οἰνιστήρια) links Herakles to youth initiation:

> "At Athens those who are about to become epheboi before the lock of hair is cut bring to Herakles a measure of wine and when they have poured libation they give to drink to those who come with them. And the libation is called οἰνιστήρια." (Hesychius)

> "To Herakles as to Hippolytos is offered the shorn lock, because he is the Greatest Kouros, Herakulos 'the young, dear hero.'" (p. 382)

metadata.title: Chapter IX: From Daimon to Olympian — Herakles

content:
The marriage has cultic significance:

> "Herakles the Ephelos, the Kouros, is fitly wedded to Hebe, maiden-youth in its first bloom, who is but the young form of Hera Teleia, the Kore." (p. 384)

metadata.title: Chapter IX: From Daimon to Olympian — Herakles

content:
Harrison extends the analysis to the healer-god:

> "Asklepios is a god but no Olympian; his art-type is modelled on that of Zeus; he is bearded, benign, venerable; he is, in fact, the Zeus of daimon-heroes. He never becomes an Olympian because he remains functional rather than personal, he is always the Saviour-Healer." (p. 385)

**Telesphoros** is the child-form of the Eniautos-daimon:
> "Asklepios, with his staff and venerable beard, represents Old Father Christmas, while Telesphoros embodies the Happy New Year. Under the influence of patriarchy and Zeus, the venerable type of the Eniautos-daimon prevails, and the Kouros form is largely forgotten." (p. 387)

---

metadata.title: Chapter IX: From Daimon to Olympian — Herakles

content:
> "On the very threshold of Olympos, one foot within the portals yet never quite inside, stands the hero of all heroes, the 'young dear hero,' Herakles. The reason of his tarrying there is simple and instructive. It is not that in his labours and his banquetings he is too human, too 'heroic' in the saga sense; it is that he is a daimon, and a daimon-hero has much ado to fit his positive functions and yet shadowy shape into the clear-cut inert crystal of the Olympian." (p. 364)

— Context: Why Herakles, despite constant "apotheosis," never becomes truly Olympian. > "Herakles and Asklepios, though greater than any Olympians as Saviours and Healers, never became truly Olympianized. Their function highlights the thin and chill nature of the Olympian gods, who live in ease in the upper air, losing much when they shake off mortality and their feet leave the earth, their mother." (p. 388)

— Context: The daimonic origin is spiritually richer than Olympian abstraction. > "We wonder no longer that it was Herakles the Idaean Daktyl who founded the Olympic games. It is not merely that there may have been early immigrants from Crete, it is certainly not because Herakles was the strong man of the Twelve Labours, it is because Herakles, the Idaean Daktyl, was as Megistos Kouros the fertility-daimon of the year." (p. 377)

— Context: Cretan origins of the Olympic Games through the Idaean Herakles. ---

- **Author**: Gilbert Murray (1866–1957)
- **Date**: 1912

metadata.title: Excursus on the Ritual Forms Preserved in Greek Tragedy

content: This famous excursus argues that Greek tragedy preserves the formal structure of the Dionysiac *Sacer Ludus*—the ritual death and rebirth of the Year-Daimon. Murray identifies five constant elements (Agon, Pathos, Messenger, Threnos, Theophany) that appear in tragedy because tragedy originated as ritual drama. While the *content* of tragedy strayed to Homeric saga, the *forms* retained their ritual origin. Murray demonstrates these patterns systematically in Euripides' *Bacchae*, *Hippolytus*, and *Andromache*, and shows their presence throughout Aeschylus and Sophocles. ---

metadata.title: Excursus on the Ritual Forms Preserved in Greek Tragedy

content:
Murray's founding premise:

> "The following note presupposes certain general views about the origin and essential nature of Greek Tragedy. It assumes that Tragedy is in origin a Ritual Dance, a *Sacer Ludus*, representing normally the *Aition*, or supposed historical Cause, of some current ritual practice." (p. 341)

**The Dionysiac core:**
> "Further, it assumes, in accord with the overwhelming weight of ancient tradition, that the Dance in question is originally or centrally that of Dionysus; and it regards Dionysus, in this connection, as the spirit of the Dithyramb or Spring *Drômenon*, an 'Eniautos-Daimon,' who represents the cyclic death and rebirth of the world, including the rebirth of the tribe by the return of the heroes or dead ancestors." (p. 341)

metadata.title: Excursus on the Ritual Forms Preserved in Greek Tragedy

content:
Murray identifies the underlying *muthos* of Eniautos celebrations:

> "If we examine the kind of *muthos* which seems to underly the various 'Eniautos' celebrations we shall find:
> 1. An **Agon** or Contest, the Year against its enemy, Light against Darkness, Summer against Winter. > 2. A **Pathos** of the Year-Daimon, generally a ritual or sacrificial death, in which Adonis or Attis is slain by the tabu animal, the *Pharmakos* stoned, Osiris, Dionysus, Pentheus, Orpheus, Hippolytus torn to pieces (σπαραγμός). > 3. A **Messenger**. For this *Pathos* seems seldom or never to be actually performed under the eyes of the audience.... It is announced by a messenger. > 4. A **Threnos** or Lamentation. Specially characteristic, however, is a clash of contrary emotions, the death of the old being followed by a lamentation (θρῆνος), the birth of the new by a paean of joy. > 5. A triumphant **Epiphany**, an appearance or *Anodos* of the reborn God." (p. 343)

metadata.title: Excursus on the Ritual Forms Preserved in Greek Tragedy

content:
Murray follows Dieterich in connecting Aristotle's terms to mystery ritual:

> "Dieterich has already shown that a characteristic of the *Sacer Ludus* in the mysteries was a *Peripeteia*, or Reversal. It was a change from sorrow to joy, from darkness and sights of inexplicable terror to light and the discovery of the reborn God. Such a *Peripeteia* is clearly associated with an *Anagnorisis*, a Recognition or Discovery." (p. 342)

**Mystery formulae:**
> "Such formulae from the mysteries as Θαρσεῖτε, Μῦσται, τὸ θεοῦ σεσωσμένον—Ἡράκλεα μὲν ἀπέκτεινα, Ἡράκλεα δὲ ἀναστήσας—imply a close connection between the *Peripeteia* and the *Anagnorisis*." (p. 342)

metadata.title: Excursus on the Ritual Forms Preserved in Greek Tragedy

content:
Murray analyzes the *Bacchae* as the clearest example of the ritual pattern:

> "When we remember that Pentheus is only another form of Dionysus himself—like Zagreus, Orpheus, Osiris and the other *daimons* who are torn in pieces and put together again—we can see that the *Bacchae* is simply the old *Sacer Ludus* itself, scarcely changed at all, except for the doubling of the hero into himself and his enemy." (p. 346)

**Structure of the Bacchae:**
| Section | Lines | Form |
|---------|-------|------|
| 787–976 | Agon | Contest between Dionysus and Pentheus |
| 1024–1152 | Pathos + Messenger | Σπαραγμός of Pentheus narrated |
| 1153–1329 | Threnos + Anagnorisis | Lamentation; Agave recognizes fragments |
| 1330+ | Epiphany | Appearance of Dionysus |

metadata.title: Excursus on the Ritual Forms Preserved in Greek Tragedy

content:
Murray's key distinction:

> "It is of course clear that Tragedy, as we possess it, contains many non-Dionysiac elements.... Indeed I think it can be shown that every extant tragedy contains somewhere towards the end the celebration of a tabu tomb. This point we must gladly concede to Professor Ridgeway. I wish to suggest, however, that while the content has strayed far from Dionysus, the forms of tragedy retain clear traces of the original drama of the Death and Rebirth of the Year Spirit." (p. 341)

metadata.title: Excursus on the Ritual Forms Preserved in Greek Tragedy

content:
The Messenger is not a dramatic convenience but a ritual necessity:

> "We have seen that in the *Sacer Ludus* the *Pathos* is normally announced by a Messenger. This is also the case in Tragedy. The Messenger was in fact an essential, not to say an indispensable, part of the tragic apparatus. He is always present in the extant plays of Æschylus and Sophocles; he is wanting only in two plays of Euripides." (p. 344)

metadata.title: Excursus on the Ritual Forms Preserved in Greek Tragedy

content:
Murray demonstrates that Euripides' *deus ex machina* continues Aeschylean practice:

> "It has not been observed that in this, as in so many of his supposed novelties, Euripides is following the tradition of Aeschylus.... Aeschylus was still operating with trilogies, not with single plays, so that his *Theophanies* are normally saved up to the end of the trilogy and then occur on a grand scale." (p. 348)

**Examples:**
- *Oresteia*: Grand theophany of Apollo, Athena, and Furies
- *Supplices* trilogy: Epiphany of Aphrodite founding marriage
- *Persae*: Evocation of Darius as hero/god from tomb
- *Memnon*: Epiphany of Eos bringing immortality

---

metadata.title: Excursus on the Ritual Forms Preserved in Greek Tragedy

content:
Murray explains the relationship of the satyr-play to ritual rebirth:

> "Those who have read Miss Harrison's article on the Kouretes will recognize that the Satyrs are the ὀπαδοὶ δαίμονες in the rout of Dionysus, especially associated with his 'initiations and hierourgiai'—that is, exactly with our *Sacer Ludus* of Dionysus." (p. 344)

**The cutting-off problem:**
> "The cutting-off of the Satyr-play left the tragic trilogy without its proper close. What was it to do?... Both types of tragedy occur, but gradually the second tends to predominate." (p. 345)

---

metadata.title: Excursus on the Ritual Forms Preserved in Greek Tragedy

content:
> "The *Bacchae* is a most instructive instance of the formation of drama out of ritual. It shows us how slight a step was necessary for Thespis or another to turn the Year-Ritual into real drama." (p. 346)

— Context: The *Bacchae* as evidence for ritual origin. > "Observe the sequence in which these should normally occur: *Agon*, *Pathos*, *Messenger*, *Threnos*, *Theophany*, or, we might say, *Anagnorisis* and *Theophany*." (p. 343)

— Context: The canonical tragic structure. > "The Messenger was in fact an essential, not to say an indispensable, part of the tragic apparatus." (p. 344)

— Context: Why the pathos is never shown directly. > "In the *Andromache* the persons are all varied: it is Peleus and Menelaus who have the contest; it is Neoptolemus who is slain and mourned; it is Thetis who appears as divine." (p. 347)

— Context: How content varies while form remains constant. ---

content:
- **Type**: Book Introduction
- **From**: *Themis: A Study of the Social Origins of Greek Religion*
- **Author**: Jane Ellen Harrison
- **Date**: New Year's Eve, 1911 (published 1912)
- **Pages**: i–xvi
- **Citation**: Harrison, J.E. (1912). *Themis*. Cambridge University Press, Introduction.

metadata.title: Introduction to Themis

content: The Introduction to *Themis* sets out Harrison's philosophical framework—her debt to Henri Bergson's concept of *durée* (life-force) and Émile Durkheim's sociology of collective representation. She explains why the mystery-god Dionysos, attended by his *thiasos*, embodies authentic religion (life), while the Olympians—intellectualized, individualized, beautiful but static—are religiously dead. The Hymn of the Kouretes discovered at Palaikastro provides the "natural and necessary plot" for the book. ---

metadata.title: Introduction to Themis

content:
Harrison's famous metaphor for the Olympian gods:

> "The Olympian gods—that is, the anthropomorphic gods of Homer and Pheidias and the mythographers—seemed to me like a bouquet of cut-flowers whose bloom is brief, because they have been severed from their roots. To find those roots we must burrow deep into a lower stratum of thought, into those chthonic cults which underlay their life and from which sprang all their brilliant blossoming." (p. i)

metadata.title: Introduction to Themis

content:
Harrison's first philosophical debt—to Bergson's *L'Évolution Créatrice* (1907):

> "I saw in a word that Dionysos, with every other mystery-god, was an instinctive attempt to express what Professor Bergson calls *durée*, that life which is one, indivisible and yet ceaselessly changing. I saw on the other hand that the Olympians, amid all their atmosphere of romance and all their redeeming vices, were really creations of what Professor William James called 'monarchical deism.' Such deities are not an instinctive expression, but a late and conscious representation, a work of analysis, of reflection and intelligence." (p. ii)

metadata.title: Introduction to Themis

content:
Harrison's second debt—to Durkheim's sociological theory:

> "The mystery-god arises out of those instincts, emotions, desires which attend and express life; but these emotions, desires, instincts, in so far as they are religious, are at the outset rather of a group than of individual consciousness. The whole history of epistemology is the history of the evolution of clear, individual, rational thought, out of the haze of collective and sometimes contradictory representations." (p. iii)

**Corollary**: "The form taken by the divinity reflects the social structure of the group to which the divinity belongs. Dionysos is the Son of his Mother because he issues from a matrilinear-group."

metadata.section: 3. The Debt to Durkheim: Collective Representation
metadata.title: Introduction to Themis

content:
Harrison distills her framework to two principles:

> "These two ideas, (1) that the mystery-god and the Olympian express respectively, the one *durée*, life, and the other the action of conscious intelligence which reflects on and analyses life, and (2) that, among primitive peoples, religion reflects collective feeling and collective thinking, underlie my whole argument and were indeed the cause and impulse of my book." (p. iii–iv)

metadata.title: Introduction to Themis

content:
The Palaikastro hymn provides the book's structure:

> "In commenting on this Hymn, discovered in the temple of Diktaean Zeus, I found to my delight that we had in it a text that embodied this very group-thinking, or rather group-emotion towards life, which I had begun to see must underlie all primitive religious representations. The Hymn sung by the Kouretes invoked a *daimon*, the greatest Kouros, who was clearly the projection of a *thiasos* of his worshippers." (p. iv)

---

metadata.section: 5. The Hymn of the Kouretes as Plot
metadata.title: Introduction to Themis

content:
| Aspect | Mystery Religion (Dionysos) | Olympian Religion (Zeus, Apollo) |
|--------|----------------------------|----------------------------------|
| **Represents** | *Durée*—life as indivisible, changing | Reflection, analysis, intellect |
| **Mode** | Instinctive expression | Conscious representation |
| **Social form** | Thiasos (group) | Individual worship |
| **Form of god** | Mutable (bull, snake, tree) | Fixed, human, beautiful |
| **Relation to death** | Dies and is reborn | Immortal, cannot die |
| **Religious value** | Authentic | Religiously dead |

metadata.title: Introduction to Themis

content: Harrison provides a detailed synopsis of each chapter:

metadata.title: Introduction to Themis

content: The Kouretes represent initiated young men of a matrilinear group. The *Daimon* they invoke is the Greatest Kouros, springing from the rite of initiation—a *dromenon* of New Birth into the tribe.

metadata.section: Chapter I: The Hymn of the Kouretes
metadata.title: Introduction to Themis

content: The *dromenon* is "a thing re-done, or pre-done with magical intent." The Dithyramb, origin of drama, was also a *dromenon* of New Birth.

metadata.section: Chapter II: The Dithyramb, the Dromenon and the Drama
metadata.title: Introduction to Themis

content: Sanctities (mana, tabu) precede divinities. "Le sacré c'est le père du dieu." The Omophagia (eating raw flesh) is a communal, sacramental feast understood through totemism.

metadata.title: Introduction to Themis

content: The seasonal *dromenon* at spring brings new life for man, animals, and plants. The Dithyramb is the Spring-Song of the Year-Festival.

metadata.section: Chapter VI: The Spring Festival and Hagia Triada
metadata.title: Introduction to Themis

content: The Games arose from a race of the Kouretes. The victor becomes the *Eniautos-Daimon*, the year-spirit incarnating the group's luck.

metadata.title: Introduction to Themis

content: The hero is not a historical great man but "a dead ancestor performing his due functions"—a functionary wearing the mask of an Eniautos-Daimon.

metadata.title: Introduction to Themis

content: Herakles failed to become Olympian because he remained an Eniautos-Daimon. Apollo succeeded. The Olympians shed their animal forms—"loss as well as gain."

metadata.section: Chapters IX-X: From Daimon to Olympian
metadata.title: Introduction to Themis

content:
Above all gods stands Themis—"social ordinance, the collective conscience projected, the Law or Custom that is Right."

---

metadata.title: Introduction to Themis

content:
Harrison explains her coinage:

> "I am well aware that no such conjunction as *Eniautos-Daimon* exists in Greek. I did not set out to invent any such word, nor did I even foresee its employment; it simply grew on my hands from sheer necessity.... I prefer 'Eniautos' to 'year' because to us 'year' means something definitely chronological, a precise segment as it were of spatialized time; whereas *Eniautos*, as contrasted with *etos*, means a period in the etymological sense, a cycle of waxing and waning." (p. vii)

---

metadata.title: Introduction to Themis

content:
Harrison's personal confession:

> "But, profoundly as I also feel the value of the religious impulse, so keenly do I feel the danger and almost necessary disaster of each and every creed and dogma. For the material of religion is essentially the uncharted, the ungrasped.... Further, every religious dogma errs in two ways. First, it is a confident statement about something unknown and therefore practically always untrustworthy; secondly, if it were right and based on real knowledge, then its subject-matter would no longer belong to the realm of religion; it would belong to science or philosophy." (p. xii)
